DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for inquiry and report by the last sitting day of 1989: The extent and nature of any practice among banks which does or may contravene the fundamental fiduciary duty of banker to client.

Translated into layman's terms, I intend, by this motion, to refer to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs the allegation that in many ways banks are excessively placing their own interests first. This has given rise to a crisis in respect of confidence concerning banking. It urgently warrants parliamentary and government attention. Reducing it even more to its fundamentals, this motion asks the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs to look at banks in Australia in 1989. Honourable senators will know that I bring this motion before the Senate as a result of considerable discussion and deliberation and presentation of materials to the Senate over the last six months. It has led me to the point at which I believe that a full-scale Senate inquiry into banking in Australia is warranted.

At the time that I was elected to the Senate 18 months ago as an Australian Democrats senator for New South Wales I was very clear on what my role in this place was. I had been thoroughly briefed by my predecessors that it was to keep the bastards honest. The only thing I was not clear about was how many there are. They are everywhere. It is in the spirit of that charter of keeping them honest that I place this proposal before the Senate this morning. I am disappointed, to say the least, to anticipate that it will be defeated by the combined vote of the Opposition and the Government. I emphasise that it is a simple proposal to place, in the public interest, before a parliamentary committee for thorough investigation, an issue of a crisis in respect of confidence in banking. As I say, I anticipate that it will be opposed by the combined vote of the Government and the Opposition.

I was moved to put this proposal before the Senate because approximately six months ago a constituent approached me with two extremely serious allegations, namely, that corrupt practices were widespread in one of Australia's banks. That allegation brought to me on that occasion related specifically to the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. The allegation was that corrupt practices were widespread through the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. The second aspect of the allegation, was that these matters had been well known to the Australian Federal Police for some years and that the AFP, to use an expression that I have used previously, had failed in its duty in this matter. Quite obviously, these are extremely serious allegations.

I deliberated over them for approximately six weeks. I examined the evidence that had been brought to me by the constituents who made these allegations. I took legal advice; I consulted with my colleagues. The first thing I did was to seek in early December 1988, by a confidential memo to the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), a briefing on these matters by the Australian Federal Police. I said, `Minister, I have got these allegations before me. Please can I be briefed on these matters by you and the Australian Federal Police?'. The memo was not even replied to, so I followed up with a verbal request for a briefing, which was denied. The briefing was denied on the ground that certain investigations were current. That tended to confirm the first of the allegations that there were before the Federal Police some allegations of corrupt practices within the Commonwealth Bank. That was cited as the reason for my not being briefed about it. This was in December 1988.

I made my first statement and revealed these allegations to the Senate on 8 December 1988 because I was unable to pursue the matter privately and satisfactorily with the Minister. I asked a series of questions of the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate. Frankly, I found his responses to those questions unacceptable. They tended to reinforce my doubts, and I had better explain why I found them unacceptable. One of the questions I asked the Minister was whether he was aware of serious allegations concerning corruption and malpractices in the Commonwealth Bank. In responding to that question, the Minister said that the Australian Federal Police had informed him that there was one such allegation and that he had been informed of that in April 1988.

I had in my possession a letter on the letterhead of the 60 Minutes program, signed by the program's producer. I was briefed to the effect that the program had a substantial file on these allegations. The allegations involved 32 senior officers of the Commonwealth Bank, including its former Managing Director. They were serious allegations. They obviously attracted my attention, and the attention of the 60 Minutes program, which had assembled a lot of information but had been advised legally not to proceed unless it had the protection of certain documents which it sought under the Freedom of Information Act. It sought those documents from the Australian Federal Police.

Seven months latter the police replied that they had investigated whether such documents existed and whether they were relevant to these allegations. They said they had identified 149 pages of documents, 40 of which they judged to be directly relevant to the allegations directed at 32 senior officers of the Commonwealth Bank, but they refused to provide them with the exception of half a page. They quoted the reasons why they refused to release them. One reason was that they might be embarrassing to overseas countries. Indeed, they must have been very embarrassing documents if the police were able to exempt themselves from providing them to the producers of the 60 Minutes program on the grounds that they were documents of considerable potential embarrassment to overseas governments and, presumably, therefore, to the Australian Government. So the program was denied access to those documents.

In the briefing to the Minister for Justice they told him that there had been one allegation about corrupt practice in April 1988 but they did not tell him that there had been allegations directed at 32 senior officers, including the former Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank, and that they had assembled 149 pages, 40 of which were relevant. In my judgment, that has to be an example of partial and inadequate briefing to the responsible Minister. It tended to confirm the second of the allegations that had been placed before me-namely, that the Australian Federal Police had been less than diligent in the pursuit of these matters. The expression that had been used to me was that there was a cover-up on. They are not my words; that is the expression that had been used to me, and this was the reaction to legitimate questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —By whom?
—By a person by the name of Donna Batiste who had tabled affidavits in the Supreme Court of New South Wales, and I have tabled them in the Senate subsequently.
—You were gullible enough to believe them.

—I am coming to that question of gullibility, or credibility of documents. I had sought a briefing from the Federal Police and had been denied it. I had asked questions of the Minister for Justice and got answers that I found unsatisfactory. I tabled in the Senate the copy of the 60 Minutes letter and the response from the Federal Police. I do not know whether honourable senators have looked at it. In a series of subsequent questions I asked the Minister whether he believed that he had been adequately briefed and he said yes. On 15 December I made a second statement to the Senate. I posed further questions to the Minister. I tabled six affidavits-including the ones I have just referred to, relating to allegations of corrupt practices with in the Commonwealth Bank-in relation to seven cases.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite predictably, the allegations were denied by the Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank, Mr Don Sanders. Frankly, I was not surprised that they were denied. He told me-and I use Mr Sanders's words-that he was surprised by my allegations. He was bewildered by them. I said to Mr Sanders that I was surprised by his surprise, for the simple reason that surely his legal officers would have told him at that time, that very day in the Supreme Court of New South Wales, there were at least three cases running on civil action against the Commonwealth Bank and I knew there were other cases running in other supreme courts around Australia, and if his legal officers had not told him about that, he, like the Minister, was only partially briefed. If his legal officers had not told him that in the previous year the Federal Police had identified 149 pages of documents, some of which were directed at allegations about his predecessor, the Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, he was, like the Minister grossly inadequately briefed. Frankly, I found it extremely difficult to accept as a fact that he found these allegations bewildering and that he was surprised by them, I believe that his dismissal of the allegations, although predictable, was unacceptable.

As a result of the tabling of these affidavits, between 15 December and 2 March, over the Christmas break, my office had literally thousands of phone calls. I am not exaggerating. I now have 150 cases that I consider to be credible. Senator Stone may not judge them as credible but I have made my judgments about them. I consider them to be credible cases of people who say that their banks have treated them very badly and abandoned the fiduciary relationship, the fundamental relationship of law that says that banks should consider the interests of the client to be at least equal to the interest of the bank. I have 150 such cases. I have tabled 27 of them in the Senate. They are a sample only. They range from millionaires to battlers, and they range across all the major banks in Australia. This flood of responses has led me to the conclusion that we have a major problem that should looked at by a Senate committee. That is what has led me today to propose that the Senate committee look into this matter.

Not only have I tabled the 27 affidavits in relation to 33 sample cases but also I am not exaggerating when I say that I have discussed this matter with hundreds of people, either on the phone or face to face. I have discussed it with lawyers, Queen's Counsel, journalists, bank managers, and ex-bank managers. I am utterly convinced that there is a problem of major proportions within banking in Australia which certainly warrants the reference of the question to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. It comes down to a general position of a dramatic shift in the ethos of banking in Australia in the last five to 10 years. Since deregulation in 1984 there has been intensification in competition between banks. Banks have become profit oriented; they have become oriented towards their own interests and less towards the interests of their clients. There has been a serious erosion of the fiduciary relationship and it has reached crisis proportions. Even if the Senate does not accept it today, the community knows that there is a crisis of confidence about banking. It will address itself to this crisis in other ways when this proposal is defeated by the combined vote of the Opposition and the Government today. The community will know who is pursuing its interests on this matter both inside and outside the Parliament.

As I said, there were totally predictable denials by Mr Sanders and Mr Allen Cullen, the executive officer of the Australian Bankers Association, but they were superficial. It is not good enough for Mr Cullen to say that banks are squeaky clean and that there is no corruption in banking. That is as credible as my saying that there is no corruption in politics; it is as credible as police commissioners saying that there is no corruption in the police force. There has been corruption in banking since the invention of the shekel 5,000 years ago, and since the invention of commerce. Banks are about money; corruption is about money. Corruption in banking is inevitable; it is merely a question of degree, it is a question of whether we focus on it and it is a question of whether we see it as a major national crisis.

As I said, I have had discussions with the Minister on this question. When I proposed that the whole matter go to a Senate standing committee, the Minister said, `Give me more time so I can take it to Caucus'. I did that. It was to be debated on 3 March; it is now 5 April. The extra time has been given. Presumably, it has gone to Caucus. If it has not, it is not my fault. I presume it has gone to the Caucus; the Caucus has seriously considered this proposition and decided against it for its own reasons. Its reasons are obvious because of what the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) has done in recent days. He has put the welfare of banks before the welfare of social security pensioners in this country. I will come to that point in a moment. The Government has its own agenda about banking and presumably the Opposition has its own agenda about banking.

I briefed Mr Andrew Peacock in the presence of Senator Messner, who will defend the Opposition's position in a moment. I have no doubt that he took it seriously. He told me that he would have access to all the affidavits that I had tabled, yet I am led to believe that yesterday in the party room his argument was that the Opposition could not interfere in this process because some of these matters were before courts. Of course, they are before courts. There will always be conflicts between clients and banks before courts. If we wait for that to stop before we perform our duties as members of parliament, we will be here until the end of time. The fact is that I was approached by people whose matters are before the courts. I said, `Have you discussed this with your lawyer?' and they said, `Yes'. I did not table their affidavits until I was certain that they had discussed it with their lawyers. Their lawyers believe that it will not interfere with the pursuit of their matters before the courts. The fact is that the banks win in courts. Banks have unlimited resources and access to the best legal minds, and they settle out of court before they even get to the court if there is anything of significance to be said. So that is a spurious rejection by Mr Peacock. It is just meaningless. It is grasping at straws. The Opposition will do anything to not have to take on the banks.

I had long discussions yesterday with Mr Allen Cullen and senior representatives of banking. They said, `But Senator McLean, did you investigate these matters that came before you?'. What more can I do with the limited resources that I have got than to talk to hundreds of people, to accept a thousand phone calls, to go through mountains of documents and to accept affidavits on oath? Do they really expect me to tell my constituents, when they come in prepared to swear something to me and to ask me to table it in the Parliament and put it before a Senate standing committee, `I do not believe you'? Do I begin from the fundamental assumption that people are lying to me when they swear on oath? Of course, that is a ridiculous proposition. I begin with the fundamental assumption that they are telling the truth when they swear on oath.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you check any of these allegations with the banks concerned?

—I have told Senator Stone that I have spent hundreds of hours of my own time, yet he asks: Have I checked this with the banks? Heaven's above, do lawyers go up to the opposition in court and say, `Let us sit down and let me share my information with you'? Of course they do not. We are adversaries in this debate and we do not go to our adversary and say, `Let me sit down and have a chummy yarn and table my documents'. Heaven's above! That is a ludicrous proposition.
—You want a one-sided kangaroo court. That is the problem.

—No, I do not. All I want is a Senate inquiry so both sides can come in and table a mountain of documents, if they want to, and be examined. I am not a lawyer; I am a parliamentarian. The honourable senator would agree with me, and he must agree with me, that our role as parliamentarians is fundamentally to take on good faith what we are told and make a subjective judgment, in the same way as we choose our wives, our business partners, our lawyers and our bankers. We sit down and talk to them for some time, look at the evidence they have got, eyeball them for a while and say eventually that we believe them or we do not. What the honourable senator is really saying to me is that I should start from the premise that they are liars. I am not prepared to do that. It is as simple as that. The proposition that I should conduct some sort of comprehensive investigation into all aspects of an affidavit that they have sworn on oath is ludicrous, and he knows it is ludicrous, and so does Mr Allen Cullen and those who are advancing the proposition on behalf of the Australian Bankers Association.
—It is all part of a conspiracy.

—No, it is not. I do not believe it is a conspiracy. So what can I, as a parliamentarian, do when my constituents come to me. I cannot do much more than I have done. I have said, `Please, can I speak to the Federal Police on this matter?', and I got a no answer. I said, `Minister, will you please help me on this matter?', and I got a no answer. I have come to the Senate and said, `Will you please help Australians on this matter?', and I am going to get a no answer this morning. The next thing I can do is go to the people. Do honourable senators know what I am going to get from them? I am going to get a yes answer. I believe that both the Government and the Opposition are making a very bad political judgment on this issue of banking. Having spoken to hundreds of people recently at a series of public meetings, I believe that there is as much ill will in the community about this issue as there was about the Australia Card. I believe that in the same way as the Government and the Opposition lacked perception about the Australia Card before the last election, they lack perception about the issue of banking before the next election. It will become a major issue in the coming election because we will make it a major issue.
—And the League of Rights agrees with you.

—The fact that the League of Rights agrees with us has nothing to do with it. Many people agree with us. I attended a public meeting in Adelaide on Wednesday which was convened conjointly by the United Farmers and the Trades and Labour Council of South Australia. The person who convened it was the National Secretary of the League of Rights. I, a Democrat senator, was the keynote speaker. What an extraordinary combination. What does that reflect? It reflects the degree of concern in the community. It is an issue which will bond people, not divide them.
—When did you find out that the meeting was convened by the Secretary of the League of Rights?
—I said that the man who had helped convene the meeting happened to be the National Secretary of the League of Rights. I found this out after the event.
—So you are being used in that way, too?

—Rubbish. I was not being used. To say that I am being used because I happen to sit down at a public meeting with some trade unionists, or with some farmers, or with people who belong to a strong action group is not justified. I do not believe that is being used. If I was being used as a parliamentarian I was being used in a constructive way, and in an appropriate way. I do not ask people what their politics are before I speak to their meetings on an issue I believe in. Senator Stone may do that; I do not.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us move on and look at some of the recent evidence of the attitude of the Government, the Opposition and the banks towards the Australian people. Let us go back a couple of days to when the Minister for Social Security said that he was prepared to condone banks getting access, by garnishee, to up to 14 per cent of pension payments. The law of the land which he is responsible for administering says that that is inappropriate. I know that there are divided opinions on this matter, but the law of the land says that that should not happen. If the intention of the law is to protect the accounts of the recipients of social service benefits, I believe it is the Minister's responsibility to ensure that the law is tested in a court or, alternatively, to change the law. Yet he condones the possible garnisheeing of up to 14 per cent of pension payments.

Let us look at articles in the Australian recently which suggest-and this is an explanation given by banks-that people who pay their Bankcard account promptly actually force up the rate of interest paid by those people who delay their payment. It is extraordinary logic for banks to be projecting to the public as justification for excessive interest rates on Bankcard. The banks are saying that the fact that some people pay promptly is responsible for the higher interest rates paid by the slow payers. It is an extraordinary situation. What about the attempt to justify special charges directed at people who have small bank accounts? Because one has a small bank account, one incurs a special charge. This does not even touch on the whole question of banks justifying increases in mortgage rates on housing month after month at a time when they are experiencing record profitability.

On the one hand, we have these actions of the banks, and on the other hand we sit in our homes and watch television advertisements which say that if we get on a camel or get into a four-wheel drive vehicle and drive into the Simpson Desert, everything will okay as long as we have our Bankcards in our hands. That is how good the banks are. It is a load of rubbish. That image of banks is projected at us through their advertising campaign. Yet we have these patterns of behaviour displayed week after week, month after month, and year after year. They are directed in the interests of the banks and contrary to the interests of their clients. They are condoned today by the Government and the Opposition.

I am simply saying to people in Australia who use banks that there is a crisis of confidence in banks. They know that to be true, and I know that to be true. I am saying, `Let's put the matter before a Senate standing committee to see whether there is any substance in these allegations of corrupt practices'. That will be rejected here today by the combined vote of the Government and the Opposition in the same way as my request for the Australian Federal Police to get a briefing on the allegations was refused. It will be rejected in the same way as my request for the Minister for Justice to intervene in this matter. He, I am told, induced Caucus to oppose this motion today. That is the situation we are confronted with in this chamber of the Parliament.

There is a plan B. There is another option, which is to go to the streets with these matters, to fill up the town halls of our capital cities, to say to people, `Come and tell us what you think about banks. You might not have been able to go to a Senate standing committee because that right was refused, but at least you can come to a public meeting at a town hall'. Honourable senators can bet that all sorts of legal writs will be filed on people for stating their opinions about banks publicly because they could not come before a legally constituted Senate inquiry into this matter. It is a massive travesty of justice. It is a gross misjudgment of this issue by both the Government and the Opposition. We are determined to make it a major issue as we move forward to the coming election, which may be only months away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the beginning it is worth looking at the modus operandi of the Australian Democrats in Australian politics and in this Parliament. I do not want to get too personal but I will deal with a few of them. Until he was removed at the last election-fortunately-we had the incomparable Senator Vigor. Senator Stone did not have Senator Vigor inflicted on him, but he made the rest of them look pretty good. We have League of Rights economics preached at us by Senator Coulter-ultimately derived from Major Douglas and transmitted to Senator Coulter via the League of Rights-a great deal of which appears to have been adopted by Senator McLean today. We have plant variety rights Powell. Senator Haines, more so now than in the past due to her doomed attempts to win a seat in the House of Representatives, takes every opportunity to win a little publicity. Now we have Senator McLean doing the same thing.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McLean is, as I said, picking up a line of argument which is unsubstantiated in any meaningful way but which is popular with a minority of people out in the country-that is, that banks are crook and banks are evil. I do not pretend that banks do not make mistakes. No human institution is free of fault or error. Nor do I imagine that banks are philanthropists. Banks are in business to make some money for themselves and some dividends for their shareholders. Senator McLean said that banks have become profit oriented. I thought they always were. But what Senator McLean is alleging goes well beyond saying that banks make mistakes or that banks are not philanthropists. He is alleging criminal activity. Allegations have been passed on to him by a variety of people and, on his own admission, he has made no attempt to check those allegations with the institutions against which the complaints were being levied. They are allegations not of mismanagement or of error; they are allegations of criminal activity. He uses the privilege of the Senate with absolutely no attempt to check out the facts. He uses the institution of parliamentary privilege to make those allegations public.

I suspect that because of his background-that is a background in which he has absolutely no knowledge of the private sector or of business-Senator McLean is particularly susceptible to some of the allegations which were being made. Banks make mistakes and so do individuals. Plenty of individuals borrow recklessly, and they get themselves into trouble. I regret to say that it is pretty clear that a number of financial institutions, including some banks, lend recklessly. There has been a pretty obvious example of that in Victoria over the last couple of years. That, however, is a different thing to criminal activity. Individuals make mistakes. I personally know people engaged in agriculture who in 1984 and 1985 were complaining about the short-sighted attitude of banks which would not lend them enough money. We were at the time approaching the end of a boom in agricultural land prices. It was argued by these people that banks should lend them additional funds, not on the reasonably assessed capacity to service the borrowings that they would have but on the increasing market price of the land. I have no doubt that similar things happened with the share market boom which finally collapsed in 1987. These people complained, `The banks will not lend me enough because they look at my capacity to generate income instead of the equity'-as it turned out, the illusory equity which they held in the land.

A few years later, of course, the land boom collapsed, as all booms collapse. The people then complained that they could not service the volume of debt, which they had previously alleged was inadequate and niggardly, that the banks had already provided. The banks took action to recover some of the loans which the borrowers were by then incapable of servicing. That appears to be the basis of the complaints in almost all of the cases that Senator McLean has referred to. I am not being particularly critical of the individuals concerned, but when that happened they were insolvent and on the road to bankruptcy-and they blamed the banks. It is not that unusual for people to blame somebody else when they are caught by bad luck, in many cases of course, supplemented by their own unrealistic expectations.

Senator McLean has acknowledged that in a number of these cases civil actions are running. It is in the civil courts or the criminal courts that allegations of misconduct or of criminal action should be pursued, not in the Parliament. Although more substantial evidence may come to light as a result of civil actions, I do not think anything that Senator McLean has presented could really be regarded as solid evidence. There are assertions by a number of individuals-assertions which he himself admits he made no attempt to check out-but they are unsupported, to the best of my knowledge, in any serious way by any independent evidence.

Senator McLean is running a conspiracy theory here. He has been associating with the League of Rights on these issues. He described the meeting in Adelaide as a fairly diverse group, an extraordinary collection, or something. I do not think it is an extraordinary collection at all. It was a collection of people who are at best ignorant and, at worst, something very much worse than that. As part of his conspiracy theory he is suggesting that the National Farmers Federation (NFF), which was party to a joint investigation of a number of the cases that he has put before us here, the Australian Bankers Association and the Australian Federal Police (AFP) are all involved in a cover-up. The Australian Bankers Association, the NFF and the Federal Police are a fairly diverse group. None of them is free of error or fault. But I find it implausible, extraordinary and ridiculous to suggest that those three organisations would be, for reasons which nobody can even hint at, collaborating in a cover-up to protect some particular banks against allegations of malpractice or criminal activities.

The only other point I want to make is that it is always easy for any politician, particularly a politician who belongs to a group, or is an individual, who will never be called upon to provide the funding for the various good ideas which they have, to get a bit of publicity and perhaps a bit of support for himself by presenting himself as standing up for the battler and the little man or woman against big institutions, be they government, the trading banks, the Bankers Association or whatever. But Senate inquiries are not free. The taxpayers pay for Senate inquiries. In my opinion, the Senate has already been irresponsible on a number of occasions in setting up inquiries into matters which were either too trivial or too silly to justify the expenditure of Commonwealth taxpayers' money on them and, in some cases, of course, were designed to do nothing other than attract publicity for the proposer of the inquiry-a category into which this one also probably falls.

These inquiries are not free, and the Senate cannot hold inquiries into everything. It should not hold inquiries into matters which have been raised on such flimsy `evidence' as has been presented by Senator McLean in support of the allegations which he has retailed into the Parliament. These are allegations which, I say again, he himself admits he made no attempt to verify. I understand that some of them concern matters which are already before the civil courts. The civil courts or the criminal courts, depending on what the allegations are, are the proper places for these matters to be determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposal before us today to refer to the Senate Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on investigation of banks was, as Senator McLean pointed out in his remarks, raised directly with the shadow Treasurer, Andrew Peacock, and me at a joint meeting that we had some month or two ago. Senator McLean produced information, some of which has found its way into the records of the Senate. He left the information with us so that we could further examine the matter in terms of the kinds of complaints that were set out therein. Naturally, at the time we met with Senator McLean we were interested in the issue. We certainly wanted to find out more about the allegations. We set about doing so by investigating the papers and the information that he had left with us.

SPEECH.PARA: It seemed at first that three broad categories of problems arose from the papers left with us. Firstly, there were allegations by those swearing the affidavits that there was, on the part of the banks, deliberate asset stripping of specifically targeted businesses. Secondly, some clients had been involved, according to their allegations, in foreign borrowings and there had been a non-disclosure by banks of risk information relating to borrowing in those foreign currencies. Thirdly, there was what was termed `premature foreclosure' on rural property holdings. Of course, all of those three areas are areas of concern. If the allegations that were set down in the information could be substantiated, of course there would be substantial reason for further investigation. We are certainly sympathetic to the concerns of all those people who have found themselves in unfortunate situations but, for a number of reasons, we cannot support the motion that Senator McLean is putting forward today.

Let me now mention a number of questions which I think have to be resolved before we could agree to support the motion before us today. First and foremost, only part of the information has yet been provided by Senator McLean. Of course, there is conflicting information, some of which we have investigated, which discloses an alternative view of the facts in many of the cases outlined. Therefore it would be necessary for any Senate committee to establish itself as a court of law, if you like, to investigate both sides of those various questions. We are not talking here about points of law; we are talking about facts. We are talking about points of fact which would be evidence that would have to be debated, discussed and adjudicated upon by the Senate committee in order to determine the truth of the original information.

Secondly, we ask the question: Would any such inquiry achieve anything meaningful at all? I think the answer to that would be a resounding no because, simply, the Senate committee would be faced with an enormous task of becoming an adjudicator, becoming in effect a court of law having to sit on many hundreds of cases such as already admitted by Senator McLean, that it would end up with a never-ending job of trying to come to some conclusion about the issues which he has raised. Quite clearly, in the end that task is beyond the capacity of a Senate committee. Of course, Senate committees were never designed to become courts of law.

Thirdly, as the Minister for Finance has pointed out, the legal system is the proper place to review such disputes, such conflicts of information. As we know, there are many cases already before the courts, some heard, some not heard, some partially heard. Some have been settled by banks in favour of complainants as a result of a good case being made out. But quite clearly there are circumstances where that may not occur. It would not seem to be the proper role of a Senate committee to sit and review cases such as that.

Fourthly, it is quite possible that, by taking this action, the Senate would be doing more harm to the system and to the interests of those complainants who have come to Senator McLean than it would do good. It is quite possible that many of the issues raised would show some of the complainants to have been very poor businessmen. It may be shown, for instance, that much of the detailed information available would disclose that their careers perhaps should be subject to greater scrutiny than they have been already. There are not necessarily going to be circumstances which arise which lead to decisions in favour of those individual complainants in the way in which Senator McLean may well contemplate.

For that reason, what is really an inadequate vehicle for the investigation of these issues should not in fact be placed in a position where it could damage the interests of the very people Senator McLean is seeking to help. In fact, one could be so uncharitable as to suggest that this is really a cruel hoax on the people who have brought their complaints to Senator McLean, in the sense that he wishes to use these people in some kind of way to gain publicity for himself and for the Australian Democrats, knowing full well that the issues can never properly be resolved by a vehicle established by this Senate.

Of course, that is the essential element, the essential point, of this debate. I would like to clarify that a little more. This issue boils down to the question of the adequacy of Senate committees to do the kind of job which Senator McLean is claiming they should do. The answer is a resounding no. It is totally inappropriate for Senate committees to adopt the kind of investigation the honourable senator is proposing. If we look at the proposed terms of reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, we can see that even more clearly. It is proposed that the Senate committee would inquire into:
The extent and nature of any practice among banks which does or may contravene the fundamental fiduciary duty of banker to client.

This refers to `any practice among banks'. Obviously there are going to be some practices which reflect on the operations of banks. Nobody is infallible. Obviously there are going to be some practices which reflect on the capacity of individual clients of the banks. Both of those sides of the question would have to be examined. They should be all subject to the evidentiary rules of law which would have to be considered by non-judicial people-mere politicians, not judges-sitting on a Senate committee, people who are not familiar with the law, in many cases not trained in anything except a rudimentary sense to be able to make and apply proper legal judgments.

That is surely argument enough to cast aside what I suggest is the rather ill-considered proposition that comes from the Democrats. There is nothing in this proposition that is going to alleviate the hardship of those people who have found themselves in the unfortunate circumstances which have led them to come to Senator McLean with their complaints. Many have lost their properties. Many have lost their businesses. Many of them have lost more than that. Those points have been made clear in many of the documents that Senator McLean has put forward. But no one word that will be put in evidence to the Senate Committee, not one decision or conclusion to which a Senate committee comes, will assist those people any more than they have been assisted already by various other means. Their answer will flow from proper legal determinations taken in courts of law or resolved in other fashions. This Committee is simply not the body to help. It is not a way in which those people can seek redress and support in the situations in which they unfortunately find themselves. I believe it to be cruel for any senator to suggest that there might be some result which flows from a Senate committee decision which might assist those individuals. That is really playing those people for fools.

That is the essence of our complaint about this motion and why we will not support it. There are perhaps some other observations that ought to be made. Of course, I did not expect the Minister to make them. Many of the predicaments which some of Senator McLean's constituents have found themselves in have arisen through the direct policies of this Government. We have seen in recent times the highest interest rates in living memory. There is nothing more conducive to the failure of a business-such as a rural activity, for instance-than out of control interest rates where the financing of, if you like, one's basic capital is subject to huge rises in annual costs to service those loans. I instance the case of many people on the west coast of my own State of South Australia who have suffered because of enormous increases in interest rates-some as high as 23 per cent-on rural loans. In those circumstances those people find that every three years their total debt owing to the bank doubles. That would mean that within three years, in many cases, their equity would have totally disappeared. This has arisen as a direct result of the Hawke Government's policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yet you argue that there is no need for an inquiry into banks. You are arguing the very point.

—It is a totally different issue and, unless Senator McLean can see that, there is something wrong with him. The point is, quite simply, that it is policies emanating from the Hawke Labor Government that have brought these things about. As Senator McLean well and truly knows, it has controlled interest rate policy in this country and has demolished many businesses. Perhaps in a calmer moment he might acknowledge that.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that there has been an inappropriate policy mix in this country for some years. Even the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia has pointed out in recent days that the Government has failed on micro-economic policy. It has failed to reform the waterfront, failed to reform industrial relations and failed to get rid of stupid, inefficient and uneconomic work practices, which add so much to the cost of production in this country and which damage our ability to sell on the world markets and to employ Australians. Those are the things that are at the core of the problem that has brought constituents to see Senator McLean. Many of the people whom Senator McLean has mentioned have found themselves in the vice, caught by rising interest rates and falling demand for their products and in a situation where the value of their properties has declined and their equity has been wiped out. Much of it is directly attributable to the Hawke Government's policies. Perhaps we could set up a Senate committee to investigate that. That might produce a more worthwhile answer than Senator McLean's suggestion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats are supporting the Government on economic policy.

—Yes, as Senator Stone points out, since 1983 the Democrats have consistently supported the Hawke Labor Government's policies which have brought us to the current debt level of $140,000m. They have brought about the highest tax rates as well as the highest interest rates in history, which are doing so much to damage incentive in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I will sum up the position of the Liberal and National parties. We certainly appreciate the difficulties experienced by many people that have been brought to our attention by Senator McLean. However, we do not believe that the Senate inquiry would be the best course to follow, for the following reasons. First, it would not offer any real help to the aggrieved parties. Secondly, in the form envisaged by Senator McLean it could only merely duplicate what is already known. It could only amount to the presentation of information which has already been put forward in the Senate-unless, of course, the inquiry establishes itself as a court of law, and that is beyond its capacity. Thirdly, the legal system is certainly the best place for individuals to pursue their cases where there is any suggestion of malpractice. Certainly, as I said earlier, I know of cases in which settlements have already been entered into by the banks with complainants to ensure that justice is done.

Finally, I believe that the Senate inquiry could do more harm than good for the constituents of Senator McLean. It is certainly not an area where we can help in these particular circumstances. I conclude by saying that I believe that to lead these people to believe that their problems can be solved by a Senate inquiry is a cruel hoax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion before the Senate from Senator McLean, to have these matters referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, is both ill-conceived and-I will go farther and say-mischievous. Senator McLean embarked upon this matter some time ago, during the previous Budget session, when he tabled in this place a number of affidavits from people alleging themselves to be aggrieved borrowers from the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. In the context of those affidavits, Senator McLean launched himself upon the view that we had a whole series of misdoings by the Commonwealth Bank and its officers, ranging from extremely bad advice and bad banking practice at one end-at the more minor end of his charges-to corruption, personal peculation, fraud, connivance with other persons or persons unknown, and, not least, corruption involving-at the furthest extreme of Senator McLean's increasingly wild allegations-the overt cooperation and collaboration of members of the Australian Federal Police.

SPEECH.PARA: This morning we heard Senator McLean extend those wild claims even further-I think to his personal shame; but that is by the way. That was where the matter began. I will have something more to say about that later. But I wanted to begin by spelling out how this matter began in that manner and how the skein has gradually unravelled until we now have a much wider patchwork of matters which Senator McLean wishes us to refer to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

Senator McLean's next move was to table in this place a further set of allegations, again almost entirely by way of affidavit, after the Senate resumed for the current session. But because I suspect Senator McLean has found some degree of reserve on the part of even the people he has been taking some advice from, such as his own colleagues in the Australian Democrats, as to the sustainability of these extraordinary charges that he has been making, Senator McLean has seen fit, in the motion now before us, to widen very considerably the ambit of the topic into which he wishes the Senate Committee to inquire to include not merely these specific instances of peculation, fraud, maladministration and corruption, which was where his allegations began, but also such matters as the whole question of how the banks conduct their affairs in this country.

In the course of his remarks this morning he referred, for example, to interest rates on Bankcard, special charges imposed or sought to be imposed by some of the banks on the accounts of very small depositors and the exorbitant level to which housing loan interest rates have now been pushed up. Of course, I would be the first to agree with him on that. But I do not think it has anything to do with the banks; it has a great deal to do with the policies of this Government, which Senator McLean and his colleagues have been supporting consistently for the past six years. Senator McLean has widened the ambit of his proposed inquiry to take account of those matters.

I believe that even he, when he wakes up in the middle of the night and wonders just how he came to be involved in this and whether he has been wise to pursue these kinds of wild allegations, has had a touch, just a twinge, of doubt as to whether the nonsense he has been talking will not result, if the Committee ever did get around to inquiring about them, in his emerging with the proverbial egg all over his features. Therefore, in order to give the inquiry some semblance of respectability, he has sought to widen it to take into account the whole practices of the banking system. Senator McLean may or may not realise it, but what he is really calling for is another royal commission of inquiry into the banking system of Australia. The last of those was in 1935.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are long overdue for another.

—Senator McLean, by way of interjection, says that we are long overdue for another one. If Senator McLean were to come into this place and argue that we are long overdue for an inquiry into the banking system of this country because it is 54 years since we last had one, at least we would have some kind of respectable basis on which to have a discussion. In those circumstances, of course, the worst way of holding such an inquiry would be to have it held by a committee of this place. As I said, on the last occasion on which we had such an inquiry, in 1935, it was a royal commission. Mr Chifley was a member of that commission; so was a subsequent Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia, Sir John Phillips, now deceased. That was a high level, heavyweight royal commission of inquiry into a serious subject.
—What would we get out of this one?

—If I may respond to the interjection by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, what we would get out of this one is a lot of television coverage for Senator McLean, which is what this shabby parliamentary device is directed towards obtaining. I cannot speak too strongly in my condemnation of Senator McLean's behaviour in this place in respect of this. It seems to me that what he has done, and is prepared to do without the slightest compunction, is to get up in this place and smear all manner of people, both collectively and in many cases individually, in the interests of his grubby little political exercise.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me mention one or two of the people whom he smeared. In his remarks supporting this motion this morning he has personally smeared Mr Tim Besley, the previous Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. He has smeared Mr Don Sanders, the current Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. Without naming the individuals concerned, he has smeared in a general reference 42 senior officers of the Commonwealth Bank.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thirty-two.

—I accept the correction. Senator McLean says 32. Only 32 senior officers of the Commonwealth Bank has he smeared. I hope he takes comfort in the correction. He has had not the slightest compunction in saying in this place this morning that before putting down these allegations in the Senate last December he made no attempt to check them with the people whose bona fides and professional careers he was traducing by doing so.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me just say something about the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. I hold no particular brief for the Commonwealth Bank. I think that over the years it has been a less well run bank in many respects than its private sector competitors, although I am bound to say with considerable pleasure that in recent years it has lifted its game considerably following a major reorganisation in which I personally had some hand in my last year in the Treasury and in which I take some pride. Because of my past associations and as a result of my then office as Secretary to the Treasury, I sat on the board of the Commonwealth Bank for 5 1/2 years. I know something about the institution as an institution. I know something about the way such an institution works, a matter about which quite clearly Senator McLean is totally and palpably ignorant, as we all know he is about most matters economic or financial.

I also know something about some, although not 32, of the most senior officers of that bank. I know something particularly about the present Managing Director, Mr Don Sanders, who has been personally known to me for nearly 33 years. For most of that time during his distinguished career he was a senior officer and eventually became Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia until a year or so ago when he was appointed Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia by the present Government. I simply want to put on the record without dwelling on it that, in my opinion, when Senator McLean casts the kind of personal slur that he has this morning on the personal standing and character of Don Sanders, it is a disgrace to him personally, to the party that he represents and, I suppose, in one sense to the procedures of this place that he should be permitted to do so. But I do not want to pursue that generalisation.

After receiving these allegations last December Senator McLean chose to put them down in this place without even asking for a comment about them from the Commonwealth Bank. He made no inquiry of the Commonwealth Bank as to whether it had any comment to make about the allegations concerned. When I made that point this morning in the course of Senator McLean's remarks by way of interjection, what did Senator McLean say? He said, `What a ludicrous idea that I should actually take these complaints to the Commonwealth Bank and ask it for its views. Is that what you normally do when you are dealing with an adversary?'. That was his word. I take it that Senator McLean will not correct me on that. In other words, Senator McLean had already convicted the Commonwealth Bank. It was already his adversary in this matter.

I spent a fair bit of time in public life as a bureaucrat, as a public servant, and it has always seemed to me that before someone gets out, particularly into an area like the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia, and starts launching accusations of the most serious kind involving individuals, which accusations, if they were to be believed, would result in total discredit and destruction of the careers of those individuals, he should make at least some attempt to check the facts. While not necessarily in any way suggesting that Senator McLean would have been bound to accept the views or comments given to him by the Commonwealth Bank had he bothered to check his facts, I nevertheless put it to him through you, Mr Deputy President, that his failure even to seek the comments was totally disgraceful.

After Senator McLean had made his allegations to the Senate, those allegations were naturally immediately brought to the attention of the Commonwealth Bank. I have recently received from the Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank copies of letters which Mr Sanders wrote in February and, in one case, March of this year to Senator McLean setting out the detailed results of the detailed internal inquiry which the bank then conducted into the allegations that Senator McLean had made. I understand that as at 22 March Senator McLean had not even acknowledged receipt of those letters from the Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank, the institution whose probity in this matter he is seriously attacking and criticising. I do not want to take up the time of the Senate-in any case I would not have the time to do so-because the four letters concerned are extremely lengthy and cover in considerable detail the particular complaints made by some of the complainants concerned. Mr Sanders, in his letter to me forwarding this material, said:
The bank is very reluctant to make public its dealings with customers but in the circumstances we feel obliged to do so.

I fully understand that feeling on his part. After all, the customers in these cases had not the slightest compunction in making what they alleged to be their own circumstances known to Senator McLean. Senator McLean had not the slightest compunction in tabling those by way of affidavits in this place, thereby making them known even more widely. Mr Sanders's letter continues:
We therefore make the information available to you with no restriction as to use.
It is on the basis of that freedom that I feel able to seek leave of the Senate to have incorporated in Hansard the four letters concerned.
Leave granted.
The letters read as follows-
9 February 1989
Senator the Honourable Paul McLean
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Dear Senator McLean
RE: ALLEGATIONS AGAINST COMMONWEALTH BANK OF AUSTRALIA BY DONALD M. BENSON
Mr Benson's complaints in the material tabled are numerous, but are summarised in the tenth paragraph of his Affidavit affirmed on 14 December 1988 and tabled by you the following day.

As stated in the letter dated 26 September 1988, various allegations made by Mr Benson had been examined as well as the general conduct of dealings between the Bank and the companies in which Mr Benson and his son were interested and my deputy was satisfied that a sympathetic and correct approach had been adopted by the Bank in its dealings with Mr Benson and his companies.

The same letter noted that there are many aspects of the points raised by Mr Benson which are in conflict with the Bank's records. While I do not consider it is necessary or appropriate to deal seriatim with the many points raised by Mr Benson, the nature of his allegations, as summarised in the tenth paragraph of his Affidavit beforementioned, makes it appropriate that his complaints be put within the context of the dealings by companies with which he is concerned with the Bank.

Mr Benson and his wife, B. L. Benson, first furnished relevant security to the Bank on 10 February 1984 when they executed a mortgage over a property known as ``Cryon Park'' to secure advances to one of their companies, Don Benson Pty Limited. In October 1984 Mr and Mrs Benson executed a guarantee to secure advances to another of their companies, Polygraph Products Pty Limited.

Early in December 1986, when making a visit to the factory of Polygraph Products Pty Limited, officers of the Bank became aware that certain businesses and assets thought to have been owned by Polygraph Products Pty Limited were variously owned by a company then called Mornway Pty Limited, which has since changed its name to Australian Drafting Supplies Pty Limited, or by Don Benson Pty Limited, or by Mr Benson and his son, W. P. M. Benson in their personal capacity.

By letter dated 9 December 1986 to Polygraph Products Pty Limited, the Bank stated it would require execution of equitable mortgages by all companies concerned and the execution of Traders' Bills of Sale by the Bensons personally as owners of various parts of the business. One of the effects of that security would be that each of the companies and individuals within the Benson family group would become liable for the debts of each of the other of them.

On 20 August 1987 the aggregate of the debts to the Bank on the accounts of Polygraph Products Pty Limited was in excess of $540,000.00. On that day the directors of the company delivered to the Bank a copy of a report of that date made by Messrs Hamilton Taylor & Brien, Chartered Accountants, who had undertaken an investigation of Polygraph Products Pty Limited at the request of its directors. That report contains the following statement:

``The estimated deficiency of assets to meet liabilities for the company, subject to the various matters dealt with in the notes on Annexure ``A'' hereto, is $731,635.00. It is apparent in this regard the company is hopelessly insolvent.''
The minutes of a meeting of the directors of Polygraph Products Pty Limited held on 20 August 1987 records:

``A letter report from Hamilton, Taylor & Brien was tabled and the contents in relation to the company's current financial position were discussed. The directors note the apparent insolvency position and it was resolved:

``To attend at the company's bankers, being the secured creditor, to request they take action under the terms of the security, it being the opinion of directors that the company should cease trading and not incur any further credit''.''

Having regard to that report and resolution and bearing in mind that all companies and individuals within the Benson family group are liable for each other's debts, it is apparent that there is no substance in Mr Benson's reference in his Affidavit to ``the buoyancy of the business'' or in the assertion that he had ``a viable business''.

On 27 August 1987 the Bank received a report from KMG Hungerfords, Chartered Accountant, now KMG Peat Marwick Hungerford, on Polygraph Products Pty Limited and its associated companies, in which it noted the indebtedness of the Benson group to the Bank was $911,349.00. That report expressed the opinion ``It is imperative to take immediate action to appoint either an agent for the (Bank as) mortgagee in possession or a receiver and manager over the assets of Polygraph Products Pty Limited.'' In relation to the other companies in the group, those accountants said ``It appears to be prudent to allow the directors a period of 2-3 months in which to arrange alternative financing.''

The Bank acted on those recommendations and ultimately allowed Mr Benson and his family more than nine months to attempt to arrange alternative finance. Those attempts at refinancing, either from another bank or other financial institution, continued until 2 June 1988 by which date it became apparent that the latest of the attempts to refinance made by the Benson group had not succeeded.

The Bank arranged for an auction of the Cryon Park property to take place on 9 November 1988. There was no bid at the auction. The conduct of Mr D M Benson and other members of his family prior to and at that auction was considered to have had the effect of deterring potential purchasers. On that basis the Bank decided to proceed with obtaining Orders for Possession of the ``Cryon Park'' property which is owned by D M Benson and his wife and of another property known as ``Hidden Valley'' owned by Polygraph Products Pty Limited, the latter property being vacant land.

The return date for both Summonses for Orders for Possession was 15 December 1988. The occupiers of ``Cryon Park'' were Mr D M Benson, his wife, their daughter, their son-in-law and an infant grandchild. Immediately prior to the hearing of those Summonses, Mr D M Benson and his son, W P M Benson, in their respective capacities as individuals and as directors of Polygraph Products Pty Limited acknowledged receipt of a letter dated 14 December 1988, a photocopy of which is attached. The effect of that letter is to allow the occupants of the properties to remain in possession until after the Bank obtains a purchaser for them, provided the occupants co-operate with the Bank in relation to any such sale. The Bank was granted Orders for Possession of the property and agreed that it would not enforce those Orders before 31 January 1989. Mr Benson and his families are still in possession of the properties.
The highest offer the Bank has received for the properties was well below both the amount owing to it and the independent valuation obtained by the Bank.

The Bank and its staff have done nothing to warrant the complaints and allegations made by Mr Benson. On the contrary, the Bank has been very considerate in the measure of latitude it has extended to Mr Benson and his companies. The Bank commenced its actions to enforce its securities over the assets of Mr Benson and his family's group of companies at the express request of a meeting of directors of Polygraph Products Pty Limited which meeting was chaired by Mr Benson.

The Bank has been generous in its forbarance since August 1987 and has given Mr Benson and his family ample opportunity to either repay or refinance the liabilities of the group to the Bank. Those liabilities now aggregate in excess of $990,000.00. The Bank is still exercising restraint while it attempts to obtain the maximum feasible price for the properties mortgaged to it. Mr Benson and his companies remain entitled to sell the properties and meet their liabilities from the proceeds of sale, or by any other means available to them.
Your sincerely
D N SANDERS

Dear Senator McLean
Re: ALLEGATIONS AGAINST COMMONWEALTH BANK OF AUSTRALIA BY WADE E. COX

The allegations by Mr Cox, so far as they relate to the Commonwealth Bank, seem to be that the Bank made an unauthorised disbursement of $75,000 and thereby induced a critical liquidity crisis in the operations of the business of his firm and destroyed its capacity to complete the feed lot operation for which money had been borrowed.

The disbursement referred to was made by the Bank on 22 July 1985 to Dalgety-Winchcombe FGC a Division of Dalgety Farmers Limited (Dalgetys). The Bank does not hold written instructions to pay to Dalgetys the subject $75,000 or indeed any amount, out of the moneys advanced at that time to Mr Cox and his partners. However, the Bank's records evidence that the payment was made with the verbal authority of Mr Cox given before the payment was made.

By memorandum dated 3 May 1985 the Kiama branch of the Bank submitted an application for finance to the Bank's Illawarra Regional Office on behalf of Mr Cox, his wife and mother. The purpose of the finance requested included-
to ``pay out Westpac $105,000
pay out Dalgetys $110,000
fund feed lot $60,000
fund irrigation system $60,000''

The Bank acknowledges that, at the time the application for finance was first made, part of the amount of $60,000, described as to ``fund feed lot'' was intended to meet the cost of structures which would make up a feed lot and the amount was not necessarily to be wholly applied to the purchase of livestock for that feed lot. That common understanding between Mr Cox and the Bank is reflected in his letter dated 24 July 1985 in which he states ``you are advised that the $60,000 to fund the feed lot was for silo construction etc as well as stock purchases from Dalgetys''.

The misunderstanding which developed between Mr Cox and the Bank seems to have arisen from the fact that, after the initial submission by the Bank's Kiama branch to its Regional Office, Mr Cox called at the Regional Office, on 16 May 1985, to discuss his financial needs. As a result of those discussions, changes were made in the details of the finance approved from that which was originally requested. Those changes included increasing the amount to be paid to Dalgetys from the sum of $110,000, shown in the original application for finance, to the sum of $125,000 specifically requested by Mr Cox on 16 May 1985 and approved by the Bank on that day. The sum of $60,000 to ``fund feed lot'' remained unchanged.

At the request of Mr Cox, made at the interview on 16 May 1985, the Bank informed Dalgetys' Sydney Representative by telephone that facilities had been approved to Mr Cox to pay out his then existing debt to Dalgetys of $125,000 and to fund the feed lot to the extent of $60,000. The purpose of that telephone call to Dalgetys was to enable Mr Cox to purchase stock at the Braidwood sales the following day. Mr Cox purchased cattle at that sale taking his then total indebtedness to Dalgetys to $237,599.10. That level of indebtedness was allowed in anticipation of Dalgetys receiving from the Bank sums aggregating $185,000 which the Bank, on the previous day at the specific request of Mr Cox, had informed Dalgetys was available for that purpose.

The misunderstanding between the Bank and Mr Cox was continued when, by a letter dated 11 July 1985, the Kiama branch of the Bank informed Mr Cox that, amongst other things, the amount approved to pay out Dalgetys was $110,000, instead of the increased amount of $125,000 approved by the Regional Office at the request of Mr Cox. In that same letter, in relation to the $60,000 to fund feed lot, it was noted-
``we understand this has already been utilized and reflects in your current debt to Dalgetys''

When the branch wrote its letter dated 11 July 1985 to Mr Cox and his partners, it overlooked that the amount initially to be paid to Dalgetys had been increased by the Regional Office at the request of Mr Cox to $125,000. The branch was also not aware that, at the request of Mr Cox, the Regional Office had informed Dalgetys that the $60,000 to fund feed lot had been approved and was available to enable Mr Cox to purchase stock at sales the following day.

When the Kiama branch paid only $110,000 to Dalgetys, Dalgetys brought to the attention of the branch that it should have received $125,000 as approved by the Bank's Regional Office at the request of Mr Cox. At the same time, Dalgetys produced an invoice for the sum of $84,137.50 for stock purchased by Mr Cox on his account with Dalgetys, after the Bank had informed Dalgetys that the sum of $60,000 to fund the feed lot had been approved. On receipt of that information and invoice, the Bank paid to Dalgetys the further sum of $75,000, being the additional sum of $15,000 which should have been paid at the outset plus the $60,000 for purchase of stock for the feed lot.

All moneys paid by the Bank to Dalgetys were paid for the specific purpose for which they were borrowed. Those moneys were paid in circumstances in which, at the request of Mr Cox, the Bank had telephoned to inform Dalgetys that the moneys were available for that purpose and had confirmed that information to Dalgetys. In these circumstances, the Bank is satisfied the payment of not only the initial $110,000, but also the additional sum of $75,000, was authorised verbally by Mr Cox.

The Bank denies that any payment by it to Dalgetys was unauthorised. It also denies that any such payment induced the liquidity crisis which Mr Cox claims was induced. In this regard it is noted that, by letter dated 24 July 1985, Mr Cox, after being informed by the Bank that the $60,000 to fund the feed lot had been approved and that the branch understood it had been utilized and reflected in his firm's debt to Dalgetys, stated ``the irrigation system money (which was also $60,000) was to be utilized, firstly for some cattle purchases until November 1985''.

It is apparent from the foregoing that not only was the $60,000 approved to fund feed lot used by Mr Cox to purchase cattle, but it was also his intention to use the further $60,000 approved to fund an irrigation system, for the purchase of further cattle at least until November 1985.

It is always a matter for regret when a respected businessman such as Mr Cox, with apparently good potential, does not succeed in a move to expand his business. While the Bank will do what it reasonably can to tide a customer over temporary financial difficulties, ultimately it must require repayment to it of moneys lent. If that cannot be achieved from income produced or refinancing, then sale of the business on a voluntary or involuntary basis becomes necessary. In this case Mr Cox chose to sell his business.
Your sincerely
D. N. SANDERS
8 February 1989

Dear Senator McLean
Re: ALLEGATIONS AGAINST COMMONWEALTH BANK OF AUSTRALIA BY DEREK GILLILAND TRADING AS THE GREAT AUSTRALIAN HAT COMPANY

I have had an investigation carried out into the allegations contained in the papers tabled in the Senate by you on 15 December 1988. I would be happy to discuss them with you, when you can find the time.

You drew particular attention to claims made by Mr Gilliland, who traded under the name ``The Great Australian Hat Company''. In view of the serious nature of those claims I feel I should put the result of our investigation on record and let you know that we have found no hint of substance in any of the assertions made by Mr Gilliland against the Commonwealth Bank and its staff.

In view of the selected details of his dealings with the Bank, given in the statement made by Mr Gilliland tabled by you, it is appropriate that I provide you with relevant details to give a balanced view of Mr Gilliland's dealings with the Bank.

On 2 February 1988, Mr Gilliland approached the Booragoon branch of the Commonwealth Bank with a tentative proposal that it provide his firm with an unsecured overdraft limit of approximately $50,000-00 and take over the firm's banking from another bank.
On 15 February 1988, Mr Gilliland formally applied to the Bank for an overdraft limit of $100,000-00. Further information was requested so a decision on his application could be made.

By 17 March 1988 the additional information requested by the Bank had not been provided, but as a measure of assistance, an overdraft limit of $30,000-00 was approved against the security of a Bill of Sale over the business of his firm.

Five days later, Mr Gilliland requested an extension of the $30,000-00 limit by $10,000-00 pending completion of an application by him to the Small Business Development Corporation of Western Australia for a State Government Guarantee for $100,000-00. The Bank complied with that request.

By 29 April 1988, the debt on the subject account, which still had an approved limit of only $30,000-00, had reached $72,162-00. That debit over the approved limit had been allowed having regard to Mr Gilliland's assurance that certain funds were due to him and his undertaking not to issue further cheques until the funds then expected had been received.

By 3 May 1988 the debt on Mr Gilliland's account had reduced to $57,977-75, but a cheque for $53,572-24 had been presented and dishonoured with the answer ``Present again-arrangements incomplete''. Mr Gilliland was critical of the Bank for not providing further support for his business. Upon receiving a certain deposit and upon being satisfied that a further deposit would be likely to be received within a few days, the Bank paid the cheque for $53,572-24 thereby committing itself to a short term debt of over $100,000-00.

On 6 May 1988 Mr Bevan, the Manager of the Bank's Boorangoon branch, received a telephone call from the Premier's Department of Western Australia. Mr Gilliland was said to have contacted that Department through the then Premier, Mr Burke, and influenced it into accepting that his application to the Small Business Development Corporation was one of urgency. At the request of Mr Brian Slerempel of the Small Business Development Corporation, a meeting with Mr Bevan and Mr Gilliland took place at the offices of the firm. At that meeting Mr Bevan gained the impression from Mr Slerempel that Mr Gilliland's application was receiving favourable consideration.

By 24 May 1988 the Bank had been informed that the Small Business Development Corporation had declined the application to it by Mr Gilliland. The debt to the Bank had risen to $108,979-00. As the guarantee from the Small Business Development Corporation, which the Bank had anticipated would be security for its overdraft to Mr Gilliland, would not be available, the Bank informed Mr Gilliland that it required him to reduce the debt on his firm's account to the agreed limit of $30,000-00 as a matter of urgency.

While awaiting action by Mr Gilliland, the Bank continued to support him by paying essential cheques, such as those for wages and materials, to such an extent that by 14 July 1988 the debt on the account had risen to $119,000-00.

The Bank's concern with the conduct of Mr Gilliland's account is shown by the letter dated 14 July 1988 to Mr Gilliland from our Chief State Manager's Department in Perth. A copy of that letter is attached. On 18 July 1988 Mr Gilliland informed the Bank he had had enough of the business and wanted to retire as soon as possible. He said that a representative of his brokers had been to his premises that morning and expected to be able to conclude a sale within three or four weeks.

The Bank continued to support Mr Gilliland by paying cheques drawn by him, which took the debt on his account to a total of $241,043-88 by the time he completed the sale of his business on 18 October 1988.

Mr Gilliland's assertion of a conspiracy between the Bank and Mr Gannon is categorically denied. Mr Gannon was an employee of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation until July 1970. The Bank had no part in the introduction of Mr Gannon to Mr Gilliland. Indeed Mr Gilliland had informed the Bank, following receipt of its letter dated 14 July 1988, that he was proposing sale of the business and had engaged the services of Charthill Professional Pty Limited, as his broker, and that is the party which introduced Mr Gannon to Mr Gilliland.

The only pressure brought to bear by the Bank on Mr Gilliland was its attempts to keep the debt on his account within reasonable bounds. The Bank was not concerned whether Mr Gilliland obtained additional finance elsewhere to keep his account with the Bank within the approved limit of $30,000 or sold his business, both of which options had been pursued by him.

The relevant Agreement to Purchase Business shows, Mr Gilliland sold his business to Gannon Nominees Pty Ltd for a gross purchase price of $990,400-00 payable by the instalments set out in Schedule A of the Agreement, a copy of which Schedule is attached. Out of the deposit paid at settlement the debt to the Bank was repaid. So far as the Bank is aware, the balance of the purchase price remains owing to Mr Gilliland as set out in Schedule A of the Agreement.

In conclusion, Mr Gilliland was not forced to sell his business by the Bank. What the Bank did do was to approve a limit of $30,000-00, allow a temporary excess to $100,000-00 against the expectation of a guarantee from the Small Business Development Corporation which did not eventuate. In the interests of allowing Mr Gilliland to find other ways to get his business in order, the Bank then allowed the debt to increase to meet wages and the purchase of essential goods and to further increase to more than twice the amount that Mr Gilliland originally requested only 8 months earlier. This finance was extended to a business which had never been contemplated as an ongoing bankable risk for such an amount, simply to give Mr Gilliland the best chance to solve his problems. I am satisfied, and I trust this information will enable you to agree, that the Bank provided a generous measure of support to Mr Gilliland and there is no basis for his assertions against it.
Yours sincerely
D. N. SANDERS
