Dear Senator McLean
RE: ALLEGATIONS AGAINST COMMONWEALTH BANK OF AUSTRALIA BY MR A. T. RIGG

The investigation I have had carried out into allegations made by Mr Rigg, contained in papers tabled by you in the Senate on 15 December 1988, has been completed. That investigation has satisfied me that although the Bank made one transactional mistake, the mistake has been rectified and there has been no impropriety or precipitate action on the part of the Bank or its staff.

The assertions by Mr Rigg in the first three sentences of the first paragraph of his Brief to you and the content of paragraphs numbered 2 and 3 in that Brief are entirely correct. The remainder of the assertions, at best, are only partly correct.

Mr Rigg has omitted to mention a material part of the relationship between him, his wife and their company, Tony Rigg Welding and Manufacturing Pty Limited (the company) and the Bank. More importantly, he has mis-stated the basis on which the Bank appointed a receiver of the rents of the property mortgaged to the Bank. That appointment was made because Mr and Mrs Rigg, as mortgagors of the relevant property, failed to pay money they owe to the Bank, not because the company failed to pay money it owes to the Bank.
So that you may understand the relationships between Mr and Mrs Rigg, the company and the Bank, the relevant aspects of those relationships need to be set out.

At all times since the incorporation of the company, Mr and Mrs Rigg have been the only directors and the only shareholders of the company. On 5 June 1985 the Bank approved a Bill Facility to Mr and Mrs Rigg for a gross amount of $485,000-00. That sum included $303,500-00 to construct factory industrial units on property owned by Mr and Mrs Rigg at Lot 6 Princes Highway, South Nowra. Security for that facility was, and remains, a mortgage over a house property owned by Mr and Mrs Rigg and over their factory property in South Nowra.

At the same time as the Bank provided the Bill Facility of $485,000-00 to Mr and Mrs Rigg, it approved an overdraft facility of $40,000-00 to the company. The security to the Bank for the overdraft facility is the mortgage over the house and factory properties owned by Mr and Mrs Rigg. The company has not guaranteed or otherwise furnished any security to the Bank for moneys owing by Mr and Mrs Rigg to the Bank. In other words, Mr and Mrs Rigg are liable to the Bank for all moneys owing by them and by their company to the Bank, but the company is liable only for those moneys which it owes to the Bank as principal debtor.

By February 1986, it became apparent that construction of the factory industrial units could not be completed for Mr Rigg's original estimate of $303,500-00 and that overruns in that construction would be 66% above his original estimates. Mr Rigg attributed that overrun to increased labour costs, to the cost of earthworks for drainage not originally provided for, to the cost of brickwork and to wet weather problems which caused a delay of three months between September 1985 and February 1986.

To assist Mr and Mrs Rigg, the Bank at their request, increased its Bill Facility to them by $265,000-00. The total of facilities approved by the Bank for Mr and Mrs Rigg and their company, which was accepted by Mr and Mrs Rigg on 7 April 1986, was increased to $792,000-00, being $40,000-00 by way of overdraft to the company and the balance to Mr and Mrs Rigg personally. The approval of these facilities was subject to a number of conditions which included clearance of the then existing Bill Facility of $485,000-00 by April 1987 from sale by Mr and Mrs Rigg of another factory site at Pitt Street, Nowra. No reduction in those facilities has been made.

The nature of a Bill Facility is such that Bills of Exchange are drawn by the customer, in this case Mr and Mrs Rigg, to mature on a stipulated date, generally not exceeding 90 days to maturity. Bills drawn by Mr and Mrs Rigg were for periods ranging from 15 days to 90 days, with most of them being for periods of either about 35 days or about 65 days. On or before the day of each drawdown of the Bill Facility and on or before the day each Bill matures, the drawer is required to provide the Bank with a Bill or a replacement Bill as the case may be. When a Bill of Exchange matures and a new Bill of Exchange is provided by the customer to the Bank, the Bill Facility is said to be ``rolled over'', i.e. the matured Bill is replaced by a Bill, usually for the same amount, with a maturity date for a period up to a further 90 days.

On every occasion, from and including August 1985 to and including November 1987, when a Bill was about to be drawn down or was due to mature and be rolled over, Mr and Mrs Rigg were written to and requested to attend at the Nowra branch of the Bank to sign a fresh or replacement Bill of Exchange. On every occasion on which a Bill was drawn down or rolled over on maturity, Mr and Mrs Rigg were written to and informed in detail of the amount of the Bill, its maturity date, its duration, the amount of fees and the net amount credited or debited and specifying the account to which the creditor debit had been made.

With the exception of the first draw down on 14 August 1985, on all draw downs and rollovers of Bills, which happened on 34 separate occasions, all proceeds of the Bills and the amount of fees on rollovers of the Bills were credited or debited respectively to the account of the company and written notice was given to Mr and Mrs Rigg.

On the one occasion, in March 1987, when the Bank requested Mr and Mrs Rigg, in writing, to provide it with a ``cheque from the account normally used to cover fees and discounts'' for the then next rollover of a Bill, Mrs Rigg provided the Bank with a cheque drawn on the account of the company, i.e. the account of which the Bank had consistently credited proceeds of Bills and debited fees on rollovers of Bills with the full knowledge and concurrence of Mr and Mrs Rigg.

Mr and Mrs Rigg have now asserted that the Bank had no authority to credit the proceeds of Bills which were drawn by them to the account of their company and they further assert they have no liability to the Bank as drawers of the last Bill for $750,000.00 which matured on 22 December 1987 and remains unpaid. Mr and Mrs Rigg, presumably in their capacity as directors of the company, now also assert, that their company is not liable to the Bank for any part of the fees on rollovers of the Bills because the Bank had no authority to debit those fees to the account of the company. The Bank is quite prepared to have the issue of the liability of Mr and Mrs Rigg determined by the Supreme Court in the proceedings which have been commenced for that purpose.

The Bank did make a mistake in that it debited to the account of the company, the amount of the Bill drawn by Mr and Mrs Rigg, which matured on 22 December 1987. That mistake has been rectified without detriment to the position of Mr and Mrs Rigg or their company. In this regard, the demand made on Mr and Mrs Rigg by letter dated 15 March 1988 for payment of $1,032,398.67 was for the right amount. It is the default in complying with that demand on which the Bank relied to appoint a receiver of the rents of the property owned by Mr and Mrs Rigg.

In this matter, as in other matters you tabled in the Senate, the Bank is concerned that it needs to have had resort, even by merely appointing a receiver of rents, to its securities when its customers are unable to meet their liabilities.

There has been no impropriety or undue haste in the Bank's resort to its securities. The debt to the Bank is now more than twice what it was initially intended to be. The customers incurred expenses in constructing their factories which they did not foresee. The Bank assisted them by increasing the level of accommodation to them and by extending the expected term of the accommodation by over two years. That measure of support by the Bank for its customers when they encounter difficulties is totally inconsistent with the accusations which have been made against the Bank.

It should also be noted that the Bank has made no move to take possession of or to sell either of the properties which are mortgaged to it. Two years after Mr and Mrs Rigg agreed to sell property to reduce the level of their indebtedness to the Bank and more than 12 months after default by them, the Bank is still giving them an opportunity to sell their properties, or to otherwise service their liabilities to the Bank, rather than the Bank take action to sell those properties as mortgagee.
Yours sincerely
D. N. SANDERS

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The letters in question are the results of the Commonwealth Bank's own internal investigations of the allegations made against the bank by four clients of the bank. I will not name the particular unhappy individuals concerned. I think they have brought no credit on their own heads in the long run by embarking upon this venture. They have done themselves no good by putting themselves in the hands of a political novice such as Senator McLean. The plain fact of the matter is that any objective reading of the documents concerned will show the kind of people with whom Senator McLean has been dealing. It will show the degree of substance in the complaints that those people have been bringing forward. Material of this kind, having been brought to Senator McLean's attention, is exactly the kind of material that he could have received if he had inquired of the Commonwealth Bank in the first place. Perhaps it is the kind of sobering dash of facts, added to all the earlier wild fantasies to which he has been succumbing, which has given him some pause for thought, when he wakes up in the middle of the night, as to whether this matter upon which he has embarked was quite as wise politically, even as he first thought it to be.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McLean, partly no doubt with those self-doubts in mind, has sought in the motion now before us to extend the scope of this inquiry into a much wider area of the whole conduct of the banking system. He has picked up the usual rabble-rousing cries in this regard about the fact that some of the banks have sought to impose special charges upon small depositors whose accounts, from a business point of view, are simply not worth keeping. Those accounts cost much more to keep than they bring by way of return to the banks. Senator McLean would like to see the banking system run as a kind of social service, like everything else in the country according to the Australian Democrats. But unfortunately that is not the way a business can operate. Banks have to make profits, like other businesses.

It is of no material benefit to the conduct of economic debate in this country and in the Senate to have senators such as Senator McLean giving voice to the kind of rabble- rousing garbage of which some of his newly acquired friends in the Australian League of Rights have been masters for decades. Senator McLean told us this morning of a substantial public meeting that he attended in Adelaide recently which he found out, or so he says by way of a response to an interjection from myself earlier this morning, to have been convened by the National Secretary of the League of Rights. He wonders how all of a sudden he has been taken up by all these people who are interested and on his side. I can tell Senator McLean that anybody who wants to get out in this country and start talking the populist rubbish that he has given vent to in this place this morning on this particular area of his remarks is going to get a lot of friends. They will all come out of the woodwork and they will all be as ratbag in these matters and their opinions as he is, I regret to say. The next thing we will be talking about is the Jewish conspiracy or some other piece of equally--

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not talking about the Jewish conspiracy.

—I acknowledge that Senator McLean did not refer to it. I am simply saying that the path he has been so unwise as to launch himself upon will lead him into that before he is through, because these are the people with whom he is now finding himself in association. These are the people who are out to create a feeling in this country that we are in the hands of a great financial conspiracy and that anybody in this country who is down on his luck, who has made a mistake, made a mistake of business judgment or made a bad borrowing deal, has not got himself to blame; there must be somebody out there who is responsible. It is the banks; and if it is not the banks, it is the Jews, or it is somebody, but it is not he.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to go on down that road because, as I said, Senator McLean has not got to that point-at least, not yet. But if he cannot see that, he ought to take a deep breath and think again, because that is where he is going in the company he is now keeping on the matter.

As Senator McLean said, we began with two extremely serious allegations. We had allegations of corrupt practices widespread throughout the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. Secondly, we had the allegation that this alleged fact was well known to the Australian Federal Police, who had collaborated in the same corruption and who were doing their best to cover it up, notwithstanding the crusade on the matter which Senator McLean was now launching. Senator McLean complained, with some justice, that when he first sought to raise the matter with the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, last December, his letter was not acknowledged. I think he has a legitimate ground for complaint in that regard. He complained further that when he sought an oral briefing from the Minister's officers and from the Federal Police, that oral briefing was denied. Whether that is a legitimate complaint I do not know, because I expect that the Minister and his advisers by that time had had some opportunity to sum up the quality of the kind of so-called evidence that Senator McLean was producing. I suppose they had made the kind of judgment that, if I had been in their shoes, I might well have made myself-namely, `This bloke has got hold of some ratbag material from the usual kind of people whom we always see and why should we waste our time further by giving him a briefing on this subject?' That may have been too high-handed an attitude on the part of the Minister's advisers but I understand their coming to that view. Nevertheless, I am prepared to give Senator McLean the benefit of the doubt on that and to say that perhaps he was treated hardly in that regard. However, that is about the point at which my sympathy for the senator stops, because, undeterred-and undeterred also by the fact that he had not made the slightest effort to check his facts or even to obtain any commentary upon those alleged facts from the people against whom the allegations were being made-he plunged on regardless by putting down affidavits in this place and repeated the offence again when the Senate resumed earlier in the current autumn session.

As a matter of fact, some of these allegations were brought to the attention of the National Farmers Federation. The National Farmers Federation-independent of the banks; it had nothing to do with the banks-employed consultants to advise it on these matters. I am advised that the view which those consultants arrived at was that, far from having been too hard on the borrowers concerned by foreclosing too early, if anything the charge to which the banks would be liable was that they had not foreclosed early enough. As a consequence, the unfortunate individuals concerned have got deeper into debt than they would otherwise have been allowed to go. That was a view arrived at, as I say, not by the banks but, I am advised, by the National Farmers Federation.

I have directed my remarks at what I call these wild allegations by Senator McLean which go back to last December. More recently, Senator McLean has taken up the cause, which is a much more substantial and more respectable cause, of a number of borrowers in this country-not merely rural borrowers, but others-who, in 1985 and thereafter, either sought to or were induced to enter into foreign currency denominated borrowings from the banks. They borrowed in Swiss francs at what looked like an attractive interest rate at the time. Of course, subsequently, when the Australian dollar fell out of bed under the policies of this Government, those people were left with very much increased debts.

There has been, as always in these matters, a whole set of individual circumstances. Each case is different. Some of the people concerned undoubtedly made very bad judgments, were greedy, thought there was a free lunch to be had and, after all, why should they not have one. Having found that the lunch was not free, afterwards they complained that they had been badly advised. That is one category of such borrowers.

There was, however, another category of such borrowers: people who were very badly advised by some of the bank managers concerned. To say that they were badly advised is not to say that the bank managers concerned were corrupt, that they were guilty of peculation, fraud or any of the other wild charges that Senator McLean has been throwing around. Those people in that latter category probably have-indeed, many of them have been found by the courts to have-an action in law for a failing of duty of care on the part of bank managers and others who advised to that effect. There have been a number of cases of that kind, some of which have been settled out of court and some of which have resulted in court decisions, some in favour of the banks and some against the banks. That is the proper place for those matters to be settled and they are in the course of being settled and determined in that category. Certainly, the last place where one would hope to settle such matters would be in a Senate committee of inquiry. It would be a total travesty of our whole system to take such matters out of the hands of the courts and hand them over to the television cameras, amply guided by Senator McLean who no doubt wants to be re-elected and wants a bit of help in doing so. I say in passing that he will need all the help he can get.

I conclude by saying that I make an exception for that latter category of borrowings which is a specific area of banking transactions which has given rise to some quite legitimate concern in recent years. But those matters are already being handled, as they have to be, through processes of either direct negotiations between the borrowers and the banks concerned or, if those negotiations cannot be fruitfully concluded, in civil actions in the courts, that being the only place where they can be legitimately resolved. I regard this motion by Senator McLean as disgraceful, both in its origins and in its further expansion and widening. We shall certainly not support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Quite obviously, I would like to reply to a number of points made by each of the last three speakers. I will start with the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh. His opening remarks were fairly typical of his approach to debate in this chamber. He maligned individuals on the Australian Democrats bench. He began one of his usual, predictable assaults on us and then moved on to some of the more substantive matters.

SPEECH.PARA: The first substantive point that he made was that a lot of these allegations are unsubstantiated. That is not true. I do not believe that Senator Walsh is in a position to make that observation. Senator Messner and Senator Stone were also not in a position to say that the allegations that I made in this chamber were unsubstantiated. It has been my experience, having had hundreds of hours of discussions with these people, that some of them are extremely thorough. One of the problems that I had was to try to avoid being drawn into the mass of substantiating documentation which many of these people have accumulated, very diligently filed and marshalled in support of their arguments, often in quite prolonged and protracted court cases. To say that they were unsubstantiated is just pure speculation on the part of the Minister, Senator Messner and Senator Stone. It is a point to be made but it is an invalid one. It is of no consequence. It was said that I made no attempt to check these allegations. Once again, they do not know whether I made any attempt to check on them--

TALK.START.PARA: —You said this morning you didn't.

—Senator Stone does not know whether I looked into those documents. He does not know how many hours of discussion I had with those people. He does not have a clue as to what degree I checked the evidence that was brought to me-often in vast volumes by the people who made these allegations. Once again, it is a point to be made but it has no substance.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the point that honourable senators were really trying to make was that there was no attempt by me to check the records of the banks; to go to the other side of the story. I will come to that point in a moment because there has not been any attempt on their part to go to the other side of the story. There has been no such attempt on the Minister's part or on the police's part. It happens to be a reality of life that if a person who takes a position has very limited resources and time, he probably will not satisfy a whim, an emotional requirement or a debating point about the other side of the argument.

The Minister pretended to know something about my background by saying that I did not have any background in business. He does not happen to know that I have been a small businessman and that I believe that this matter is substantially about the plight of small business people in this country and their plight at the hands of the banks and their financiers. I have participated in small business probably virtually non-stop for the last 20 years. The fact that the Minister does not know that is his problem.

He made the point that there are no grounds for criminal action. That is a point that the Australian Federal Police (AFP) have made-that there are no grounds for criminal action as opposed to civil action in many of these cases. I suggest that the Minister, Senator Messner and Senator Stone are probably being a little premature in making that judgment. There may well yet prove to be grounds for criminal action in relation to some of these cases. I can tell honourable senators that while the AFP and the banks say that they have thoroughly investigated these matters since I raised them, they have not done so. On 2 March I rang all of the six people affected and whose affidavits I have tabled and asked them whether their banks had subsequently come to them and carried out further investigations, or whether the AFP had, during that period, come to them-the accusers; the people who had made the allegations-and carried out further investigations. The answer was no. In the last 36 hours my staff have rung or attempted to contact all 27 of the people about whom I have now tabled affidavits and asked them, `Since the affidavits were tabled, have the Federal Police or the bank carried out this so-called thorough investigation that they or certainly Mr Cullen and Mr Sanders, claim has been carried out, to prove that there is no substance in these allegations?'. As of last night 16 of the 27 had said no. So these judgments that were made here by the Minister and the other speakers this morning, that there is no substance in these allegations, may well be a little premature. This is fairly early on in the process. It is early times yet.

I ask the Minister, Senator Messner and Senator Stone whether they have actually read the affidavits that I tabled in the Senate, because they are basing their rejection of the assertions in those affidavits on arguments which presuppose that they have read them. Almost every one of those affidavits I have tabled have appendages, but not substantiating documents. Those substantiating documents are with me, and none of those people who participated in the debate this morning have come to me and said, `Can I look into these substantiating documents?'. They have not been thorough in their investigation, but they reserve the right to stand up here and claim that I have not been thorough in my investigation. I have just said that the police and the banks have not gone back to the documents. Yet these senators are basing their rejection of these arguments this morning on the fact that somehow or other they are holier than thou because of their thoroughness. I know for a fact that yesterday afternoon Senator Messner contacted my office and asked for a brief summary. I said that there was not one-a summary about the length of a page was asked for, so that presumably he could prepare himself adequately to deflect these arguments in this chamber today.
This has been a good debate but it has been fairly lacking in substance. These debaters are clever. Of course they are experienced senators-experienced in the process of debating.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are an amateur, are you?
—No. I reserve the right to say that I have had considerable experience too. This is not the only place where we gain experience in debating, reasoning or the aspects of life, for heaven's sake.

SPEECH.PARA: I move on to Senator Messner's arguments. Senator Messner developed the theme that committees are not adequate to deal with these sorts of things as they are not courts of law. It was never intended that the committee be a court of law. A court of law addresses itself to the details of a specific case, one on one. It is intended that the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs would address generalised principles and observations about the state of banking in Australia today. To argue that I propose that the Committee function as a court of law is simply either a misunderstanding of what is being proposed or a lack of perception of what the Committee is about.

Today Senator Messner is rejecting the credibility of committees to pursue these things, yet I anticipate that tomorrow he will be calling upon the Australian Democrats to support his Party in referring to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade a matter involving corruption, the misappropriation of hundreds of millions of dollars and national security. I refer to the Opposition's request for us to support it on the referral of the matter of the National Safety Council of Australia, Victorian Division. So he stands up here today and attempts to negate the credibility of committees, and tomorrow he is going to want one. What is more, he is going to want our support in getting it.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we don't. We want the Government to appoint a royal commission.

—Okay, that is the honourable senator's point. I am coming to royal commissions. Senator Messner frankly was lost. He groped around in the air and tried to find something to reject, and he came up with the cruelty line-he suggested that somehow or other I was engaged in a cruel hoax because these people had approached me and alleged that their banks had exploited their circumstances. Many of them are financially, emotionally, domestically and maritally ruined, and they came to me. I will tell honourable senators where they had been beforehand. They had been to both of the major parties with these sorts of issues. The first day that these issues arrived on my desk, the people who brought them to me had already been to coalition party senators. They asked me to bring them to the Senate and to do certain things with them, yet Senator Messner grasps at this argument that somehow or other I am engaged in some sort of cruel hoax to take advantage of the circumstances of these people.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to Senator Stone's arguments. Senator Stone, by his own admission, perhaps has a predisposition towards the Commonwealth Bank of Australia by virtue of having proudly been a board member for 5 1/2 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —At no time did I mention that word. I said that unlike you I know something about the institution.
—I will accept that the honourable senator knows something about it. Apparently he does not know the things that I have brought to the Senate, so he is partially informed. I will accept that.
—It is better than being wholly uninformed.

—No, the honourable senator is grasping at straws. He made a big issue of my claims about the Federal Police. My claims about it were really fairly constrained. I said that people had come to me accusing the Federal Police of a cover-up and of having failed in their duty. What does the honourable senator expect me to do with these serious allegations? I have been elected to this place to do something responsible about these things.
—Treat them seriously.
—I have treated them very seriously. Does he expect me to ignore them? Of course he does not.
—Opposition senators ignored them.

—Senators in his Party ignored the jolly thing. At least I have, in six months of concerted effort, spent hundreds of hours and made thousands of phone calls to talk to the people. I have sat and cried with some of them. What does he expect me to do, for heaven's sake?
—Not cry on television, I hope. Not yet.

—You have said that you have greater expectations of me in this matter. I have greater expectations of you also. I think your attitude towards the whole thing is very flippant and irresponsible. You argued in favour of a royal commission. You stated that the last royal commission into banking was in the 1930s. In response to my interjection, when I said we were overdue for another one, you then said how much you believed it would be appropriate to have a royal commission. If you want this inquiry to be a royal commission, that is fine.
—How many millions of dollars will that cost?
—I am not proposing a royal commission, Minister.
—Nor did I.
—You did not, okay.
—Senator McLean, would you be gracious enough to direct your remarks through and to the Chair?

—I am sorry. I am confused as to just what Senator Stone was proposing. He was singing the praises of royal commissions. I would have thought that, if a royal commission were appropriate, the Senate Standing Committee might have arrived at that conclusion. It may well have passed that recommendation back to the Parliament, and a royal commission may or may not have eventuated. But at least we have established in this debate that the last thorough investigation into banking in this country was in the 1930s, and that is worth establishing.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stone then talked about my grasping for exposure on television-pursuing the media. This is somebody who has a weekly column in newspapers-syndicated columns around the nation. I do not know whether he is paid for these services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course I am.
—Good luck to him. I am not denigrating him for that, but talk about a high media profile!
—He started every argument and never finished one.

—That may be so. But for Senator Stone to argue that I am on a media bash is incredible. Then we got to the very emotive theme of smearing. He said that I have smeared people. He said that I have smeared Mr Don Sanders, the Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank, and others. I do not know what he means by `smeared'. I believe I have made quite objective, real, honest observations about what they have said and how they have reacted to this situation. The word `smear' is emotive. Its use was obviously designed to have debating impact, but it is in no way related to the way in which I have interacted with these people. Yesterday afternoon, for about an hour and a half in my office I had very intense discussions with three senior members of the banking establishment. It was an honest, frank, and worthwhile discussion. They will be mentioning my name today in the media and I will be mentioning theirs. Senator Stone knows as well as I do that that is the price of public office. I am not only talking about parliamentary office; I am talking about office in the most powerful institutions of this land. Let us not pretend that this Parliament is the most powerful institution in the land. It pales into insignificance alongside the banks. If we had not mentioned some names, the people who are listening to this debate today would not know who were in control of this extraordinary dimension of their lives. I do not apologise for having mentioned a few names, or for having reported to the Senate how they have reacted to serious allegations, because I have not misrepresented their reactions. I have not smeared them.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stone went on about me not having checked my facts. I have already suggested that I have been considerably more thorough in the checking of the facts that have come to me than the banks have been. Senator Stone refers to the letters that he has from Mr Sanders. I have the letters.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are letters to you.

—I know they are letters to me. Does the Senate know why I have not responded to them? It is because they are a restatement of the bank's position. They are a statement in black and white of what I would have got had I gone there and spent time talking to these people. They are totally predictable statements. They are based on their file in their bottom drawer. They say they have reinvestigated the matter, but they have not gone to their accusers. They have not gone to the Australian Federal Police. They have gone back to the drawer from which their case came in the first place. They have pulled it out, flicked through the file, and said, `Things have not changed since we reacted in that totally predictable way, in the banker's way'. They have typed it out and sent it to me.
—You might at least have acknowledged it.

—Yes, I could have acknowledged it. I chose not to become involved in lengthy, meaningless and valueless written debate between the banks and me. That was an objective judgment on my part. Senator Stone says that I have not checked the facts. I have been as thorough as the police have been in checking the facts. I have been interviewed by the Australian Federal Police on this matter. They came to my office in Gosford. We talked about it. That was the day before the Minister said in his press release that there was no substance in my allegations. The police said to me that they had investigated one case-the Taylor case. That is one case out of six. They said they had found no grounds for criminal action, but they acknowledged the fact that it was before the Supreme Court of New South Wales on civil grounds. I do not know whether those Australian Federal Police officers were uninformed but they told me the day before the Minister said that there was no substance in these things that they had partially investigated only one of the six cases. Since then I have tabled details of another 27 cases. Yesterday 16 of those people-and I have not been able to contact the rest-told me that the Federal Police had not been near them. So it would appear that there is some rather inadequate fact checking not only, perhaps, on my part, but also on Senator Stone's part, on the police's part, on the Minister's part and on the bank's part. Mr Sanders has responded to Senator Stone in relation to three of the 17 Commonwealth Bank cases which I have tabled. He has not responded in relation to others. Perhaps he will some time in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stone then went on with a most extraordinary outburst on how I might, if I am not careful, some time down the line become a conspiracy theorist. That was just speculative rubbish. I have stood in public places, including the public meeting in Adelaide last Wednesday, and told people that I do not put any value on these conspiracy theories. I think when there are three politicians in one room there is a conspiracy. That has been happening since the beginning of time. If getting together and planning to achieve power and make money is conspiracy, it is all around us. I think Senator Stone is the mythologist on conspiracy, not me. To spend five minutes haranguing me about the possibility that if I am not careful I will be drawn into some zionist or some fabian theory of conspiracy is, to use the honourable senator's expression, unworthy of him. Then Senator Stone got onto the withholding tax issue and the foreign currency borrowing issue. He admitted that perhaps--

TALK.START.PARA: —I never mentioned withholding tax.

—I am sorry, foreign currency borrowings scam. He talked about some of the difficulties experienced by an estimated 1,500 people who were sent bankrupt as a result of their experience in foreign currency borrowing. Many of those victims have formed themselves into the Foreign Currency Borrowers Association, to which I spoke as a keynote speaker in Sydney last Saturday. I think I am well informed about the experiences of those people who borrowed overseas currency on the recommendation of their banks. In fact, I drew attention to an anomaly in some taxing aspects of those borrowings just last week.

SPEECH.PARA: I have deliberately taken time to make these very important points to the Senate. I have deliberately taken weeks to report to the Senate on the serious allegations of corrupt practices in banking and on the failure of the Federal Police adequately to pursue these allegations. I do not apologise to the Senate for having brought them here. I believe that is what I was elected to do; yet I am being accused by these respondents today of somehow or other being irresponsible, of lacking thoroughness and of other things which have been thrown at me. I believe I am honour bound to do what I have done since October in relation to this issue. I make no apologies for that. I believe the tabling of the affidavits was appropriate. I will be tabling more tomorrow and more next week. I will be building up the bank of information available to honourable senators who care enough to look at it. I do not believe that any one of the three who have spoken on this matter today have seriously done that. I will be tabling more affidavits and I will be making another attempt to have the matter referred to a Senate standing committee. I have confidence in Senate standing committees, even if Senator Messner does not. I do not happen to believe that they have to act as courts of law, as he has attempted to convince us they do. I happen to believe that the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, which is investigating the use of drugs in sport, is rendering a service to this nation, not a disservice. I happen to believe that it is appropriate that the whole question of the National Safety Council of Australia be referred to a committee. In fact, in my own party room yesterday I argued that case, and it was supported by my colleagues. I happen to believe that the plight of Aboriginal people in this nation was quite appropriately referred to a Senate subcommittee and that the Senate handled that reference responsibly. Unlike Senator Messner, who contradicted himself in a matter of two minutes on the issue of the credibility and viability of Senate standing committees, I happen to have confidence in them.

I have responsibly brought this incredibly serious issue before the Senate. I have responsibly used my parliamentary privilege, which provides the opportunity for senators to do things in this place that they cannot do elsewhere. I do not believe that I have abused that privilege. It is extended to all of us. It takes courage to use it. I believe that I have used it responsibly. I am prepared to live with the consequences-and, obviously, I will live with the consequences-of having done so.

I am drawing to the attention of the Australian people the fact that we have a crisis of confidence in banking. This has been evidenced to me in three ways. Allegations have been brought to me of examples of deliberate asset stripping by senior officers in banks. Assertions and allegations have been made about incompetence and negligence in relation to foreign currency borrowings, which has resulted in approximately 1,500 previously successful business people being made bankrupt on the advice of their banks. They all had to be successful in order to qualify for a loan of half a million dollars on the advice of their banks. The third dimension of this matter is premature rural fore- closures. People on the land have always had special needs in relation to credit. They have always suffered as a result of certain factors, and a special bank was established to cater for their needs. That bank has shifted its focus to the normal banking sector, and those people have lived with the consequences of what we believe has been bad banking support in recent years.

Senator Stone and the National Farmers Federation are quite entitled to challenge the focus of the Mitchelmore investigation. A counter report was made into this matter. But the reality is that both were investigating a problem. The two bodies concerned reported differently on the problem but they both acknowledged that there was a problem. They said that the causes of the problem were different but they both acknowledged that there was a problem. The problem is still there, and it is folly to pretend that it is not.

I think that the Australian electorate will judge harshly both the Government and the Opposition for refusing today to refer to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs grave and serious allegations and to ask the Committee to look into a major social crisis in our nation-refusing because they do not have the moral fortitude to take on the banks.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator McLean's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 4 April.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, subclause 5 (2), lines 13 to 18, leave out subclause, insert the following subclause:
``(2) If a provision referred to in section 21A of the Christmas Island Act 1958 is in operation, this Act does not apply to anything dealt with by the provision.''.
(2) Page 3, clause 6, definition of ``Commonwealth authority'', paragraph (a) lines 1 to 3, leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:
``(a) that is incorporated by or under a law of the Commonwealth or by or under a law of a Territory, other than:
(i) an enactment as defined by section 3 of the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988;
(ii) a law of the Northern Territory; or
(iii) a law of Norfolk Island; and''.

The need for amendments (1) and (2) arises out of the passage of self-government legislation for the Australian Capital Territory. Now that the Lands Acquisition Bill will not commence operation until after the establishment, I hope, of local governing administration in the ACT, subclause 5 (2) has been amended to delete reference to sections 7a and 9a of the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910. The reference is no longer necessary because the ACT Administration will not be bound by the requirements of the Bill, given that the definition of an authority in the Bill does not include a body politic. However, amendment No. 2 amends the definition of a Commonwealth authority in clause 6 to identify that statutory authorities which are the responsibility of or established by the ACT Administration are not bound by the requirements of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would simply inform the Committee that, in spite of the fact that the Australian Democrats did vote against the self-government Bill for the ACT, a matter which seems to be a bit fuzzy in the minds of many people at the moment, we will be supporting the Government amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Clauses, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 7 to 21-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clauses 22 to 39-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a couple of remarks which relate primarily to clauses 22 and 24, which come within this group of clauses. These clauses relate to the pre-acquisition declarations which are to be made under the Lands Acquisition Act. The pre-acquisition declaration which is provided for in clause 22 provides that in a number of areas there may be some review and some appeal against Ministers' decisions. However, subclause 6 of clause 22 provides that, if the Minister includes in a declaration a statement under subsection 3-that is to say, the Minister believes that the land is suitable for use or for development of use for a particular public purpose-he may also include a statement that it is essential for the implementation of the policy referred to in the statement under subsection 3 that the interest in the land be acquired, and the declaration is, for that reason, not subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 24 provides that the Minister may indicate that there is an urgent necessity for the acquisition of land in question and that it would be contrary to the public interest for the acquisition to be delayed by the need for the making of a pre-acquisition declaration and its possible reconsideration and review.

I wish to draw attention to the comments made on this matter by the Land Acquisition Reform Committee and to seek the Minister's comments on them. The Land Acquisition Reform Committee indicates that it is disappointed that the Bill has not been further amended in a way which would prevent the Government withholding the process which sets the Act in motion for any length of time, thereby potentially disadvantaging the people whose land will eventually be acquired. The Committee draws attention to the injustice which is illustrated in the case which I referred to at some length yesterday, namely, at Badgerys Creek since the then Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support made the first public announcement on 17 February 1986 and informed landholders in letters dated 24 February 1986 and later that land there is likely to be acquired by the Commonwealth.

The Land Acquisition Reform Committee makes a point on which I invite the Minister's comments. The Committee says that although the new Bill is amended in clause 22, the declaration that land is suitable for acquisition uses the phrase `is considering' the acquisition and `appears to be suitable'. The supporting speech made by the Minister in the House of Representatives on 20 October 1988 indicates the declaration is not to be made early to enable the Minister's proposal to be tested and effectively reviewed as the Australian Law Reform Commission recommends.

Indeed, as the penultimate step to acquisition, the new process-the pre-acquisition declaration-becomes just another name for the old notice to treat. While ever this flaw is perpetuated the many excellent provisions of the new Bill which come into play after the pre-acquisition declaration has been made remain out of the reach of affected landholders, who will be unjustly victimised up to this point in the process, as they have been in the past, as has been indicated by the saga of the acquisition of land at Badgerys Creek. That concern has been expressed. I would be grateful for the Minister's comments in relation to that particular matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some material which I hope answers Senator Puplick's question. Clauses 22 and 24 provide, amongst other things, that a Minister can decide to proceed with an acquisition without following the pre-acquisition procedures that would give an owner the right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) to the decision to acquire. The Law Reform Commission, in its report, recommended that there should be two instances where pre-acquisition declaration need not be given and where there would be no right of appeal to the AAT about the decision to acquire. These were in cases of urgency or when national security requirements prevented the disclosure of details of a proposed land use.

SPEECH.PARA: The Administrative Review Council recommended that a third situation should have a constraint on appeal to the AAT, namely where the Minister is satisfied and certifies that it is essential that the particular land be acquired. Circumstances where this provision might be used would arise infrequently, but, for example, the Commonwealth may need to acquire land in a unique location for an aircraft navigation aid. The Council expressed the view that in such instances appeal to the AAT should be precluded provided the Minister makes a public declaration that the acquisition is essential. Such a declaration would indicate the Government's commitment to the acquisition. Hence review by the AAT would be redundant, given that the Government is not bound to accept a recommendation by the AAT. The Council believed that it was highly desirable that the Minister remain politically accountable for such decisions.

The essentiality provision was cited twice in the initial Bill at clause 22 (4), where a pre-acquisition declaration would be issued and an appeal to the Minister to reconsider would be available but appeal to the AAT would not be available, and, secondly, in clause 24 (1) (b), where there would be no pre-acquisition declaration and no appeal to the Minister or the AAT.

The Bill has now been amended to delete the more severe of these provisions at clause 24 (l) (b). However, the Government is of the view that clause 22 (4)-clause 22 (6) in the revised Bill-should remain unaltered because, in its present form, the need for public accountability is met. If a Minister chose to use the provision, he would not be able to do so without the details of what he was doing becoming public. A pre-acquisition declaration would be issued to anyone affected by acquisition and copies of the declaration would have to be published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette and in a newspaper circulated in the area where the land was located.

Furthermore, if an owner of land being acquired using any of the above three provisions-that is, urgency, national security or essentiality-believed that the provision was being misused, he or she would be able to appeal to the Federal Court under the provisions of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.
Clauses agreed to.
Clauses 40 and 41-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a fairly complex matter to raise in relation primarily to clause 40 which arises from some correspondence which has passed backwards and forwards between the Land Acquisition Reform Committee (LARC) and the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr West. The Committee transmitted to the Minister some advice which it had received from His Honour Mr Justice Wilcox. The reply of the Minister, which is dated 6 March 1989, is in fact part of the document from which Senator Ray just quoted in relation to the matter I raised about clauses 22 and 24 and subsequent comment from Mr Justice Wilcox which proposes that the Government consider introducing a new subclause 40 (6). I will take the Committee through that and seek the Minister's response to the recommendation made by Mr Justice Wilcox in relation to clause 40 (6). Clause 40 deals with the question of acquisition by agreement rather than contested acquisition. In a letter that Mr Justice Wilcox sent to Mr Duff, the Chairman of the Land Acquisition Reform Committee, on 14 February 1989, His Honour makes this point:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I am concerned to note the introduction into the Bill of cl. 40 (5) (d) and (6). The Law Reform Commission thought that it was most undesirable for even ``voluntary'' agreements to be entered into prior to the service of a pre-acquisition declaration. Our reasoning was that, in practice, such agreements are not truly voluntary, an announcement of ultimate acquisition having been made and people often being unable to accommodate the delay in the normal processes of acquisition. Furthermore, there is a very grave danger, particularly in the case of a big project such as an airport, of the Government acquiring by ``voluntary'' agreements a patchwork of properties so that, when a pre-acquisition declaration is ultimately served and the question of the project is up for review, the process will be embarrassed by the fact that the Government has already laid out very substantial funds. Ideally, it would have been good simply to say that there must be a pre-acquisition declaration in each case.

However, it was pointed out to the Law Reform Commission that the Commonwealth often acquires small parcels of land by truly voluntary negotiation, even a single parcel such as a house for a Commonwealth officer. It was argued, and we agreed, that it would be absurd for a pre-acquisition declaration to have to be served if the vendor actually had the property listed with an agent for sale and was extremely willing to sell. Consequently we inserted these exceptions. They have been reproduced, as paras (a), (b) and (c) of cl. 40 (4), in the Bill as it now stands.
It is not clear to me what purpose is intended to be served by the insertion of a provision for a certificate that the acquisition would be a ``standard commercial transaction''.
That phrase is to be found in clause 40 (5) (d). His Honour continues:

Obviously this is not intended to cover a case where the property is already listed for sale. Those cases are already covered. Therefore, ``standard commercial transaction'' must refer to a case in which the Commonwealth has approached an owner who has not put his or her property on the market. The Bill does not specify any criteria for determining what is a ``standard commercial transaction''. Does this merely mean that the form of contract is the usual real estate form of contract and the price is one which has been determined by negotiation? If so, the exception would open the way to the very problems which I have already mentioned. If the phrase means something different from this, that is more restricted, it would be desirable for the Bill to make this clear.
His Honour went on to recommend that the Land Acquisition Reform Committee should press for the deletion from the Bill of subclauses 40 (5) (c) and 40 (6).
In relation to representations made on that matter, Mr West, in a letter of 6 March, addressed to Mr Duff of the Land Acquisition Reform Committee, made the following point:

Regarding the standard commercial certification at cls. 40 (5) (d) and 40 (6) the Law Reform Commission (LRC) was concerned to protect the interests of persons dealing with the Commonwealth in property transactions and that is the main reason why the Commission recommended that owners should be issued a pre-acquisition declaration advising them of the Commonwealth's intentions and providing to them the right to seek an independent review of the Government's decision. The Commission was concerned that such a declaration should be served prior to acquisitions by agreement as well as by compulsory process to cover situations in which whilst the vendor agrees to the sale he might do so because he might feel coerced to agree or else have his property compulsorily acquired.
The Minister goes on:

The Government agrees with that view and the Bill provides that this would occur. However the Commission recognised that such a procedure would not be necessary where a vendor was already in the market having advertised his property for sale or lease because in such situations the vendor presumably would be well advised regarding values and would not experience coercion to sell to the Commonwealth.

The Minister goes on to explain in some detail that the Commonwealth believes that the vendor has a choice in this matter and that the legislation has, as a result, been drawn in the way in which it has. However, on further examination of the Minister's reply, in a letter dated 21 March Mr Justice Wilcox makes the following points, which I simply read into the record and on which I seek the Minister's comment:

I do appreciate the point made by the Minister regarding cl.40 (5) (d) and (6). I think that it is correct to say that there would be circumstances, not itemised in cl.40 (5) (a), (b) or (c) where property was truly available on the market irrespective of any intended acquisition on behalf of the Commonwealth. The Minister has furnished an example of one such case. I agree that the logic of the Law Reform Commission recommendations would extend to covering this situation. My apprehension, which I think that you share-
that is, that Mr Duff shares-

is that the certification procedure might enable ``the tail to wag the dog'' in the case of a substantial acquisition program. In my opinion this would be a misuse of the procedure, but it is one which may occur under some administrations. This has caused me to wonder whether it might be possible to tighten the wording, so as to avoid abuse, but, nonetheless, so as to cover the problem which concerns the Minister.

The Minister has in mind a situation where an interest in land would be available on the market irrespective of any proposal on behalf of the Commonwealth or of a Commonwealth authority to acquire that interest. The problem with the current clause is that it does not take in that element. It simply restricts consideration to the question whether the parties would be dealing with each other on equal terms; whatever this means in the context of a dealing where one party is the Commonwealth Government with compulsory acquisition powers. Perhaps the concern which I have previously expressed could be overcome if the concept which is favoured by the Minister was expressly built in to clause cl. 40 (6). This could be done by changing that sub-clause to read as follows:

``(6) If the Minister is satisfied that a particular interest in land would have been, or would have been likely to become, available in the market irrespective of any proposal on behalf of an acquiring authority to acquire that interest and that the acquisition of that interest would amount to a normal commercial transaction between parties dealing with each other on equal terms, the Minister may give a certificate stating that the acquisition of the interest by the acquiring authority would be a standard commercial transaction.''

It seems to me that that is a very reasonable proposition in terms of a potential rewording of subclause (6) of clause 40. I do not believe that to accommodate that particular suggestion would cause the Government any great problem. I would be grateful for the Minister's advice on that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I could go into a lot of detail on this particular matter, but I will come to the end first, if you like. We are aware of Mr Justice Wilcox's suggestion in this matter. On the whole, we do not believe it is necessary. We believe that it is already covered within the existing Lands Acquisition Bill. However, I would also have to say that an assurance has been given that a Bill of this sort of complexity that has been hanging around for so long will need to be reviewed as it starts to operate and probably within two years. We know that some amendments are going to be necessary. This is a matter which we would seek to monitor to see whether it is covered adequately under the current Bill. If it is not, then the Bill will need to be amended. We believe it is. Until one actually sucks and sees it is very hard to tell whether it will be covered or not. On this occasion though, on balance, we definitely think it is covered enough in the Bill. But we do give the assurance that if problems arise out of it in the general review of the Bill we will amend accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
