SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that Senator Reynolds has been involved in a car accident and will be absent from the chamber for Question Time for the remainder of this week.
—Is she okay?

—Yes, although I understand she has sustained some back injury which will require her to be prone for some days. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Reynolds in her capacity as Minister for Local Government or Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs should be directed to Senator Ray. Those which would be directed to her in her capacity as Minister assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women should be directed to me.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice. I remind the Minister that on 8 March I asked him whether, in view of the publication in the West Australian newspaper of purported extracts from the National Companies and Securities Commission report into the Rothwells Ltd collapse, the Government would agree to table a suitably edited version of the report in the Senate. I interpolate there that the need for editing is simply because one would not wish to prejudice prosecutions. The Minister will recall saying that he would consider the request and that it could be forwarded to the Chairman of the Ministerial Council of Attorneys-General, which received the report, the Council having agreed the report should be tabled in the Western Australian Parliament. Is the Minister aware that despite the resumption of the State Parliament in Western Australia the report, or a version of it which would not affect any possible prosecutions, has still not seen the light of day in Perth? Is he aware of speculation in today's Australian newspaper that, despite its apparent support for the release of the report, the Dowding Government is working behind the scenes to prevent its tabling because of the likely embarrassment it and its predecessor government will face? What has the Minister done since I raised this matter with him? In view of the tardiness of the Dowding Government and justified doubt about its motives, will the Commonwealth as a matter of urgency agree to table the report in the Senate or will the Commonwealth continue to collaborate in a cover-up?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I utterly refute any suggestion that the Commonwealth is engaged in collaborating with the Western Australian Government in any attempt to cover up the report of the investigation into Rothwells. The interim report that has been prepared for the Ministerial Council was considered by the Ministerial Council on 2 March. I recall that Senator Chaney's question followed that. The Western Australian Government has directed the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) to arrange for a special investigation to be conducted into the Rothwells affairs. It will be recalled that a prominent Perth QC, Mr Malcolm McCusker, was appointed to carry out that special investigation. The Ministerial Council agreed to the NCSC's interim report being released in the Western Australian Parliament provided that such publication would not prejudice the interests of the administration of justice.

ANSWER.PARA: An independent counsel's opinion, that of, I think, Mr Walker, QC, from the Melbourne Bar, was sought on that particular matter. That opinion has been obtained on whether the report would prejudice any future prosecutions. That opinion has been quite properly considered by the Ministerial Council. As senators will know, the Ministerial Council is, as I have mentioned many times before, composed of Attorneys-General not only from the Federal Government but from every other jurisdiction around Australia. It is at that level that the question of the release of the report will be taken. Obviously, that particular decision is one for the Council. It is not one which ultimately the Western Australian Government in that sense can veto. It can have an influence on the deliberations of the Council. I certainly do not accept that any allegation or press speculation attributing certain motives and a desire to cover up or to somehow edit this report in any way other than to protect the course of the prosecutions that might be undertaken has any substance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security aware of claims that only 7 per cent of families with dependent children have benefited from the Government's families package? Will the Minister advise the Senate of the actual gains from the families package?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that Senator Harradine claimed during an urgency debate on 1 March and in a press release on the same day that `90 per cent of all families with dependent children had suffered a substantial drop in living standards under this Government'. He also claimed that only about 7 per cent of families with dependent children had benefited from the families package of this Government. These claims are fanciful. They do not reveal the true record. It is very important for the true record to be put in response to these particular claims. In fact, Senator Harradine's claim is based on one major misconception. That misconception hides the fact that almost a quarter of Australian families with dependent children have benefited under this Government. The misconception lies in Senator Harradine's seeming ignorance of the fact that the families package has provided substantial increases in payments not only to those families receiving the family allowance supplement (FAS) but also to pensioners and beneficiaries with dependent children. By not including that particular component Senator Harradine excludes over 440,000 pensioner and beneficiary families who have received the additional pension or benefit for their children at the same rate as FAS. It is also important in this context to remember the amount of that payment. For younger children it is $24 per week and for teenagers it is $31 per week.
—What proportion of non-pensioner families have benefited?

—Senator Harradine also made the point that families have not benefited under this Government. The crucial factor is that since this Government came to power payments and benefits for children have increased in real terms by 61 per cent for younger children and by 108 per cent for teenage children. Since 1987 payments for children paid to low income families have increased by $7 a week for children under 13 and by $14 a week for teenage children. Overall, therefore, these increases have benefited over 577,000 low income families, with over one million dependent children benefiting from them. As Senator Chaney might have asked, this represents 30.7 per cent of all families receiving family allowance benefits and almost a quarter of all families with dependent children. We should note another benchmark in terms of what the situation was like when we took over. When the families package was introduced the child payment for a low income family represented only 11.9 per cent of the combined married rate pension. In less than two years it has now changed. For children under 13 it is now 14.1 per cent and for children between the ages of 13 and 15 it is 17.5 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: There have been a number of initiatives that are central to this Government's achievements in this area. The most important one is this Government's commitment to low income parents to set benchmarks for the level of payments to children, particularly to teenage children. As indicated by the Prime Minister in 1987, these benchmarks are 15 per cent of the combined married rate pension for younger children and 20 per cent for teenage children. The Government has also committed itself to indexing these payments for cost of living increases. As the Minister for Social Security has said quite recently, on a number of occasions, this Government will meet its child poverty benchmarks this year. It is also important in this context to recognise other gains in the disposable incomes of families that have accrued under this Government. Importantly--

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. There is an increasing tendency on the part of Ministers to use Question Time to make statements. The Minister is clearly going on extensively beyond the need to answer the question put to him. I think he should be called to order and senators given an opportunity to ask questions. I hesitate to say that he is debating the question because he is delivering it in such a boring monotone. In reality, apart from his style, he is debating the question. He is debating what was said in this chamber by Senator Harradine in a debate three or four weeks ago. It is absurd that he should go on in this extended manner.

—Order! I have no power over how a Minister answers a question. But I remind all Ministers that in recent days there have been some very long answers to questions. I would like them to take that into account.

—Mr President, I think it is quite appropriate for me to give the Government's full record in response to some of the claims that have been made. I know that it may not suit Senator Chaney for me to do so--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister has made it quite clear in his response to your request to him that he is making a statement. He says that it is appropriate to give the full record of the Government. It is not appropriate to give the full record of the Government in a major area of policy with respect to a dorothy dix question. I ask you again to call him to order. He has made it quite clear in what he said that he is abusing Question Time.
—In response to the point of order: the Minister's answer is in order but it is a very long answer and I ask him to take that into account when he is concluding.

—Mr President, if Senator Chaney showed some degree of patience, he would be able to hold on for a minute and I would finish the answer. In fact, he has probably wasted more time of the Senate by his churlish, pathetic behaviour. What I was going to say, in response to the allegations and in answering the question, was that we should also take into account the Government's record in employment of 1.3 million jobs. We should also take into account the fact that Medicare is of great assistance to low income earners. We should also take into account the fact that Austudy payments for secondary students have also contributed greatly to children living with families, particularly low income families. Despite the frustrated efforts of Senator Chaney, the Government's record in this area is absolutely nothing like what has been presented in this place on previous occasions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I remind the Minister of what he said during a television program on 5 March in relation to Papua New Guinea (PNG). He said that the military riot was essentially a matter of industrial relations and, I quote:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . obviously got a little out of hand and obviously is a little hairy when you find it happening in a military context. But the stories that were floating around about imminent coups and so on, I think were very wide off the mark.

Does the Minister accept that there is a deteriorating law and order situation in Papua New Guinea? Is he still of the view that the Government is not threatened by that deterioration? Is the Minister satisfied that the Papua New Guinea Government and Papua New Guinea security forces are able to maintain law and order, especially on Bougainville Island, and that Australians living and working there are not physically endangered? In light of recent events, is the Government satisfied that the current levels and form of Australian economic, military and technical assistance are the best Australia can provide to support Papua New Guinea's economic and political stability?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are continuing law and order problems in Papua New Guinea, as has been obvious from recent press reports. Expatriates, including Australians, have been victims of some violent attacks but it does have to be acknowledged that the majority of victims are Papua New Guineans and there is no particular evidence of a programmed course of action against the expatriates in general or Australians in particular. The Namaliu Government recognises that law and order problems are constraining Papua New Guinea's development. They are a disincentive to foreign investors. I believe the Government is doing its best to come to grips with these difficult issues. Clearly, these issues are within that country's jurisdiction and, I believe, its capacity to resolve.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has announced several initiatives in law enforcement and the administration of justice. An amount of $12m is to be allocated over a four-year period. A cabinet committee has been set up to tackle the problem. A joint police and Papua New Guinea defence force operation against crime has been operating in the Highlands, in Lae and Madang. As far as Australian support for these endeavours is concerned, in August last year $11.9m was allocated from Australia's non-budget support aid program-that is, project aid-for a five-year project to strengthen PNG police capacity, following a PNG request for assistance of that kind.

Specifically in relation to the situation in Bougainville, it has to be acknowledged that it remains uneasy. A curfew has been imposed since 23 January following sabotage of mining equipment and government property by landowners demanding increased compensation from Bougainville Copper Ltd (BCL). Police are searching for the leader of the militant landowners, Mr Francis Ona, and explosives that were stolen from BCL. More recently, as we have all seen from press reports, there has been an outbreak of fighting between Bougainvilleans and workers from other parts of Papua New Guinea, particularly the Highlands. In addition to a police presence of 350, some 190 defence force troops have been sent to the island, although the operation of the mine has not been affected by these ethnic hostilities. We have now had an announcement by Prime Minister Namaliu of the establishment of a bipartisan truce committee which will include members of the national Government and Oppositions together with provincial premiers. Prime Minister Namaliu has said very forcefully that the Government could not condone people taking the law into their own hands and that he was determined to see those responsible being dealt with under the law.

The Australian High Commission remains in close touch with the Papua New Guinea Government on this matter. There was a little friction a few days ago in relation to a visit by a member of the High Commission staff to Bougainville as part of that process of keeping in touch with the issue and, in particular, keeping in touch with the interests of Australian expatriates there. It has become obvious that the contretemps was the product of, I believe, a quite genuine misunderstanding on the part of the people involved. Essentially, that part of the issue has been satisfactorily resolved.

Australia's main contribution to the financial side of resolving these problems is through our major contribution to the Papua New Guinea Budget. That is supplemented by specific projects from time to time of the kind that I mentioned in the law and order area. We will continue to keep in very close touch not only through our High Commission but also directly, government to government, on these issues and do the best we can to get PNG through what is obviously a rather difficult and volatile period. It is not, I repeat, as I have said publicly, a period or a course of events that ought to cause any great alarm about the future stability of that country. I think the problems are acknowledged; they are being grappled with. There is a highly competent team of people in the PNG Government. Part of the problem obviously has to do with the constitutional situation; the volatility of the Government in an environment where no confidence motions can be moved at six monthly intervals. If that problem can be resolved, which many people are now working to achieve, I think there is a fair chance that a lot of these other issues will stabilise over time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of recent arrests and detention without trial of people in Czechoslovakia, including Vaclav Havel and Peter Cibulka? Peter Cibulka has been charged with spreading information about Charter 77 and other matters. Can the Minister say what action the Government can take to protect such infringements of human rights? Will the Government make its opposition to these infringements known to the Czech Government in the strongest possible terms?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government is closely monitoring the human rights situation in Czechoslovakia and is very concerned over recent developments which are clearly inconsistent with internationally accepted standards of human rights and for that matter, the spirit of the final document of the conference on security and cooperation in Europe which was recently signed by Czechoslovakia. It is the case that hundreds of people were reportedly detained during a week of demonstrations in January this year, including the distinguished writer, Mr Vaclav Havel. Mr Havel received a nine-month gaol sentence for the charge of incitement and obstructing the work of a police officer.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government has expressed concern to the Czechoslovak authorities about the case of Mr Havel and his co-defendants, noting in particular that he was arrested for participation in a peaceful public gathering. I am not aware of the full circumstances of the case of Mr Peter Cibulka. The Australian Embassy in Warsaw, which is accredited to Czechoslovakia, will be instructed, as a result of Senator Crowley's question, to investigate his situation. The Government would, of course, clearly express its concern if Mr Cibulka's human rights have been violated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of a delegation from the Parliament of the Philippines led by Senator Alvarez. On behalf of all honourable senators I welcome the delegation to the Senate and trust that their visit to Australia will be both informative and enjoyable.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to the deteriorating situation in Namibia and the ultimatum which has just been delivered by the South African Foreign Minister to the United Nations Secretary-General that, unless South West African People's Organisation (SWAPO) forces are prevented from entering Namibia and fighting South African forces, South Africa would halt its observance of the UN supervised transition. What is the Government's attitude to this ultimatum and does it find it acceptable? Secondly, does the Minister acknowledge that the recent developments endanger the safety of the UN personnel, including members of the Australian contingent? Is the Government satisfied that the United Nations Transition Assistance Group (UNTAG) is still capable of fulfilling its objectives?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that the UNTAG operation has been very slow to be put into place and to implement its deployments. It has had some problems which can most charitably be described as initial teething problems. I spelt out yesterday at some length-I do not want to repeat anything I then said-the difficulties that have been experienced and some of the reasons for them. The Australian Government believes, however, that with proper management UNTAG is capable of fulfilling its objectives, and there are sufficient signs on the ground of the present situation being responded to effectively to make us still believe that the situation will stabilise and the transition period will be able to be managed as originally hoped.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said yesterday, it is for the Secretary-General to decide whether the situation warrants an increase in the size of the force to the upper authorised limit of 7,500 troops. We will just have to await his judgment on that matter. It may be that it will prove to be enough just to have in place the full range of fighting battalions and so on that are associated with the initial deployment of 4,600-odd, provided they get into place quickly in a way that has not yet occurred. We certainly have full confidence in the Australian management of our own 305-man engineer contingent. We are closely monitoring the situation, and every care will continue to be taken to ensure that Australian lives are not put at risk-although obviously there is an element of risk, again as I said yesterday, in any peacekeeping operation.

In relation to the South African ultimatum, if it can be so described, I can really do no more at this stage than say what I said yesterday: we are still not in possession of any detailed report from the United Nations as to the particular circumstances of what has occurred over the last few days, although to some extent those events speak for themselves. Our basic hope and expectation is that South Africa will act now with a maximum of restraint and in full cooperation with UNTAG, particularly given that there are some indications at least that SWAPO may have undertaken the movement in question without hostile intent. The evidence is ambiguous on that score; the evidence is conflicting. But to the extent that there is some such evidence, it is in nobody's interests to rush to judgment about who is to blame. The main thing is to try to get the situation back under control through rapid deployment of the remaining UNTAG forces through an effective taking command of the situation by the UNTAG commander, and by everyone, including the Opposition, exercising an appropriate degree of self-restraint.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In view of the positive approach of the Palestine Liberation Organisation under Yasser Arafat in the Middle East peace process, has the Australian Government considered raising the status of the PLO office in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I announced early last month, the Australian Government has responded to requests from the former Palestine Information Office to change the title of that office to one under the rubric of the Palestine Liberation Organisation. I have had a further communication from Mr Kazak seeking clarification as to whether or not it is the Government's position that it be described as the Palestine Liberation Organisation Information Office or simply the Palestine Liberation Organisation Office. I have responded to that by making it clear that the Government has no objection to the office being called the Palestine Liberation Organisation Office; that is to say, simply deleting the word `information', if that is what is requested.

ANSWER.PARA: The main point that I have been at pains to make clear to Mr Kazak and others interested in this question is that this in no way represents the granting of diplomatic or consular status to that particular office. It in no way implies that any of the privileges or immunities that are associated with diplomatic or consular status will be attached to the office. What it does reflect in Government policy is a recognition of the quite fundamental change that has occurred in the publicly stated position of the PLO as a result of the statements made in Geneva in December last year by Mr Arafat in which the PLO did, of course, renounce terrorism and accept Israel's right to exist within secure and recognised borders. All of these matters I put on the public record in an answer to a question, which I have just now turned up in Hansard, on 2 March. I made the point in public statements on 2 March and in my letter of a few days earlier to Mr Kazak that, while:
The Government has welcomed the positive development in the PLO's approach to the peace process as expressed by Mr Arafat in Geneva . . .
he would:
. . . appreciate that any retreat from these commitments in the future will necessarily result in a further review of the Australian Government's position.
I said:

Our willingness to make the kind of gesture embodied in our acceptance of the renaming of your office is very much contingent on both the letter and spirit of those commitments continuing to be observed.
May I also say that in further recent correspondence with Mr Kazak I underlined that point in the following terms:

I should, moreover, like to underline the points I made in the final paragraph of my earlier letter. The Government will continue to monitor closely the honouring of the commitments made by Mr Arafat in Geneva in December last year. In this regard, I am concerned about some reported statements attributed to PLO leaders in recent months which, to the extent that they imply a continued willingness to contemplate certain terrorist activity, are profoundly unhelpful in maintaining the credibility of the PLO position.

I make those points because I think it is important to appreciate that, while the Australian Government wants to be responsive, as do so many other countries around the world, to the manifestly very important change in position by the PLO-because we believe that negotiations between the PLO and Israel are the only way forward out of the impasse in the Middle East-nonetheless those words have to be accompanied by deeds on the Palestinian side. Good faith has to be maintained. It is very much a part of the process of developing a climate of confidence in which we can achieve peaceful resolution of the situation in the Middle East that there be no resiling in practice from either the letter or the spirit of those undertakings. That is the basis on which the Australian Government has been prepared to acknowledge explicitly a representative role for the PLO in this country, but it is very much with the qualifications that I have again put on the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is he aware that the decision by the Government to scrap its ill-conceived 40 per cent tariff on lightweight woollen cloth has left a number of major manufacturers licking their wounds from substantial tariff charges, some in excess of $11,000, which were incurred in the brief period in which the tariff was in operation? Does the Government have any plans to reimburse those manufacturers, given that by its action in axing the tariff the Government has admitted that it was wrong? Does the Minister agree that, as a matter of principle and in order to maintain its credibility within the garment manufacturing industry, such reimbursement would constitute a just and equitable resolution of the whole lightweight woollen cloth tariff fiasco?

—I am asked whether a number of manufacturers, who are few in number, are licking their wounds as a result of this decision. I suspect that the answer to that question probably is yes, if that is what manufacturers do.
—You should know. You are the Minister responsible.

—I am not helped by interjections from Senator Boswell on this issue. I am sure that he licks his paws every day, but whether manufacturers lick their wounds is a different matter. The answer to the question whether we have any plans to reimburse the manufacturers so concerned is no. Was it an admission that we were wrong? Tariff changes are made from time to time on various issues and, of course, they affect different people in different ways. It is not conceded in any sense that it is an admission that we were wrong. I think that just about answers the question, and that will enable the honourable senator to go back to his wound-licking manufacturer and explain what I think about the issue.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Is the Minister aware of a statement by the shadow Minister for defence, Mr Peter White, which claims that the Government may be considering the reintroduction of national service training? Are there any grounds for Mr White's speculation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —There are no grounds for Mr White's speculation that the Government is considering the reintroduction of national service training. On a number of occasions I think Mr White himself has suggested it, but the Government certainly is not considering it. The Australian Labor Party's policy suggests that all forces must be made up of volunteers. Conscription would be resorted to only in the event of an attack against Australia. At this point in time I am not aware of an attack being mounted against us.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the possibility of an Australian contribution to a force in Cambodia, again the Government would not be considering any sort of conscription for an exercise of that kind. The Government, unlike the Opposition, would never use conscription as a reflex action. We regard it as far more serious than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer: What is Australia's present level of international indebtedness? How does this compare with our international indebtedness when the present Government came to power six years ago? Would not the projected $50 a week combined pay rise and tax cuts mean a sharp rise in the spending power of Australians? Can we afford this in our current economic circumstances? What does the Minister expect will be the effect of such an increase in spending power on our balance of payments and hence on our international indebtedness?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there are about eight questions altogether. I did not get a note of all of them, but I will answer most of them. Firstly, I do not remember off the top of my head the precise figures about external debt, but there is no doubt-I am not trying to walk away from this-that there has been a very large increase over the last several years. That, of course, is the sum of the sequence of current account deficits that we have been incurring over a very long period. It is no secret that the current account deficit in this financial year clearly will be somewhat higher than the Budget forecast, and that of course is not a good thing.
—Somewhat? About double.
—However, Senator Stone, I think it ought to be noted that this year we may well come in with a current account deficit equal to 4 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP).
—You should. You have slugged everyone just about senseless.

—Senator Boswell should listen to this, too. The major cause of that is that demand has been running at almost unprecedentedly high levels in Australia-certainly in the absolute sense-and the rate of growth in demand has been extremely high because the growth rate in the Australian economy is very much higher than had been expected. So in this financial year we may well have a current account deficit somewhat more than 4 per cent of GDP. But in John Howard's last year as Treasurer we had a current account deficit of 4 per cent of GDP in the midst of the worst depression the country had seen since the early 1930s. That is the genius of John Howard-to still have a 4 per cent current account deficit when in the middle of a depression. It is very much harder to do that than it is to have a 4 per cent current account deficit when we are in the midst of a very high rate of economic growth and an investment boom.

ANSWER.PARA: Whatever the precise figures on debt may be, two refinements should be made. Firstly, the net indebtedness should be looked at, rather than the gross. Secondly, and this is a very important point, over recent years Australia has for the first time become quite a major exporter of capital.

TALK.START.PARA: —When are you going to resign, Walshie?

—I suggest that it would be much more useful if the honourable senator did. Let me tell her that, tiresome as she is not only to me but also to everybody else in the Parliament, including her own colleagues, and therefore it is tempting to escape from her boorishness by leaving the Parliament, the trouble is that that probably would enhance the chance of the ratbags opposite getting back into government. That is a pretty powerful deterrent for anybody who has any concern for the future of Australia.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. I take offence at being labelled a ratbag by a Minister who might otherwise wear that title himself. I ask that he withdraw the reference to members of the Opposition as being ratbags.
—A fair amount of give and take occurs at Question Time. Senator Walsh has finished his answer. I call Senator Hamer for a supplementary question.

—It is not really a supplementary question as I ask the Minister to answer the bits that he did not answer. Would not the projected $50 a week combined pay rise and tax cuts mean a sharp rise in the spending power of Australians? Can we afford this? What does the Minister expect would be the consequences of such an increase in spending power for our international indebtedness?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Actually, I had not quite finished. I will finish the point I was making, and that is that in recent years for the first time Australia has become a significant exporter of capital, in particular of equity capital investment. That also ought to be taken into account when one is making a final assessment of the changes in our level of international indebtedness. To the extent that we have become a significant exporter of equity capital, though still in total an importer of capital, that of course has aggravated the figures shown in the accumulated external debt.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the second part of Senator Hamer's question, I think I am already on the public record in last Monday's Age; but if I am not on the public record I certainly was on the record when I spoke to the Age's bureau chief on this matter. If it were a simple question of whether it would be better to increase disposable incomes in Australia, I think everybody would have to agree that under present circumstances it would be better not to increase disposable incomes-at least unless the increase in disposable incomes were to go into saving. However, the statement which the Treasurer will be making next Wednesday will be about a package of taxes and wages, and-Senator Stone even, I think, agrees with this-at some point it is better to settle for a smaller Budget surplus, than might otherwise have been the case, in return for a lower wages outcome. It is a matter of judgment where that point is reached.

I make two final points about that. Never in the five years that John Howard was Treasurer did he go anywhere near achieving a Budget surplus at all. He left behind him a fiscal time bomb in the form of an impending Budget deficit of nearly $10 billion, or 5 per cent of gross domestic product. The second point is that whatever the appropriate size the tax reductions may be, if the Opposition's assurances or propaganda are to be taken at face value, there would be very much larger tax cuts if the Opposition were in government-so it says-offset by expenditure cuts. But it never identifies any expenditure cuts; it keeps presenting an ever growing list of expenditure increases.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to letters being sent out by the public relations and marketing manager of the Royal Automobile Association of South Australia, suggesting that the recipients write to the local Federal members using an enclosed stamped and pre-addressed envelope to ask for more spending on roads and to complain about the use of petrol excise for purposes other than road construction? Does the Government accept the proposal of the RAA of South Australia that petrol excise should be spent only on roads? How will the Government respond to this campaign?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the letter from the South Australian RAA. Similar campaigns are being waged by comparable organisations in other parts of the country. The basic proposition is that the Federal Government ought to spend on roads all the money that it collects in fuel excise. It is not a new slogan. It has been around for at least 25 years. I remember Harold Holt replying to it when he was Treasurer. It goes back at least that far. What the South Australian RAA fails to mention is what services, what areas of government expenditure, it would like to see reduced if the present surplus of collections of fuel excise, net of Commonwealth expenditure on roads, were to be reduced or eliminated. Two or three possibilities flow from that. First, other taxes would have to be increased. I do not know which other taxes the South Australian RAA thinks should be increased; or, secondly, expenditure would have to be reduced or the Budget deficit would blow out. That is the way that John Howard dealt with these problems when he was in government, not that the Liberal Party, to its credit, ever hypothecated all taxes on fuels for Commonwealth road construction.

ANSWER.PARA: However, in regard to the campaign, on 30 March a letter was published in the Advertiser by S. Colhoun of Happy Valley. It was such a good letter that I believe I should quote three paragraphs of it. It says:
As a member of the RAA for the past 18 years, I strongly object to my membership fees being used to help finance a $6 million political campaign.
I am happy that some of my fuel taxes go towards things such as pensions, education, nursing homes, health programs, etc.
It is quite obvious that additional funds for roads would only mean more taxes-or would we really like less spent on our aged and our children.

S. Colhoun has summarised the issues very succinctly. I need not say much more about this issue except that although certain opportunistic members of the Opposition pay lip service to this campaign which is being waged by various motoring associations, never, when they were in government, did they adopt the principle, nor would they if they ever get into government in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. Again I put to you that I object to being labelled as an opportunist. As you have not accepted such a point of order in the past, I take the opportunity to speak to the point of order before you make your ruling, to advise you, Mr President, that on 16 April 1985 President McClelland ruled just that word by just that senator out of order. I ask that the same ruling be made by you now.
—Order! The honourable senator has taken a point of order on the use of the word `opportunist'. There is no point of order.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support. I refer him to a recently launched program by the Government entitled `Roads Australia-Meeting the Challenge'. In that program the Minister states:

QUESTION.PARA: Improvements will be concentrated on roads of national economic importance in urban and rural areas-roads which will contribute to Australia's economic growth through tourism and the carriage of goods to markets and ports.

Does this therefore mean that the Government has finally recognised that its failure to maintain funding for roads in Australia-a fall of 30 per cent in real terms over the last four years-has been short-sighted in that it did not take into account its effect on the nation's economy?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that we have been quite selective in the application of our road funding money. We have had a certain resistance, for example, to funding the surfacing of roads to people's properties in circumstances where there is no discernible benefit to anyone at all other than the particular person in question because of the political associations of that person. We have been very careful in terms of the criteria we have applied in that respect.
—That is below the belt.
—You were right up to your ears in that, Boswell. I'd be very quiet if I were you.

—I thank Senator Button. The circumstances of the funding of the Commonwealth's national roads program are perfectly well known. It has been very effectively articulated on innumerable occasions by the current Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support, Mr Robert Brown. There has been some cessation of one particular category of that funding as a result of the program being completed, but the funds that are now being made available are being allocated to the areas of maximum economic benefit and return. It certainly does not imply any concession that in the past there has not been a similar criterion applied. It is just that we are moving away now from the notion of national roads, the completion of the round Australia black-top highway, to a more selective application of the funds that are available. Particular emphasis is being placed, as the honourable senator should recall, on roads that are part of the transport infrastructure surrounding ports that are important for the movement of goods around the major cities, and on the improvement in the condition of the major urban arterials. These are all priorities that are centrally important in the development and maintenance of our national transport infrastructure. The priorities that have been articulated still have regard to real human needs and are not solely of an economic or an industry kind. It is for that reason that road funding has been maintained in real terms for local government right around Australia, even though in some other categories it has not been possible to maintain the funds at quite that level. I will be happy to supply Senator Bjelke-Petersen with extensive detail about the precise priorities that are currently being applied and the circumstances and the context in which those funds are now being generated. I think she will see, with the care and rationality that she notoriously brings to her consideration of these matters, that the Government's policy is well founded and does not justify the really quite untoward slights that she offered in her question.
—I direct my question to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. It relates to one of the many success stories of this Government.

—I knew that would get them going. Will the Minister advise the Senate as to whether the Government's target set for tourism visitation in the bicentennial year was reached? Will the Minister advise the Senate as to the current expected predictions for tourism growth in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government once again exceeded its target figures in terms of tourists visiting Australia during the bicentennial year. The figures for December were announced this morning. They show that there were 2.249 million visitors for 1988. This phenomenal figure represents an increase of 26 per cent on 1987. Given that the increases in 1987 and 1986 were 25 per cent in each year, this shows why Australia has the leading rate of growth in tourism in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. So I think we can take considerable credit for those phenomenal figures. John Brown must be paid the credit due to him for establishing tourism as a priority not only for this Government but for all governments to come. Tourism can never again be ignored, as it was under the Fraser Government. Tourism now employs 6 per cent of the work force and creates 20,000 jobs a year.

ANSWER.PARA: The interesting part of Senator Collins's question concerned predictions in the longer term. The Bureau of Tourism Research suggested figures a year ago that I think were accepted in the industry for a time. It suggested that the projected rate of growth until the year 2000 would be 7 per cent. However, many people in the industry are beginning to query that figure. Recently it was indicated to me by the Australian Tourist Commission that it is conducting a review of that figure because it believes it does not state the full case. I am more than confident that in the very near future the Commission will be making an announcement, on the basis of some well-founded research, which will suggest that that figure of 7 per cent should be made much higher.

I am interested in the remarks about Queensland and what it does for Tourism. The facts are that a great many tourists visit Queensland and that is certain to continue. However, more would visit Queensland if there was less destruction of that magnificent coastline that goes on under the Queensland National Party Government. More people would visit Queensland if some wetlands were left. Every time the Queensland Government finds such an area, it knocks it down. It might not be a bad idea to give this matter some consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Is it a fact that only one Medicare schedule fee now applies to cover maternal confinements, regardless of such variable factors as the number of antenatal consultations or the method of delivery? Did the present Government change the Medicare schedule in August 1987 so that only one schedule fee of $425 now covers all births? Can the Minister advise why the Government believes that the skills and time involved in a straightforward birth are the same as those for a complicated forceps delivery or a caesarean section? Is it the intention of the Government that obstetricians should be forced to change their clinical practices through a system of financial disincentives? Is the Government aware that consumers who have caesarean sections or other forms of surgical intervention in delivery have, in most cases, no choice in the matter and, therefore, can be faced with substantial unscheduled out of pocket expenses in giving birth? Does the Minister accept that this is just one more penalty on people trying to raise families under this Government's anti-family economic policies?

—I do not accept in any way, shape or form the last part of the question. One of the great social reforms of this Government was the introduction of Medicare which has enabled Australian families to save considerable amounts of money because of the high cost of medical health insurance in this country. That reform remains one of the monuments of this Government's social equity program. So in no way do I accept the last allegation. I will refer the eight other questions to the Minister for Community Services and Health of whom, through me, they were asked for a reply in due course.

—Is the Minister for Resources aware that the regional head, forestry, Eden Forestry Commission, New South Wales has publicly stated on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) on 20 March and on Channel 10 on 28 March that pulpwood has been cut from compartment 1323, Coolangubra State Forest, and trucked to the Harris-Daishowa (Aust) Pty Ltd chipmill at Eden for stockpiling? Is the Minister aware that this pulpwood extraction for export is being carried out in an area which is on the interim list of the National Estate, in apparent direct contravention of section 6c of the interim licence to export hardwood woodchips from Eden for the calendar year 1989? Is the Minister able to table correspondence notifying the Harris-Daishowa company that this extraction of pulpwood is acceptable to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy? Such correspondence would appear to be necessary to comply with the requirements of section 6c. Is the Minister aware that on Apogee Road in Tantawangalo State Forest leading to compartment No. 2453, significant amounts of timber were pushed over in apparent breach of section 5c of the licence and that no attempt has been made to salvage a large number of huge logs for utilisation? In light of these apparent breaches of licence conditions, will the Minister consider revoking the Harris-Daishowa 1989 woodchip licence or taking other action to ensure compliance with all the requirements of the interim licence for 1989?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a way I suppose I should thank Senator Dunn for this question because it enables me to make what I regard as an important distinction in this debate that has grown up over the south-east forests, and that is: what are the powers of the Commonwealth? There is a belief abroad that the powers of the Commonwealth are absolute. Of course, under the Constitution forestry is a State responsibility.
—I wish you would recognise it. You run right over the conventions.

—Before the honourable senator goes off the deep end, he had better listen. Our powers relate to export controls, to foreign affairs considerations and, in certain circumstances, to corporations. But we do not have a direct power in terms of regulating domestic forestry on the ground for the internal market in New South Wales.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked in the first part of the question whether I was aware of something that had been said by the head forester. I cannot confirm all of the very precise details that Senator Dunn put in her question because I did not see the programs on the ABC or Channel 10 on the dates set out in the question. But I understand that a leading forester employed by the Forestry Commission of New South Wales has made statements of a similar sort to those referred to by the honourable senator. I do not know on what basis he made those statements-whether in his own right or as a spokesman for the Forestry Commission.

With respect to the first part of the honourable senator's question, it is certainly true that there are logging operations going on in what is now commonly called the Coolangubra Forest but which, in forestry designations, is the Bondi Forest near the Coolangubra area in New South Wales. Those logging operations, according to the Minister for Natural Resources in the New South Wales Government, have been set in train by him through the Forestry Commission for the purposes, as he describes, of supplying saw logs to sawmills at Bombala. The Commonwealth was not consulted before this decision was taken. It is not a decision I have any power to regulate.

However, I have a power to be concerned about and regulate logging which is occurring in an area on the interim list for the National Estate-an area in respect of which I have a statutory obligation to make sure is not logged if there are feasible or prudent alternatives. I do have the power to see that any material coming out of those operations or out of the sawmill residue that is left over from sawmilling because of the logging is not exported as woodchips. I have advised Harris-Daishowa that that is not to be the case.

I know that that company has quarantined any material coming out of the area. It is put aside in the company's yard. It is not being sent to Harris-Daishowa to be stockpiled, as the honourable senator has suggested, but simply because there is no other place to put it. Whether or not it is ever milled for woodchips for export depends very much upon whether the Commonwealth and the State can reach an agreement on the outstanding conditions and terms of the Harris-Daishowa export woodchip licence. So far I have had three meetings with the New South Wales Government. A this stage I would anticipate at least another meeting before we would know the answer to that question. There will certainly not be any authorisation for that material to be milled or exported as woodchips until such time as there is an agreement. Given the need for the agreement, it may be that it never is milled and exported, particularly if there are feasible alternatives.

The honourable senator referred to section 6c of the interim licence. That is a new provision which I put in the licence for this year. It was not a provision in the licence previously. It is the first time the provision has appeared. It gives me direct power to regulate the supply of material out of National Estate areas or out of areas on the interim list of the National Estate. That is an explicit condition of the licence. In my view that condition of the licence is not being transgressed by Harris-Daishowa, and that is a view that I have formed after investigating the issue.

In the last part of her question the honourable senator referred to Apogee Road in Tantawangalo State Forest. I know of some trees that have been, I am informed, blown over in windstorms in the Tantawangalo area. I am not able to verify whether they are the exact trees the honourable senator is referring to but there are a number of them. The reason why they are not being taken for milling is simply that this is yet again another outstanding area which is dependent upon a settlement between the Commonwealth and New South Wales governments before there can be any acceptance of materials for woodchipping. Whether they are taken for woodchipping or not depends very much on whether that agreement is reached.

The last part of the honourable senator's question referred to `apparent breaches of licence conditions'. That is a very qualified and soft allegation, if I might make that observation. I do not believe that there have been breaches and I therefore do not think that the Harris-Daishowa woodchip licence should be suspended.

Let me conclude by making this remark: the logging in what is now called the Coolangubra, but by definition is the Bondi Forest, is logging being conducted under the auspices of the New South Wales Forestry Commission. I do not find it particularly comfortable that that is occurring while the Commonwealth and the State of New South Wales are trying to negotiate what, by any test, is a delicate and sensitive agreement. The fact that that is occurring makes it very difficult for us to conclude a final undertaking between the Commonwealth and the State.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FUNCTION FOR FRETILIN MOVEMENT: ATTENDANCE BY PRIME MINISTER

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Tambling asked me whether the Prime Minister had attended an Australian Labor Party function for `the rebel East Timorese Fretilin movement' in Darwin last weekend and thereby delivered a snub to Indonesia. The answer to both questions, as I said yesterday, is an unequivocal no, but I should attempt in a supplementary answer to relieve the obvious distress of Senator Tambling at what he seems to believe was some sort of shadowy gathering of insurgents in Australia's far north.

ANSWER.PARA: The situation was in fact as follows. My colleague Senator Collins and the member for the Northern Territory, Mr Snowdon, jointly hosted an informal function at the East Timor Association's Lafaek Club in Darwin on Saturday, 1 April, to coincide with the visit of the Prime Minister to that city. The function was an attempt-in fact, a very successful attempt-to give the Prime Minister an opportunity to meet a broad cross-section of the Darwin community. The list of more than 300 invitees included representatives of organisations as diverse as the Greek Orthodox community, the Indian Cultural Society, the Migrant Resource Centre, and a range of trade unions and professional associations, not to mention such sinister organisations as the Family Planning Association, Darwin pensioners, Darwin Senior Citizens Association, the Darwin Uniting Church Women's Fellowship, the Catholic Women's League and the Country Women's Association.

Not content with that list of 300 invitees, Senator Collins and Mr Snowdon went further, placing an advertisement in the Northern Territory News inviting anyone in Darwin who had so far escaped their attention to attend the gathering. In short, this function was a community-wide affair attended by people from many different groups, including, yes, the East Timor Association, the members of whom, incidentally, are overwhelmingly these days naturalised Australian citizens-the overwhelmingly diverse set of groups that make up that very rich cultural environment that Darwin is these days. To brand the occasion, as Senator Tambling did, as a Fretilin meeting was not only grossly inaccurate, and an insult to Darwin as a whole, but also typical of the kind of wild and baseless allegations we have come to expect from the senator from the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented in a question by Senator Coates of which I was not given notice and by the answer given by Senator Bolkus. I seek to correct that. It is not my usual practice to get up on personal explanations but I believe I have somewhat of a reputation in this place of being absolutely meticulous in providing information, including statistics, to the Senate. I am concerned that I was misrepresented by the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) in his answer. I was relying on figures that were provided to me by the statistics group of the Department of the Parliamentary Library. Those figures show quite clearly that only 6.7 per cent of all Australian working families benefit from the family assistance supplement. I actually said 7 per cent. The figure happens to be only 6.7 per cent. I seek leave to have incorporated into Hansard the document supplied to me by the statistics group of the Department of the Parliamentary Library.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
FAMILY ALLOWANCE RECIPIENTS: AUSTRALIA, AUGUST 1988
Number of Families Receiving FAS: 139,036

TALK.START.PARA: —There may have been a misunderstanding on the part of the Minister or anybody reading Hansard of 1 March in that I referred to all Australian families. I was speaking then in the context of a campaign that I had been waging in which I had spoken to groups in Tasmania about an advertisement that appeared on behalf of the Government in the daily press. It said, `Cash for working families'. What I said on that day and what I said previously was in that context of working families. If there was a misunderstanding on the part of the Minister, that misunderstanding should have evaporated if his Department or whoever prepared the response had referred to my press release of 3 March and had not just relied upon that of 1 March. The statement of 3 March made it perfectly clear what I was talking about. I was talking about `Australian working families'. I believe it is important not only for my reputation for being absolutely meticulous on figures and statistics but also for the record that has now been incorporated in Hansard to show that only 6.7 per cent of all Australian working families benefit from the family assistance supplement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I also claim to have been misrepresented. I will not take too long in rectifying the situation. I wish to respond to Senator Harradine. I think I said clearly that he had excluded 440,000 pensioner and beneficiary families from his calculations. Accordingly, the figure of 30 per cent that the Government refers to is more appropriate. The press statement of 1 March was very explicit in the first paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Government's family policies are a fraud, because over 90% of all families with dependent children have suffered a substantial drop . . .
Probably the best thing I should do is to take Senator Harradine aside and go through this. It is quite clear from his press statement of 1 March that he refers to all families.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the following papers-
(a) the answer of the Minister for Consumer Affairs;
(b) the personal explanation by Senator Harradine; and
(c) the subsequent statement by the Minister for Consumer Affairs.

I would like to speak briefly to the motion because the answer given by Senator Bolkus typified the abuse that we have seen of Question Time since the Parliament resumed, which has resulted in a very small number of questions being asked in the Senate over this period. Ministers have come in to this place-Senator Bolkus is but one of them-and given prepared statements. Senator Bolkus's own words during his answer made it clear that he was intending to make what he described as a statement of the Government's position on this important question in response to what was supposed to be a question without notice.

The seriousness of this matter goes beyond the matter of the number of questions asked during Question Time. The fact is that the answer, clearly a carefully prepared answer, given by Senator Bolkus was in itself substantially misleading. Senator Bolkus was trying to get away from the facts that were drawn attention to by Senator Harradine in his comments in this Parliament and in the press statement that he put out on 3 March. Senator Harradine-Senator Bolkus referred to the first paragraph of that press statement-said this:

The Government's family policies stand condemned by the figures produced in the AIFS document `Families and Tax' which shows that most families have suffered a substantial loss of disposable income since 1984.

That is an unexceptionable statement. Whatever confusion there may have been about working and non-working families, the truth is that this report put out by the Australian Institute of Family Studies shows that whilst the Government can point to some percentage of Australian families who are on very low incomes having gained in some way from this Government, even on Senator Bolkus's figures, about three-quarters of Australian families have gone backwards under the Hawke Government, even if one looks at no more than the issue of tax and family allowance and other forms of assistance which are directly available to families with dependants.

Because I believe that Senator Bolkus has tried to muddy the stream, I will again refer the Senate to what was reported by the Institute of Family Studies just a couple of months ago. The point is made-it is all set out on page 7 of the report-that, with the exception of very high income earners and those people on a low enough income to get the family income supplement, the heaviest tax increases have fallen on middle income families with children. The table set out in this document shows that the burden has fallen without any regard to social obligations. I will quote directly from page 8 of the report:

The pattern of higher increases in average tax rates for those on lower incomes is repeated for all the various family types shown in Table 1. The outstanding exception to this pattern is for families on low incomes with children. These people have been greatly assisted by the Family Allowance Supplement.

Depending on how one plays with the figures one can say that that is 7 per cent of Australian families or one can try to lump them in with pensioner and beneficiary families-in other words, those families that are totally dependent upon the state for support through the Department of Social Security-and one can say that this Government has done something to ease the burden on the bottom quarter of income receiving families in Australia. But the truth is that the vast mass of middle income earners in Australia, including people on quite modest incomes, have suffered very badly under this Government. The report says:
The most striking feature of Table 1 is the very high proportional increases in the average tax rates for all family types around AWE.
that is average weekly earnings. To continue:
This contrasts sharply with the large declines in average tax rates experienced by very high income earners during the same period.

That is the truth and that is why there is such a revulsion about this Government in suburban Australia. That is why so many people are groaning under the weight of not only the extraordinary increases in interest rates but also the average tax rates that have considerably increased under this Government. We are not talking about the wealthy of this country; we are talking about medium income earners who are trying to do no more than live an average Australian life. They are finding it increasingly difficult, if not impossible, to buy a house. They are finding it increasingly difficult, if not impossible, to buy a car. And they are finding it increasingly difficult, if not impossible, to make ends meet.

We had this Minister-Minister Bolkus; one of the less competent Ministers in this Government, I would have to admit-get up today in Question Time, not with an answer to a question that he did not expect, but with a piece of paper in front of him because a dorothy dix question had been arranged. He tried to give the impression that under this Government there has been a substantial increase in assistance to families. Under this Government 70 per cent or more of Australian families have suffered increases in taxation and a decrease in the value of whatever benefits are available to them, whether it be family allowance or dependent spouse tax rebate. Where changes have been made to family allowance, other than for people who receive such a low income that they can get the family assistance supplement, for many families this Government has removed the family allowance entirely. Senator Bolkus, no doubt--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are abusing the leave that has been granted to you.

—Had I not got leave, Mr President, I would have sought suspension of Standing Orders. We have now sat here for two weeks and seen Question Time abused with statement after statement. I am now responding to one of those matters. The Opposition is sick of this Government's performance. We are certainly sick of the sort of performance by Senator Bolkus, who is continually misrepresenting the position with respect to those portfolios that he represents in this place. The truth of the matter--

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I ask Senator Chaney to withdraw that remark that insisted that Minister Bolkus is continually misrepresenting Ministers in the other place that he represents when he makes his answers. That is a grave slur against the Minister.

—I am, in a quite specific way, drawing attention to the fact that Senator Bolkus has misrepresented the position. In his answer he made a quite inaccurate point-it must be inaccurate, to his knowledge-that under this Government assistance to families has greatly increased. If one looks at the documents tabled in this place by this Government it is quite clear that assistance to the great majority of families has significantly decreased.
—Order! There is no point of order. It is being used--
—Or course there isn't.
—Order! I will give the ruling, Senator Walters. There is no point of order. The term was being used in a debating sense.

—I will go back to the point that I was seeking to address. A substantial number of families have had their entitlements to family allowance totally removed. No doubt, Labor senators will get up and say that those families can afford it; why should they get any assistance? Those families, with incomes of around $40,000, who have lost family allowance, now have to pay exactly the same tax rates as people with the same income but who have no children to support. All the notions of horizontal equity, so carefully addressed by Bettina Cass in her reports to this Government, about people on equal incomes but with differential capacity to pay tax because they have dependants, go out the window. This Government ignores the fact that the same Institute of Family Studies that produced this report told this Government that the real disposable income of a family with an income of $40,000 or more and with dependants is in fact no more than that of a single person on average weekly earnings. There is no sense of social justice in what the Government has done. Everyone can commend the assistance given to very low income families.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor Party might occasionally acknowledge that its whole system of assistance to low income families is in fact built on an initiative of the Fraser Government, introduced in the 1982 Budget when I was Minister for Social Security under the term `family income supplement'. We do not quarrel because we introduced the proposal that assistance should be given to low income, working families. I see Senator Harradine nodding because he has had connections with the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Union. This is a classic case of a union with many members who have family responsibilities and are earning relatively low incomes. Under the old social security system, one could have the absurd situation that those families could have lower incomes, employed, than unemployed. It is a matter of rank injustice. The Fraser Government introduced the notion that there should be additional assistance provided for working families under those circumstances. We have never quarrelled with that. What this Government has done-the three card trick; the dishonesty of the Hawke Labor Government-is disguise the additions to that scheme as being assistance to families in Australia; it is not. It is assistance to a tiny proportion of families in Australia. If we are going to get ministerial statements in Question Time, if we get continued abuse at Question Time in the way Senator Bolkus abused it today when I believe he set out to misrepresent the position with respect to assistance to families and to misrepresent the position that has been consistently advocated by Senator Harradine, then I put the Government on notice, since Senator Button says that we will not get leave to move to take note of these matters, if there is going to be any debate on it, that we will move for suspension of Standing Orders to enable debate on these matters forthwith.

Question Time is being abused by this Government. We are sick of it. If Senator Bolkus or other Ministers engage in it, then we will take up the time of the Senate to ensure that the record is put straight. The record with respect to family assistance is quite clear. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard, to foreshorten my contribution to this debate, pages 7 and 8 and the first two paragraphs on page 9 of the report `Families and Tax in 1989-AFIT Bulletin No. 5' instituted by the Australian Institute of Family Studies.
Leave granted.
