Table 1 shows the changes in average tax rates between 1976-77 and 1988-89 for various family types and income levels. The starting point of 1976-77 is chosen because this was the year of introduction of family allowances. Table 1 also shows the additional dollars paid in tax in 1988-89 compared with the tax that would have been paid in 1988-89 if the 1976-77 tax situation still prevailed. The calculation is based on estimated average weekly earnings in 1988-89 of $25 903.

The table indicates the changing tax circumstances of selected hypothetical families and individuals. The incidence and representativeness of these hypothetical situations in the Australian population can be assessed by reference to Appendices 6 and 7 which show the distribution of annual taxable incomes by family type according to the 1985-86 ABS Income Survey updated to 1988-89.

The pattern of higher increases in average tax rates for those on lower incomes is repeated for all the various family types shown in Table 1. The outstanding exception to this pattern is for families on low incomes with children. These people have been greatly assisted by the Family Allowance Supplement. The table shows, for example, that a couple with two children aged less than 13 years on half AWE are in fact $18 better off per week in tax terms than they would have been under 1976-77 conditions. In other words, FAS has already more than compensated for the increased tax circumstances of low-income families with children. In terms of the Government's Family Assistance Package, it remains for this group to receive the payments under the FAS system to bring total payments for children to 15 per cent and 20 per cent of the married rate of pension for children aged less than 13 years and 13-15 years respectively.

The most striking feature of Table 1 is the very high proportional increases in the average tax rates for all family types around AWE. This contrasts sharply with the large declines in average tax rates experienced by very high income earners during the same period. The increases in average tax rates for families on AWE range from 4.8 percentage points for one-income couples with no children, to 6.8 percentage points for two-income couples with two children. These increases in average tax rates for families on AWE compare with an increase of only 2.7 percentage points for a single taxpayer on AWE.

Middle-income families have fared worse because they have experienced declines in the real values of the dependent spouse rebate, the sole parent rebate and family allowances without the offsetting tax reductions that those on the highest marginal tax rate have received. In addition, where a total family income equal to AWE has been derived from two incomes, both incomes have suffered from the sharply increased average tax rates on low incomes, yet the family is above the income level where it could benefit from FAS. It is clear from these findings that a reform package must address the reduced circumstances of low income people without children (those in the income range where FAS applies) and all middle-income families.

When families on AWE without children are compared to families on AWE with children, it is clear that the increases in average tax rates have been much greater for those with children. Indeed, it is middle-income families with children that have fared worst in the tax system over the past 12 years. This conclusion applies irrespective of whether the family with children is a sole parent family, a one-income couple family or a two-income couple family. This reflects the decline in the real value of family allowances. Thus, in any reform package, middle-income families with children would require additional benefit.

At income levels higher than AWE, increases in average tax rates have been greater for families with children than for taxpayers of a similar type, but without children, and at the same income level. Thus, a two-income couple with children on 2AWE, for example, has fared worse than a two-income couple without children on 2AWE. Similarly, a single parent on 1.5AWE has fared badly compared to a single person on the same income level. This trend indicates the need in a tax reform package to give additional benefits to all families with children.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Those pages make it quite clear that for the vast majority of modestly placed Australians-I am talking now about the school teachers, policemen, bus drivers, shop assistants, clerks, process workers, the people who make up the bulk of the work force in this country--
—People whose wage increases you have opposed every year.

—The Leader of the Government in the Senate now seeks to widen this debate into the opposition to wage increases. Let us look at this Government's record with respect to wage increases. What this Government has done in its accord with the trade unions is to produce wage increases which are between two and three times higher and two and three times as fast as the wage rises in comparable countries. What is happening under this Government is that, because it has completely messed up economic management and because productivity is stagnant-and the Minister cannot deny it-those wage rises have translated into inflation. Australian workers are worse and worse off under this Government. That is why people are so sick of it.

SPEECH.PARA: The truth of the matter is that figures do not lie when they are analysed properly. The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development analysis, which is greatly provided by this Government, shows that this Government has achieved stagnant productivity and a declining standard of living for many Australians. One can excuse Government members their stupidity and economic mismanagement-and perhaps I should close soon to allow the debate to proceed under the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Senator Austin Lewis, who will be bringing forward a matter of public importance in just a few minutes-and one can have some sympathy for a government which is not capable of managing the economy which prevents the disasters now facing Australia, but one cannot excuse a Labor Government which loads the burden onto the lowest income earners. It is made quite clear here that the lowest income earners without dependants have suffered very badly. Middle income earners with dependants have suffered very badly. As against that, the only benefits that are shown in these tables are for high income earners. This Government is a social joke. It has totally ignored its own constituency. I look forward to having many debates on these issues. This Government is a disgrace and the people of Australia know it. I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented and seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio program The World Today an interview was conducted between a Mr Phillip Russell and a Mrs Christine Milne, who, for the information of the Senate, has been a central figure in the Wesley Vale pulp mill disaster. In the course of her remarks on that program Mrs Milne said:

SPEECH.PARA: But I perhaps didn't expect the level of anger in the local community, and I think that was exacerbated by the behaviour of Senator Stone, Mr Reg Hope and Mr Chris Miles who held a meeting in Devonport in which they really whipped people into a frenzy of anger and stereotyped the radical greenie as the person to blame. And I think that did a lot of damage in the community.
First of all, I totally deny being part of any process of whipping people into a frenzy in the course of a public meeting held in Devonport on the evening in question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or anywhere else, I would hope.

—Or anywhere else, indeed, as I am reminded by one of my colleagues. There was no frenzy in that meeting. There was deep emotion; there was deep but very well controlled anger. I think it is fair to say that there was bitter hostility to the activities of well-heeled people like Mrs Christine Milne. But there was no frenzy. Secondly, I totally deny the charge of having stereotyped the radical greenie as the person to blame. I did use the term `radical greenie' to distinguish between what I call the extreme, the blinkered, the unreasoning, the irrational anti-development person, such as Mrs Milne-I might say the pro-unemployment person like Mrs Milne-and the great majority of Australians who are perfectly conscious of the need for sensible conservation and environmental policies in this country but who do not take their objections or views in that regard to the point of denying a $1,000m capital investment project which would otherwise have produced 500 jobs.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 5 April, from Senator Lewis:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency-

The need for the government to reform areas such as the waterfront, telecommunications, transport, coastal shipping and industrial relations because, as the Governor of the Reserve Bank has said, micro-economic reform has a major role to play in raising productivity and is now urgently needed.'
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency-

The need for the government to reform areas such as the waterfront, telecommunications, transport, coastal shipping and industrial relations because, as the Governor of the Reserve Bank has said, micro-economic reform has a major role to play in raising productivity and is now urgently needed.

I note that on the speakers list the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, will be following me, and I shall be interested to hear how he responds to that statement that these matters are now urgently needed. Will he deny them or will he, as he has already indicated in his interjections to Senator Chaney, as usual make some personal attack? As we know, Senator Button plays the man when he is on the back foot and never the ball. After the 1987 election 20 months ago, Mr Hawke announced that micro-economic reform would be the key element of the Government's third term agenda. Where are we down the track on that element of this Government's agenda? Frankly, nowhere. I am disappointed that it is Senator Button who is following me. I was rather hoping that it would be the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh. Notwithstanding Senator Walsh's rudeness and vitriolic tongue, in this particular matter some of us on this side of the chamber almost feel sorry for him. He is tired and worn out.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has practically given up.

—As my colleague Senator Hill says, he is worn out; he wants to resign. The National Media Liaison Service has convinced the media that he is tired because he is sick of saying no to Ministers who ask him for more money. I say to the Senate and to the public that that is absolute nonsense. We know that Senator Walsh is worn out because for nearly six years in government he has been battering his head against a brick wall as he has tried to persuade his Cabinet colleagues to introduce some micro-economic changes even of a minor nature, all to no avail. No wonder he is exhausted. No wonder he wants to get out.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government does not even have the courage to decide to build Mascot's third runway. There has been no decision yet. The National Media Liaison Service again has persuaded the compliant media in Australia to hoodwink the people into believing that some decision has been made. In fact, the only decision that has been made is to defer the decision for another 18 months pending an environmental impact study. It was that decision not to make a decision that caused Senator Walsh to say, `Well, I give up; I am sick of it. If the Government cannot even make up its mind to build a third runway in Sydney how on earth will the Government have the courage to fix up the waterfront or to address the coastal shipping problems? How on earth will the Government have the courage to address the industrial relations problems in this country? How on earth will the Government face the transport difficulties that have to be faced by a government which is genuinely concerned about micro-economic reform in this country?'.

That is why Senator Walsh is worn out. He recognises that after six years of being Minister for Finance in this Government he would have made a greater contribution to the economic problems of Australia if he had stayed at home growing more wheat for export. That is the simple situation. Of course, we saw him today during Question Time. He is like a punch-drunk boxer. When the roar of the crowd comes he rises to his feet and the hands come up, but in truth it is only to surrender.

The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, having made that statement about micro-economic reform being the key element of this Government's agenda, in May of last year the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the other place-Senator Walsh repeated the words of that speech in this place-said:
. . . tonight I will announce to the people of Australia far reaching economic reforms that will take our nation into the 21st century.
Do honourable senators remember the rhetoric?

TALK.START.PARA: —When was this?
—That was on 25 May of last year. He continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I am also announcing another comprehensive range of fundamental economic reforms.
But at the outset I want to make it clear why they are necessary.
This Government is committed to getting all aspects of the economy right.
What has happened to interest rates? What has happened to inflation?

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the bacon he was going to bring home?
—My colleague reminds me about the bacon he was going to bring home. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the impetus for change must be transmitted to managements and workers who make the crucial decisions about where and when to invest, and how to go about their work.
They are the crucial things-`how to go about their work'. He continues:
If we cannot get these things right, we will never really get the big picture right.
This is why the Government has adopted such a complete and comprehensive strategy--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—That was Mr Keating. He goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: This is why the Government has adopted such a complete and comprehensive strategy; big brush economic changes reinforced by sweeping strokes going to the micro or industry level.
What we have been after is a full picture-not something half finished.
He goes on to say that the Government had taken major steps to reform its business enterprises. I will come to that area in due course. He went on to say:
More competitive pressure will also be applied to the operations of Telecom and the Overseas Telecommunications Commission . . .
I shall address that later. Having said that on 25 May, two days later the Australian Financial Review reports:
The Federal Treasurer, Mr Keating, turned his attention yesterday-
in other words, one day after he made that speech-
to the labour market, which he sees as the last great reform challenge for Labor.

In other words, the very day after he made the statement of 25 May he acted as if the things he said in that statement had already come true and the last great area for change to be overcome was the labour market. Of course, he was right but it was not the last area for change. It is absolutely necessary that the labour market be reformed but what on earth has the Government done about any of these things? What on earth has the Government done about its micro-economic reform? What on earth has the Government done about the reform of the labour market? There were some tariff reductions and tax changes. We acknowledge that. There were some cosmetic changes to the Government's business enterprises. Some of them changed their names. The Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC) and the Australian National Line changed their names to public companies and got boards of directors. As to infrastructure changes, there was virtually nothing done. It instituted some inquiries. There was a lot of talk but by March of this year, about 10 months after Mr Keating had made this speech, the Government acknowledged that no changes had been made and by then it knew this country was going down the drain so far as its terms of trade were concerned at the rate of $15 billion a year. By then everyone was screaming for micro-economic reform. So what did the Government do? It decided to make some speeches about it. I really do not know whether the Prime Minister, Mr Keating or Senator Button believe that if they talk about something the people will believe they have done it. But believe me, the people no longer believe that they have done it. I will tell honourable senators some of the things they said. On 3 March this year the Prime Minister said:
A lot of people were thinking that the April statement-
that is, the one that is to come out next week-
was just going to be an announcement of tax cuts. I think you'll find there'll be more in it than that.

That was a great statement. It built up our expectations immediately. On 2 March Mr Steve Burrell wrote an article in the Australian Financial Review. We all know that Mr Burrell is commonly known as the mouthpiece of the Treasurer. He seems to have some sort of direct communication with him. In that article he said:

The Federal Government will widen the scope of its April Economic Statement to include a number of micro-economic reforms in an attempt to address criticism that its structural adjustment agenda has been allowed to stall.
There is an acknowledgment that the Government's structural adjustment has been allowed to stall. Once again the rhetoric comes out. Mr Burrell went on:
The Structural Adjustment Committee of Cabinet agreed yesterday that ministers should bring forward work on policy changes . . .

The Prime Minister announced in July 1987 that it was going to happen. In March of this year, 1989, the structural adjustment committee is saying, `You Ministers have to bring forward these proposals'. Mr Burrell reports that they should:
bring forward work on policy changes already in train and develop new initiatives for inclusion in the statement in key areas such as education and training, industry-
Senator Button is talking about bringing it forward in industry-
science-
Mr Barry Jones is incapable of producing anything for the science community-
research and development, transport and communication, housing and social welfare.
Twenty months after the election nothing has been done in these crucial areas. In this report Mr Keating's mouthpiece went on to say:

Mr Keating has been increasingly concerned about criticism levelled at the Government that its agenda of micro-economic reform-promoted as the centrepiece of its third term-has stalled in the face of union resistance and a loss of political will.

Let me draw the attention of honourable senators to those specific words. Mr Keating is not concerned that there is no reform. He is concerned that there is no perception of reform. That is what he is worried about. He is not worried about producing reform, he is worried that the people do not think he is doing anything about reform so he has to come out with some form of words which will make people believe that this Government is doing something. I tell Senator Button that it is good having Mr Burrell as Mr Keating's mouthpiece because we get all sorts of reports as to what happens in Cabinet. The article by Mr Burrell reads:
Mr Hawke sought initiatives from ministers late last year to counter perceptions that the Government had lost its political energy and lacked a vision for a fourth term.

Again, the Prime Minister is concerned about perceptions; he is not concerned about the reform which is desperately needed. Three weeks later, on 23 March 1989 in the Australian Financial Review, Mr Burrell reported:
The Federal Government dropped plans yesterday to include a number of micro-economic reforms in the April statement . . .

Again, it has all fallen in a great heap and again, we are not even to get an announcement of micro-economic reforms from this Government. I now turn to a very important speech by Mr Johnston, the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia. This is not a speech by some Liberal or National Party politician; this is a speech by the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia. I quote:
It is also important to realise that we can't keep the economy in a permanent state of sedation in order to keep the current account and inflation in check.
How very true that is in relation to the macro-economic situation. He then goes on to deal with the micro-economic situation, which is what we are talking about. He says:

We need to press on with more constructive policies-to switch investment growth into export and import-replacing industries, to save more to finance investment, to sustain our international competitiveness and to raise productivity.
The so-called micro policies of reform-of work practices and the established ways of doing things-have a major role to play in raising productivity.
These are more-not less-urgent when all is not going smoothly at the macro level.

In other words, Mr Johnston acknowledges that things are not going smoothly at the macro level. He says that that makes it all the more urgent for the Government to do something in this area. I refer to another paragraph of Mr Johnston's speech:
They reflect the degree of willingness that we Australians are prepared to offer in order that the country may reach its full potential.

What is the Government doing? We are unable to point to anything that it has done in relation to these matters. The Industries Assistance Commission in its draft report on coastal shipping pointed out that it is cheaper to ship salt from Mexico to Australia than around the Australian coast. It is cheaper to ship sugar from overseas to Western Australia than from Queensland or New South Wales, and it is cheaper to ship milk powder from Tasmania to Taiwan than from Tasmania to the mainland.

A few days ago, 10 months after the Government made an announcement about telecommunications, it finally produced a draft telecommunications Bill in relation to Austel, which is due to come into operation on 1 July. If one looks at that Bill one will see that the Government is interested only in protecting the monopolies of the carriers-OTC, Aussat Pty Ltd and Telecom Australia-and is not interested in doing anything to implement the things that Mr Keating talked about on 25 May when, as I said, he said that more competitive pressure will be applied to the operations of Telecom and the Overseas Telecommunications Commission. Where is that set out in this draft Bill? Nowhere. What is set out in this draft Bill is a continuation of the monopolies of Telecom. I am not the only one saying that. If Government senators wish to take any notice of Professor Baxt, Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission, they can read in yesterday's national affairs section of the Australian Financial Review this report of what he said:
. . . that the bill establishing Austel and the new rules for the industry had failed to embody the deregulatory spirit of the policy announced in last year's May Economic Statement.

Again, in another simple area where the Government could have taken some steps to introduce some micro-economic reform it steps away from it. Since Senator Gareth Evans has handed over the portfolio of transport and communications to Mr Willis, micro-economic reform has run into an absolute brick wall and has stopped.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because he talks to the trade unions. He takes his orders from the trade unions and always has done.
—Exactly. As my colleague Senator Stone says, the trouble with Mr Willis is that he has always taken his orders from the trade union movement, and it is not interested in micro-economic reform.

SPEECH.PARA: No longer does Australia have excuses for being uncompetitive with the rest of the world. We now have a population of over 16 million. That is not a bad size domestic population to enable industries to get a start. Our wages, in comparison with those of some of our overseas competitors, are not high. Senator Button appears to dispute my statement about population. I say to him that the population of the German Democratic Republic is about the same as that of Australia. It is doing better than we are, notwithstanding its communist regime. In comparison with our Asian neighbours our wages are no longer high. The Australian dollar is not as low in value as Senator Button would want and, on the other hand, not as high as Mr Keating would want.

The question is: Why are we going down the drain at the rate of $15 billion a year? What is this Government going to do about it? What is its policy, other than just to wait and see? Will it wait until whatever the year is, 1993 or 1994, when the Economic Planning Advisory Council predicted we might get back to par? What is the Government doing about it? Absolutely nothing. We are going down the drain through our trade balance at the rate of over $1 billion a month, and this Government is not addressing the problems. What are those problems? They are work practices, restrictive regulations, business input costs and rigidities built into the system. In addition there are taxes, inflation and interest rates. At least the Government could be addressing at this stage these micro-economic matters which I have listed. There is no question of what we are talking about. We are talking about reforming the waterfront, telecommunications, transport, coastal shipping and industrial relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the need for Opposition senators to psych each other up. It is absolutely essential. When John Howard's name was mentioned at Question Time they all made yawning noises, which is precisely what the electorate is doing. Senator Lewis has made a speech which is, of course, a collection of quotes thrown together in no particularly coherent way. The lightest touch in his speech was when Senator Stone interjecting that Mr Willis gets his instructions from the trade union movement. People said, `Oh, that's dreadful'. Senator Stone was the right man to make that interjection. The Liberal Party gets its instructions on these issues from the National Party, and did so throughout the 30 years that it was in government. That was why no micro-economic reforms were carried out in this country. That was why nothing happened in that period of government. That is why this Government has the problem today: in those 30 out of 39 years when the Opposition was in office, it did nothing about these things. That is why they are all on the agenda today. A day or two ago Mr Howard was interviewed here in Canberra by Pru Goward. He spoke about some of these issues. She challenged him about producing long term solutions. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: No, no. Long term solutions are the important ones, and this Government has frittered away years . . . the almost two years now has gone by since the last election has been . . . frittered away-nothing achieved, nothing gained, nothing planned, nothing changed, and even at this late stage, I would say to the Government, `Use the April statement as a vehicle for comprehensive economic reform. Don't see it merely as a tax bribe exercise'.

The Leader of the Liberal Party advises the Government about tax bribe exercises! This is the man who was the Treasurer in a government which waved around fistfuls of dollars before an election in tax offers to the Australian people and took them away five months late-and he lectures us about tax bribes. The Liberal Party is feeling a bit good at the moment because interest rates are up and things like that, and this improves its psychological condition for a few months. The Liberal Party goes through these perpetual crises; morale goes up when economic conditions turn down. That is what has happened in the last six or seven years and the Liberal Party is on an up phase at the moment. But let us look at what it is all about. A lot of it is about what was put in the Liberals' document called Future Directions. I will quote from what a respected political commentator said in the Bulletin on 13 December about Future Directions:

There is plenty of truth glossed over and no shortage of unrealistic promises in . . . ``Future Directions''. The unrealistic promise of simple solutions to immensely complex problems underpins the whole exercise. It is not possible to return to the comfortable predictability and simplicity of the 1950s but ``Future Directions'' encourages people to believe it.

The document seeks to imply that Labor deserves blame for protectionist policies which were, of course . . . the work of ``Black Jack'' McEwen and the Menzies government. It tries to pin Labor as the Party of regulation, ignoring the Hawke government's major deregulatory measures such as floating the dollar and admitting foreign banks. Howard, Treasurer in the last Liberal government which conspicuously failed to implement significant free market policies, is portrayed as the great deregulator. The coalition which has been in power in Australia for 30 of the last 39 years suggests that Labor is primarily responsible for the decline in moral values, the family, education standards, . . .
As analysis, in other words, ``Future Directions'' is about as shonky as can be.

The same might be said of the speech that has just been made. Members of the Liberal Party talked today about how they, presumably, would tackle some of these issues. They gave no indication of how they would do it; it is just suggested by implication in some vague way that they would. It is a funny day for them to come in here and talk about these sorts of issue. It is the day after the Liberal Party, the Party of deregulation, was again stood over by its National Party colleagues and friends on the issue of deregulation of the domestic wheat market-again stood over as it was for year after year of the Fraser Government, the Menzies Government and others in between.

The Australian Financial Review, in today's editorial, talked about the compromise that the Liberal Party reached, against its wishes, on deregulating the wheat market because it had to face up to that issue now; it could not put it off until after the next election as it did in those 30 years of government. This compromise was made by the Liberal Party, with many of its prominent figures-or should I say noisy figures; it would be generosity in the extreme to describe Wilson Tuckey as prominent. But Wilson Tuckey and others prominent in the Liberal Party in that sense made that compromise. The Financial Review said about it:

As an exercise in damage control, it can at least be said that it avoids the hilarious condition placed on steps towards wheat deregulation by that silo socialist Mr Sinclair, leader of the National Party: that progress first be made towards eliminating agricultural subsidies on world markets.

The editorial goes on to say that the conditions which the Opposition has placed on the legislation to deregulate the domestic wheat market, involving transport, handling, storage and waterfront areas `are indeed long overdue and desperately needed'. This Government does not disagree with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you doing about it?

—I hope the honourable senator is in the minority in the Party room. He has at least been consistent on some of these issues. But the editorial makes the point that these changes are needed, as Mr Howard well knows, as well as domestic wheat market deregulation. So the members of the Liberal Party, when confronted in their Party room with a real issue that they have to face up to, as distinct from waffling about us in here, because they are scared of the National Party they reach a shonky compromise, tacking these other things onto this very important issue in the Australian economy, the deregulation of the wheat market. That is the sort of alternative government that we would get in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators opposite talk about structural problems in the Australian economy. Let us have a look at the structural problems in the coalition. The Australian people would get the same performance from honourable senators opposite as we got over 30 years from previous coalition governments. As the article in the Bulletin points out, these issues are useful in opposition-I suppose honourable senators over there have to be able to say something-but really they are not very much to the point. Senator Lewis asked what is being done about science funding and research and development, as if that is a new issue. I happened to be looking through the Tertiary Education Commission report for 1982, the last year in government of honourable senators opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why would you look through that? Why don't you look at your own?
—The honourable senator asks why I would be looking through that. I found this--
—Why don't you quote the 1988 one?
—I am quite happy. It is Senator Lewis's job to quote the 1988 report if he can find anything in it. But honourable senators should listen to what the Commission said in 1982:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the proportion of universities' recurrent expenditure devoted to research activities has steadily declined, that the ratio of total research expenditure from all sources to total recurrent expenditure has fallen significantly, and that the total research expenditure per research worker has been steadily falling (in real terms).
We hear Mr McGauran-I am not sure whether the one I am talking about is National Party or Liberal, but whatever he is-making big unquantified promises about research funding and so on.

We are here about politics. Ultimately the people have to make a choice between us and the Opposition. The first point I want to make is that, on the basis of the record of honourable senators opposite-not only in government when they tackled none of the issues they are now complaining about but also in opposition-when confronted with an issue they have to face up to they will run away from it because of the National Party. The record is quite clear for students of politics to see. The numerous problems that this Government has had to face up to are the result of years and years of neglect and lack of courage and vision sufficient to tackle some of these issues which now face the Australian people. It is this Government's role to get us out of that mess, and it is a difficult process. There is some talk about tired people on this side of the House, but look at what is happening opposite.

I want to make a few points about some of the things which this Government has done. I do not think macro-economic issues are much in question in this debate. The Opposition, when confronted with difficult alternatives to the Government on macro-economic issues, really runs away from those, and there are not many differences.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Johnston has explained why. You have got this country into such a shambles that there is nothing you can do about high interest rates or to try to keep the dollar up. It is all your fault.

—That is right. Mr Johnston has said nothing different from what he and his predecessors have said to us over the years and he has said nothing different from what the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and other spokesmen for this Government have said on a number of occasions. We recognise the problem and we are facing up to it. We are capable of facing up to it and we have sufficient courage to do so, which the Opposition did not have over all the years it was in government, and it does not even have now in opposition.
—Every time there was an election or even a by-election, all he could talk about was interest rates-that interest rates would come down; easy to predict.

—I do not think there are many substantial differences on macro-economic policy. So the Opposition has discovered, for the first time in its history, macro-economic policy. Senator Lewis keeps interjecting about interest rates, inflation and all these things. Last year he used to say Australia had a higher inflation rate than all the countries we could think of. What countries did he mention? He mentioned the United States of America and the United Kingdom. They were always at the top of his list. Australia had a higher inflation rate than those countries but we have not heard much about that this year from that lot opposite because the Australian inflation rate is now not higher than it is in those countries.
—It is not a question of making a comparison.

—No, but that is what the honourable senator used to do. Maybe he has forgotten. Somebody once said that if a new idea ever entered a British politician's head, there was no evidence of a new one having ever left. That remark might well be ascribed to Senator Lewis, because in the speech he just made there is not a sign of a new idea having left his head.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to go through some of the things that this Government has done on micro-economic reform. There have been enormous financial reforms in this country, such as the floating of the dollar, the deregulation of the financial sector and the admission of foreign banks. All those things were on the agenda before the Opposition when it was in government, and it ran away from them. It did not take the advice of the experts it appointed to deal with them. There has been massive taxation reform in this country; the tax base has been widened; there has been the introduction of the capital gains tax; a reduction in corporate taxes; a whole range of changes to the personal taxation regimes and so on, and further tax changes will be announced this month. Senator Lewis made some comments about labour market reform. The important point to remember is that we do not say we have succeeded with this issue. It is no good our saying that we are perfect in respect of labour market reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course there is no use in your saying it.

—No, but look at the results. The honourable senator claimed in his speech that wages in Australia in comparison to those in Asian countries are no longer high. Senator Chaney was making exactly the opposite point in his speech a few minutes before. What is the Opposition saying? Are they too high or are they too low? The Opposition would not have a clue whether they were too high or too low. It is making opposite points within two 10-minute spans. If we look at the results of industrial relations reform in this country we see that less than half the number of industrial disputes occur now compared to those under the previous Government. Enormous breakthroughs have taken place and are taking place in work force flexibility and in award restructuring. These are historic things which those people opposite ran away from.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lewis mentioned industry policy. If he had made his speech two years ago, half of the people on his side of the chamber would have said that we ought to do something about tariffs in Australia, and the other half, represented by Senator Watson and others, would have said that we should not do anything about tariffs. We did it. The Opposition did not do it in all its time in government. It frigged around at the edge of the debate and did nothing in all of the period that it was in government. We did it in May last year, with a 20 per cent cut in manufacturing tariffs, and there were cuts even before that. The Opposition did nothing about the two-airline agreement, but we did. It did nothing about oil market deregulation, but we have done something. It did nothing about government business enterprises, but we have, although perhaps not enough-more to go. It did nothing about telecommunications deregulation, but we did it through greater private access to the provision of customer services. It did nothing about aggregation in the television system, but we have done it. All these are fundamental reforms which we had to tackle. Somebody had to have the guts to do it, and the guts were not found in the people who now re-present themselves, because interest rates are a bit high, as a possible alternative government in this country. The same intestinal fortitude exists in these people as in those who were around in the Opposition's period in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Senator Walsh's retirement threat?

—The honourable senator does not have his facts right even on Senator Walsh's retirement. I understand his debating point, but Senator Walsh's alleged retirement offer was made about three weeks before any decision was made about the Sydney airport or before the Government had addressed it. The honourable senator had it all wrong; that is the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: All these things I have referred to are fundamental reforms which have been pursued by this Government, and they will be pursued further in April and May in respect of some of the issues which Senator Lewis has mentioned, such as the waterfront, coastal shipping and so on, in the matter of urgency which he has moved.

But ultimately we can only talk. Senator Lewis was going on about people talking and acting. This Government has acted. In this sort of debate we can only talk, but we have done a lot by way of action. We do not by and means rest on our laurels. We have an awful long way to go in this country because of those 30 years of sadness and neglect when governments of the conservative persuasion were stood over by the National Party of Australia. Those governments missed opportunities and did not have the courage to take hard decisions. Similar people here are criticising us. It is a disgrace. I would have been told by my parents, `You cannot criticise people like that unless you put your own house in order, unless you have courage and conviction yourself'. But that is what those opposite are paid for, so they come in here and criticise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button has said in his contribution to the debate that we are here about politics and that people have to make a choice. He also referred to an interview between Pru Goward on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio in the ACT and the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, in which the interviewer was pushing the Leader of the Opposition for long term economic solutions. That is certainly the key. The Australian Democrats join with the Opposition in this urgency motion in calling for the Government to reform Australia's economic environment but the nature of those reforms must be in accordance with concepts of social justice.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this opportunity to place on record the way the Australian Democrats would shape the economy. Obviously Australia is increasingly facing serious inter-related economic, environmental and social problems. We continue to live beyond our means while our future is being shaped by decisions made with little concern for the longer term consequences and in the absence of public consultation or scrutiny. The economic practices which govern all of our lives reflect an increasing lack of concern for what should be the central issues of social and environmental quality of life in both domestic and international contexts. The economic policies of both the Opposition and the Government perpetuate this destructive and shortsighted disregard for our future.

The Australian Democrats want an Australian economy which is socially equitable, environmentally sustainable, democratically controlled and which makes a positive contribution to the well-being of the Asian and Pacific region in particular. Our economic policies are designed to realise these interdependent goals. To achieve these goals-goals which I suggest any responsible political party ought to find difficulty disagreeing with-we believe we need an economy which is significantly different in structure and process from that which we now experience. It must be an economy which is based first and foremost on cooperative endeavour and on the acceptance that it is both rational and profitable to make social needs and ecological principles an integral part of our economic behaviour. The market, much vaunted especially by the Opposition and only to a slightly lesser extent by the Government, is a useful tool in assisting and planning the allocation of goods and services, but it fails to guarantee that these social needs and ecological principles are recognised. To leave our economic fate entirely to the market is to abdicate responsibility to build an economically viable, socially just and environmentally sustainable society. Nor can unrestricted private ownership of industry and control over investment, or bureaucratic self-interest, be allowed to override these goals. They are best pursued through open, cooperative and participatory processes of planning and production involving local communities, employees, unions, employers and government. Emphasis on democratic planning, decentralisation of productivity and increased community self-reliance is central to the progressive displacement of the socially and environmentally inefficient functions of the market as a major means of allocating resources and satisfying human needs.

The Democrats want to encourage the growth of cooperative enterprises and we would require, over time, that shared ownership and participatory decision making governed the actions of all public and private sector enterprises and utilities which employ more than 10 people. We envisage that this process would reshape the structure and performance of the economy which would increasingly comprise three sectors: a few large public sector enterprises and administrative units necessary for the provision of goods and services in their areas, and large private sector corporations, each publicly and democratically managed as one sector; a second sector of many small public or private sector organisations, cooperatively run and owned businesses employing 10 people or more; and a third sector of individual private sector units which employ less than 10 people. We are a great distance from realising these goals, but the source of our support for the motion before us today is simply what that motion says, that we need economic reform. We certainly agree that we need reform in the directions which I am outlining.

The economic policies and practices pursued or proposed by the other parties in this place are in fact hindering our progress in the directions which the Democrats would want to go. As a result, the Australian economy is not serving the Australian people. Clearly it is not serving the Australian people. Ask people whether they believe they are better off or worse off now than they were three years ago or five years ago. Most people have a perception that they are worse off, yet we have more jobs in the economy, we have a Budget surplus, we have increased industry profits; yet people still feel they are worse off. Clearly the economy is not serving the Australian people. There is excessive unemployment. Both the Government and the Opposition seem satisfied with the fact that we have plateaued our unemployment at 6 or 7 per cent. Major economic advisers in our community throw their hands up in horror when the figures show that the numbers of jobs are increasing. They say the economy will overheat, that it will tip in the wrong direction. It appears that we need to maintain a plateau of 6 to 8 per cent unemployment. It is unacceptable as far as the Australian Democrats are concerned.

Ordinary consumers lack purchasing power for the goods and services that we could readily produce with our unused labour, resources and machines. On the one hand, there is an excessive and increasing concentration of wealth in the hands of a few; yet, on the other hand, the number of people living in poverty continues to increase. Financial deregulation of which Senator Button on the Government's behalf is so proud-tax avoidance, off-shore investment and an increasing foreign control of Australian enterprises and resources-is also occurring. Manufacturing industry is declining. Productive investment is low. Many companies are moving their operations overseas and others are threatening to if we try to get them to meet their taxation responsibilities here. Many small businesses continue to go bankrupt. We have accumulated a massive level of foreign debt and, as a consequence, our economic priorities are increasingly determined by international financiers, hence the economy does not serve the ordinary people. The proportion of women in the labour market has improved marginally, but young people, ethnic people and Aboriginal people still face major disadvantages. Our natural resources are being destroyed at a rapid rate and there is no serious attempt to develop alternative energy sources. We have a long way to go.

As Senator Button said, people have to make a choice and people will make a choice. We need to look at the issue of reform in the hands of the Opposition and the Government. I have outlined the basis for reform that the Australian Democrats would want to see. The performance of the Fraser Government between 1977 and 1980 when, it is interesting to note, Senator Stone played such an active role in the Government's economic platform, resulted in a period of industrial anarchy and a severe blow-out of wages in 1981. The bull-at-a-gate approach of the coalition proved singularly unsuccessful in its previous term in office. While we support the basic thrust of the urgency motion, any reforms which take place must not be along those sorts of lines. On the other hand, by maintaining a sound relationship with the Australian Council of Trade Unions through the accord, the Australian Labor Party (ALP) has been able to institute gradual reforms-for example, in the shipping industry-that have seen our industrial relations record, and therefore our image, improve amongst our trading partners while starting the move towards a reduction of the featherbedding which has characterised, and which still does to a great extent characterise, the Australian waterfront. To adopt a confrontationist approach to these reforms would be both foolhardy and ineffective. The ALP's policy to make haste slowly is much more economically sensible than the Opposition's approach which in the past has resulted in the alienation of the waterfront and the stagnation of trade due to conflict between coalition governments and unions. We need to look at the failure of coalition governments to deal with the demands of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) to attempt to commence reforms on the waterfront. Honourable senators will remember that in 1980 the IAC called on the Fraser Government to establish a formal inquiry into coastal shipping and waterfront activities. This was not established until last year by the Australian Labor Party Government.

From looking at this motion, it seems that the Liberal Party has failed to learn from its disasters of the late 1970s and early 1980s when it was in government. This period showed that punitive legislation and confrontationist policies failed to deliver in Australia in the area of industrial relations. Industrial relations is a vital factor in this motion before us today. A poor industrial relations record like that of the Fraser Government could not have delivered the return that the ALP is beginning to obtain in various areas of micro-economic reform. In an article in the Age in July last year headed `Liberal Party ignores past mistakes at its own peril' Peter Stephens said:
The Liberals have failed to handle industrial relations before because they do not understand the relationship between economic conditions and wages policy.
I will also quote what was said by a member of the Liberal Party in the other place, Ian Macphee. In an article in the Herald in April last year he is quoted as saying:

I am frankly in no doubt that the wages outcome which has been delivered so far by the Government could not have been achieved by a coalition Government, even if I had been Industrial Relations Minister.

That is, of course, something which this motion tends to ignore. It must be said, however, that unfortunately the Australian Labor Party itself is sacrificing in too many respects the concepts of the accord in order to uphold Thatcher-like policies that have led to the erosion of real standards of living for its traditional supporters while, at the same time, allowing the transnational corporations, or our own home grown varieties, to send their middle and particularly their upper level employees on a wages spiral.

At this point I would put on the record the Democrats' disappointment with the Government's approach to the trade union developed document Australia Reconstructed. That document acknowledged that this nation and this economy are in a transition period. It took a positive approach and made innovative suggestions. But the Government has not acknowledged and acted upon the innovative aspects that were brought forward in Australia Reconstructed. Of course, the Opposition has been totally reactionary. Certainly the Opposition has taken this attitude-and I would be very disappointed if this were the case in respect of the Government-because of the hand of people like Laurie Carmichael in the development of that document.

The Government had a golden opportunity when the Industrial Relations Bill was debated in this chamber last year to ensure that we all moved into a new and positive era in industrial relations. But the debate in this place demonstrated that both the Government and the Opposition were prepared only to maintain their entrenched positions of confrontation. As I said, the Australian Democrats support the coalition's call for the Government to commence the restructuring of the Australian economy as a whole but we have a particular view about the nature of that reconstruction.

We are a vast nation. Just picking up the question of telecommunications and transport, it is clear that the market cannot in all cases and in all instances support the needs of the Australian community. The Democrats believe that the quality of service received by the disadvantaged, whether they live in cities or outlying areas, is of paramount concern in the provision of public services. The Democrats have been asked to support Senator Lewis's motion. But what social benefits does the Opposition believe will accrue to the ordinary person, the ordinary family, in our community, as a result of its proposed micro-economic restructuring or, in other words, privatisation. The benefits of the real growth in profits that corporations are now experiencing are being felt only at upper levels of income while ordinary families are increasingly at the mercy of those large corporations. That is why the Australian Democrats emphasise that reform must be accompanied by the concept of social equity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of urgency on the need for the Government to reform areas such as the waterfront, telecommunications, transport, coastal shipping and industrial relations because, as the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia has said, micro-economic reform has a major role to play in raising productivity and is now urgently needed. The Hawke Labor Government has reduced the Australian economy to a shambles. This is despite good prices for our export commodities. The old excuse about the terms of trade going wrong is no longer true. Our terms of trade are good, yet our economy is in a shambles. After the next election, the incoming coalition Government will have a tremendous task to get this country back on the rails.

SPEECH.PARA: Look at what the management of the Treasurer, Mr Keating, has achieved in the last six years. We have borrowed $85,000m overseas to maintain our standard of living. We are now the third most indebted country in the world. The interest bill on our foreign debt is taking a fifth of our export income. We are now promised wages rises and tax cuts but no compensating reductions in Government expenditure. The resultant increase in consumer spending will make our overseas indebtedness much more disastrous. Our inflation rate is double that of our competitors. Despite a lot of talk, productivity in the vital manufacturing and transport sectors has scarely risen at all. Improved productivity is essential if we are to raise, or even maintain, our standards of living, for the productivity of our competitors is rising while ours is standing still. Under this Government's economic management, we are not becoming more competitive; we are becoming less competitive.

Interest rates are sky high, and they are going to go even higher despite the nonsense talked by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) while overseas. These high interest rates deprive many young Australians of the chance to own a home, make vital new investments in plant and equipment uneconomic and, through the resultant overvaluation of the Australian dollar, make it much more difficult for our manufacturers to be internationally competitive. It is a very sorry tale. It is not surprising that Mr Keating was runner-up in 1986 for the title of world's worst finance Minister. The winner, by the way, was the Finance Minister of Egypt. For some curious reason, this achievement by Mr Keating never seems to be mentioned by the Australian Labor Party.

What we must urgently look at, as this motion emphasises, is improving national productivity. This is, as I said, essential if we are to improve or even maintain our standard of living. Australians can be extremely productive. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing our productivity in a number of different areas compared with Britain, Germany, United States of America and Japan.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The table, which is the latest I have been able to get, is dated 1983. Although the figures are substantially true now, the relative position will have worsened because all the countries with which we are comparing ourselves have improved their productivity since then while Australia's productivity, in six years of Labor Government, has been virtually static. But, as I said, the table shows that Australians can be extremely productive. In agriculture Australian workers are nearly seven times as productive as Japanese workers. We are 1 1/2 times as productive as the United States.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth studying where we are more productive and where we are not. One is forced to the conclusion that the areas in which we are not productive are areas where militant unions have had and use their monopoly position. This has been to the great disadvantage of the community. We are, for instance, extremely uncompetitive with the United States in manufacturing and in transport. An Australian worker is roughly half as productive as an American worker and that makes it very difficult for us to be competitive on world markets.

The key area in this motion that I wish to discuss is the transport sector. This is where the most immediate gains can be made. Look at some of the problems. Delays, stoppages and inefficiences in our ports are costing our economy about $2,000m a year. Savings can be made. If they are made, they will be particularly beneficial because, for every dollar saved through transport reform, our economic output would rise by $2. There would be a $2 rise in national output for every dollar we could save by eliminating the featherbedding, inefficiencies and rorts in the transport industry. Other estimates have been made that 20 per cent of the $11.5 billion spent on transporting exports and imports could be saved by proper reforms of our transport industry. These are reforms that we do not make. If we do not make them, it is to our great disadvantage.

Let us look at some of the things that have been going on on the waterfront and the way in which the Government has been neglecting the opportunity to reform them. As I said, the costs are high, about $800m a year on our waterfront, costs to the community resulting from inefficiency and featherbedding. Our ports have the unenviable reputation of being the worst in the developed world. Of course, the community as a whole pays. We pay for the extra costs of things that are imported. Our exports are less competitive because of the costs in our port handling, so we all finish up paying for these imports.

It is not only extra costs. We lose contracts through unreliability; we frighten off companies who are not prepared to take the risks of becoming involved with our exports. I remember a few years ago I was in Korea and Japan. The news that used to come there comprised a list of strikes in Australia that affected those countries, strikes in the coal export industry, shipping strikes, port strikes. The reputation of Australia is deplorable in this field. We lose many contracts and the whole community suffers because these matters are not being tackled and the Government is putting all this in the too-hard basket. It is not tackling the problems, that it should be tackling.

I would like to give a couple of examples of the sort of featherbedding that goes on. When grain is being loaded one worker is required to stand at the edge and watch the loading into the container ship. But union rules insist on two workers being there. Only one is needed but two must be provided. Because there are two workers, the union insists that a supervisor must be present, and because there is a supervisor there must be a foreman. Thus four workers are employed to do one man's work. The world does not owe us a living. If we do things like this the whole community suffers.

Let me give another example. In 1985 the Australian National Line (ANL) ship River Torrens came to Brisbane carrying cement clinker from Adelaide. The ship had been restructured at considerable expense so she could unload in perfect safety and very rapidly without the need to employ any shore labour at all. When she reached Brisbane the union insisted that, for each of the three shifts, one foreman, one waterside worker and one clerk would be present and paid for even though there was nothing for them to do. Because they were there the union also insisted on having a first aid officer-in case they injured themselves doing nothing. These are the sorts of things that must be stopped. The whole community is suffering. We are trading with the rest of the world at an enormous loss. If we go on like this, we are in desperate trouble.

I will give one more example. Grain terminals use highly expensive capital equipment which is fairly standard around the world. If we look at grain terminal performance in the United States of America ports the throughput per employee is 60,000, 80,000, 80,000, 120,000 tonnes, an average of about 100,000 tonnes throughput per employee. In Sydney, using the same equipment, the throughput per employee is 17,000 tonnes. In Newcastle it is 21,000 tonnes. That really epitomises what we must tackle. We must stop merely addressing problems by simply talking about them, as the Government does, and start to really tackle them. The whole community suffers with the inefficiency of our transport shipping and port handling facilities.

I would like to turn briefly to coastal shipping, which I have spoken on many times in this chamber. Because of the ruthless use of the monopoly power of the maritime unions our coastal shipping has become highly inefficient by any standards and what is carried in our coastal shipping is only what cannot reasonably be carried any other way. If one goes up the Hume Highway, for instance, one sees containers being transported by road from Melbourne to Sydney. That is ludicrous. They should go by ship. They do not, for very good reasons. We are using our transport very inefficiently because of the ruthless way in which the monopoly powers of the maritime unions have been exploited.

As I have said many times in this chamber, but it is worth reiterating very briefly, if we bought a ship from Sweden and raised the standard of accommodation from what is accepted in Sweden, a country with a higher standard of living than we have, and fitted that out to make it acceptable for Australian seamen, it would cost between $1m and $2m extra to provide the extra facilities required by our seamen. The cost of crews, even in new ships, is still 25 per cent higher than in comparable ships run by other developed countries. Of course, in the older ships they are very much more again. We must remember that it costs about $100,000 per billet. When one looks at billets in Australian ships another very interesting thing comes up. Our unions get six months leave a year. For a year's work they in fact get 338 days. This compares, for instance, with 216 days for an American, 174 for a West German, 141 for a Norwegian. When the matter was raised recently the unions said it was non-negotiable and that they were not prepared to discuss it. This is a ruthless rort. It makes Australian ships very expensive to run. We have got to provide 2.2 people for every crew billet. This again affects the whole community. Transport costs on the Australian coast are grossly excessive. Things that should go by sea do not go by sea because of the inefficiency of our coastal shipping and our ports. Those issues must be tackled.

The only way we will break the coastal shipping monopoly is to introduce competition. Monopolies can be controlled in one of two ways. The first is by enforcing tough legislation. It is very doubtful whether we have the effective constitutional power to do that, and it would be very difficult anyway. The second is by introducing competition. It cannot be done by negotiation. All the unions will do is make some minor concession here and take it up in some other area. People who have a good monopoly going will not yield it unless they are forced to. The only effective weapon governments have is to introduce competition. That is what this Government always refuses to do. It does not understand the value of competition, the economic efficiency caused by competition, and the great benefits to the Australian community which result from competition.

These are the sorts of things we must tackle to increase productivity, to involve our work force in the success of their enterprises and to ensure the living standards of the whole Australian community rise as they should rather than, as they have under this Government, falling further and further behind the standards of the rest of the developed world, involving us in the most enormous international debt in order to maintain the living standards we have. We have been borrowing, borrowing and borrowing to maintain our standard of living. Some time-and the time is now-all those debts are going to come in. We must work harder and more efficiently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with great interest to what has been said. I must say at the outset that the Government has no great argument against what is being requested by the motion in principle, of looking at macro-economic reforms, looking at reforms in the area of transport and the waterfront, and looking at better industrial relations. That is the direction we have been heading in since we took office, a direction in which we can travel reasonably peacefully and faster than the Opposition could ever imagine because there is an understanding between the trade union movement and the Government, one based on a partnership of trust and fair dealing, something that the trade unions have never had and could never expect from a Liberal-National Party government.

SPEECH.PARA: A lot has been made about raising productivity. As far as I am concerned, raising productivity in itself is no particular asset unless that productivity is to be shared amongst all Australians in a fair and equitable way. I am not interested in raising productivity so that companies and individuals can become richer while workers become poorer, work harder and longer, have reduced living standards and no real future, and go back to the days of the Liberal-Country Party government. Productivity has to be shared.

Senator Powell from the Australian Democrats made the point that they do not accept 7 per cent unemployment. Levels of unemployment throughout the world are a fair bit higher than they were in years gone by. I can recall a Liberal government almost being thrown out of office because of a 2 per cent unemployment rate. I can also recall recently a Labor government being re-elected with a fairly high level of unemployment. If we look to reducing levels of unemployment, to putting more people back into the work force until we have nil unemployment and look at our capacity, with high levels of technology, better management and better industrial relations, and our ability to produce so much more in terms of consumer and capital goods and services, we have to look at reduced working hours. When we look at reduced working hours those opposite throw up their arms in horror and say `You cannot do that. That will reduce productivity. People will have to work longer hours'. This is obviously to put more profits in the hands of the people who run industry.

Senator Powell also talked about industrial anarchy. Since the Labor Government was elected there has consistently been a lower level of industrial strife than ever before. A legitimate industrial dispute is not anarchy. Sharing the productivity is most important. We also have to look at the bigger picture. As we become more prosperous and share it amongst our people, we need to look at overseas aid to assist developing countries. For some time the workers have accepted wage restraint. And I am sure, from talking to them and the leaders of trade unions, that they will continue to accept it if it is in their long term interests and they can see a gain at the end of it. But they become increasingly frustrated and angry when friends of those opposite continually get wage increases. I understand that even one of our enterprises recently upped the ante by 100 per cent, from about $100,000 to $200,000 in a wage package by reclassifying a position of manager. Those opposite then say to a baggage porter or an aircraft mechanic for Australian Airlines, `You should have wage restraint'. One can put to them all the arguments one wants about the value of that manager, but it is a bit hard for them to accept it, and I understand that.

What is done with company profits? Are they reinvested? That is not our experience, and the figures show that. The trade unions have played a positive role. We believe that management should also play a positive role in terms of the required changes and concern for Australia as a nation. Let us look at the role of labour and capital and our Labor Government. As Senator Button and others have said, deregulation of banks, airlines and wheat and sugar was put in the too hard basket-which was full-by the Liberal and National coalition Government. We took on those hard tasks. I have long been an advocate of orderly marketing. I can understand why the National Farmers Federation has said that it wants to see no tariffs on manufactured goods so that its members can have cheaper inputs into their farm operations. But I find it a bit ludicrous when its members in the sugar and wheat industries then say, `We don't want our system deregulated. We want protection. Let's rip the workers apart. Let's get all our goods from overseas and have large areas of unemployment or reduced wages and living standards. But we want our protection'. That is totally dishonest.

I took the trouble to speak to some people in the trade union movement, one of those people being Ivan Hodgson, the National Secretary of the Transport Workers Union. Ivan's response to me about this matter was that his union has continually, over some years now, expressed a desire for cooperation in improving skills and operating methods in the transport industry. It has talked to top management of various companies about that and it has received a negative response. From my experience I would say that that is because top management feels it is its right to manage regardless of the effects on its employees and other people in middle and lower management. The Transport Workers Union has a very positive attitude. It is concerned about longer driving hours, higher road speeds, the danger to people on the roads, the deaths that have occurred. The unions want to cooperate. They want to see a reduction in transport costs. But they do now want to see this done at the expense of working conditions and the wages of their members. That does not need to happen. We can have both with better, more efficient management and better ways of doing things.

Ivan also has a view about benefits to the whole community. That is important to him. If cooperation does occur and things change and there is a reduction in transport costs, he wants to see the benefits passed on to the community, not bottled up in the profits of companies, which then benefit a few individuals. He is also concerned and expresses a view about the idea of integrated transport systems-using all methods of transport where they are most suitable. Let us face it: if there are job losses in some areas because of changes, our responsibility is to make sure that those people are retrained and put into other jobs. If we believe that under no circumstances should any people lose their jobs, then we are really in trouble. I know that Senator Parer has a good understanding of those sorts of things. He has worked in a real way in those sorts of industries. We may have different views on some things. There are certain indisputable truths that neither of us would walk away from.
The Waterside Workers Federation is always getting labelled by the Opposition. I spoke to Tas Bull. He sent me a document which sets out the attitude of the waterside workers. He says:

Self-serving solutions are not the answer. The waterfront is in desperate need of rejuvenation-it's time for a major revamping of the industry. We're calling for a co-ordinated plan to make Australia's ports efficient and reliable, a plant that involves employers and labour working together to ensure a skilled and motivated workforce, productivity improvements and a safe working environment.

That is not a troglodyte speaking. That is not somebody who does not want change. That is not somebody who does not have a concern about the community. He speaks about jointly owned companies, having one local stevedoring contract and the work being done at a lower cost to Australia's exporters and farmers as well as more efficiently.
Senator Hamer made a point about productivity not going up. The document states-I am sure this can easily be verified:
In the last 20 years productivity, measured by the number of tonnes moved on average by each waterside worker, has increased by more than five times.

Indeed, the numbers of waterside workers in Australia since 1950 have reduced from 25,000 to 6,000. If that is not making an effort on the part of the unions and the people who work in the industry, I do not know what is. Those opposite talk about work practices. The myth is that ours are very bad, but in fact other countries have invested more heavily in sophisticated machinery and computerisation. Australian waterside workers often work on cramped wharves with antiquated equipment. United States containers are loaded directly onto a trailer, ready to be driven away. In Australia, due to lack of space, containers are stacked on top of each other. This often means moving two containers to get to one. That is not a Waterside Workers Federation decision; that is a management practice. Yet those opposite would declare that as something that was inefficient and something that needed to be fixed.

The wharfies are considered to be really well paid. Until 1947, they did not get annual leave, they got no sick leave until 1956 and they got no long service leave until 1961; whereas most other workers in industry had those rights long before. Today the waterside workers are pioneering new ideas and initiatives such as multiskilling agreements, productivity deals, joint venture schemes and safer working environments. It is very clear: they are very forward thinking. They want to cooperate. They want to do something. But they will not be used by employers and they will not be used by the Opposition, which represents the employers. They want a fair and equitable position.

This material talks about 13 wharfies in Mackay who have a company in partnership with an employer. One of the workers said, `We are a lot happier on the job with the new company. The work is better; production is up; there is less tension. We are making the shippers and the users happy, so we stand to get more work'. They are just some of the things that the waterside workers are doing but get no credit for. Instead, they get abused and castigated.

The rail system has often been maligned. A review of the road cost recovery-occasional paper No. 90-has received widespread national publicity. Some of the things it talked about were the cost of railways and the money that governments have to put into railways by way of subsidy. It stated that heavy vehicles with three or more axles failed to pay their attributable road system costs by $1.49 billion. That is the extent to which the roads are wrecked, without money being put back in to have those roads maintained. The railways have got to totally maintain the track. Articulated trucks alone failed to pay attributable road system costs of $1.283m. The 26,000 six-axle articulated trucks plying Australia's road system failed to pay attributable road system costs by $828m or, on average, $31,865 per vehicle. I am not knocking the drivers of those trucks. They do a job, they are workers, and they are entitled to wages and conditions. But they are continually being asked to drive further and faster, putting road users and their own lives at risk.

Criticisms have been made by a person paid by the truck operators, Ms Kathy Robertson. The ARU's response was that the Bureau's report included all fuel taxes, whether Federal fuel excise or State fuel franchise fees. This means that the road freight deficit may be much higher than the Bureau's estimate of $1,497m because not all fuel taxes are levied as road user charges. However, even when all fuel taxes are considered as a road user charge, the point remains that the road freight deficit is $1,497m.
