It was then indicated that tax is paid on the fuel used by railway vehicles, but that money goes on the upkeep of roads, not on the upkeep of the railway's permanent way. So the railways are maligned because of their inefficiency when in fact it is not necessarily the case.

The railways asked for an industry council and the Railway Industry Council was formed. It is working to get a better and more efficient railway system. It provides railway unions with a genuine opportunity to influence the long term direction of the industry. It will not provide answers to current processes of labour rationalisation. For too long trade unionists have failed to become involved in the shaping and direction of their industry. It is the realisation of the Australian Railways Union that it now needs to get involved in the direction of the industry, get involved in what needs to be done and be part of management's decisions. If that is the case, the union has a responsibility to see those decisions work. Trade unions have an important role to play in our community, and it should be seen that they be given every opportunity to do that. The Railway Industry Council process is obviously not about solving the problems experienced by railway workers overnight. There again, the rail unions are being cautious. They are not saying, `Let's go on strike, let's have a blue'; they are saying, `It will not happen overnight, but let's work towards it'. With membership support, the process can be used by railway unions to overcome the longstanding institutional problems which have put the industry into decline and led to endless rounds of labour rationalisation. Without the support of those unions and others, we will never achieve the sort of goals that the Liberal Party is asking for. If one wants to look at problems, one should look at the institutionalised problem with the Victorian railways. It was going to put down a four foot eight inch gauge. The New South Wales Government originally agreed and put down a four foot eight inch gauge. The Victorians then put down a five foot one inch gauge. We hear talk about railway workers being efficient. That institutionalised system makes efficiency almost impossible. If we are going to achieve the things that need to be done not only for those workers but for everybody in this country, there has got to be a lot more cooperation and trust developed and a lot more working together in a meaningful way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating today the urgency motion moved by Senator Lewis which states:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the government to reform areas such as the waterfront, telecommunications, transport, coastal shipping and industrial relations . . .

Reference is also made to comments by the retiring Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia. We have three industries in Australia today that hold this country together-primary industry, mining and, more recently, tourism. The only advance we have made has been in the area of tourism. We have gone backwards in the manufacturing industry. This explains the high debt, the high current account deficit and the high balance of payments deficit that we now incur, even at a time when our terms of trade are the highest they have been for 10 years. This Government is moving into its seventh year.

Earlier in this debate the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, castigated my colleague Senator Lewis for quoting from various newspapers but promptly went on to spend the rest of his speech making selective quotes for his own purpose. Quite erroneously-he had to go back to December last year-he quoted from the document Future Directions, which has gripped the imagination of average people in this country who have suffered and who continue to suffer because of the economic mismanagement of this Hawke-Keating Government.

These days it is a common theme in the media, and I might say initiated by the Opposition, that there is an urgent need for the Government to tackle what is called micro-economic reform. Micro-economic reform covers the areas in the urgency motion-the waterfront, telecommunications, transport, coastal shipping and industrial relations. What it means is to face up to the tough issues-the inefficiencies of the work place, restrictive work practices-which unnecessarily add to costs and which are a major contributing factor to our own inability to compete on world markets with our manufactured goods. Senator Burns, quite correctly, said that he was not going to abide any method which would cut wages. We would agree with that. Our approach is to increase productivity to make us more competitive so that the individual worker gets a greater real return. That will not be done if we are not competitive and cannot market our goods.

There are, of course, appalling work practices in many industries. Most are steeped in history and were introduced by union militancy at a time when we could better afford to pay. The worst areas-and this was referred to by Senator Hamer-are those areas where there are monopolies. Monopolies are the most difficult to handle. A person in a manufacturing industry has an opportunity if things go badly to get into some discussion with his own work force and to correct them, but in a monopoly position that opportunity is not available. The days when this country could afford to pay are gone. We are now part of a competitive world which has shrunk. Compared with our near neighbours-Japan, Korea, Taiwan and now, of course, the emerging Thailand-we are from a productivity and manufacturing point of view approaching, if we have not already achieved it, Third World status. It gives me no joy whatsoever to make that remark. A country with our natural inherent wealth should not allow that to happen. Our standards of living have deteriorated and continue to deteriorate to a totally unacceptable level. As I have said before and will say again and again, the only way out of this morass is to become more competitive. We must export more; we must import less; and we must manufacture import replacement goods within Australia.

Our current account deficit is running at between $1 billion and $1 1/2 billion a month at a time when our terms of trade are at their highest for 10 years. Our net foreign debt is in the order of $100 billion and rising monthly. In an address I gave to a group of young people the other day, I amended the so-called seven beatitudes so that one said, `Blessed are the young in Australia because they shall inherit the Hawke-Keating debt'. That is what it has got to.

For an island continent a key factor to enable our exports to become more competitive is the waterfront-a classic monopoly area. There are two very large problems on the waterfront: the costs and the lack of reliability. I will talk about the costs, but before I do so I will cite a remark that was made to me just a week ago by a shipper, by whom I mean someone exporting. He said, `I wouldn't mind the cost if I could be assured of reliability. I will sacrifice the restricted work practices if I can be assured of reliability'. That is how important it is to him and others in this country.

Every good this country imports and exports must run the gauntlet of rorts and disputes on the waterfront which blow out costs and make vital exports uncompetitive on overseas markets. Our foreign trading partners, regrettably, are well aware of our abysmal record. Senator Hamer referred to it. In past years I was required to send telexes almost on a weekly basis to overseas countries declaring force majeure because of industrial disputations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was in government then?

—Let us ask ourselves who was the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions then. It was Mr Robert Lee Hawke. In 1984 the Baltic and Maritime Conference urged its members-this is why I mentioned overseas markets-to think twice about trading with Australia. In 1984 a South East Asian shipowner warned potential charterers to treat Australia like a communist country or a war zone. That was the feeling. It has not changed.

SPEECH.PARA: The list of restrictive and unproductive practices that beset the waterfront is a very long and sorry one. I will give a few examples. There is the infamous `nick system' under which two men are rostered to do one job and then take turns to nick off while on full pay. It is still going on; it has not changed. Another variation of this is the practice of drawing straws. Workers on night shift on the wharf work for a short time and then draw straws to decide which one will remain to the end of the shift to clock everyone off while the rest of the gang go home. In this way they all get paid for the full shift. The workers work on average about 28 hours a week, for which they are paid in the order of $800. That is a fairly conservative figure. It varies, sometimes going as high as $1,000 or $1,200. In addition to this they receive a whole range of extravagant allowances, including a site allowance, a telephone allowance, a laundry allowance, an obnoxious cargo allowance, a bad stow allowance-if they have to unload a badly stowed cargo-a noise allowance, a dirt allowance, a rain allowance and a cold allowance, to name just a few.

The real Achilles heel of the waterfront is the inflexibility of the work force. There is a reason for that: there is a pooling system. The present industry based system means that stevedoring firms must hire their work force from a pool. In other words, workers are not employed by a particular company. One week they might work for P and O, the next week they might work for the Patrick Stevedoring Co. Stevedores cannot choose either the number of men or the particular men in the work force, so they cannot match their labour to their work requirements. This is not a matter of saying, `We do not want that guy or another guy'. They need to do that for efficiency. I think everyone would agree.

In the ports around Brisbane, where I come from, the employment of casual labour is totally forbidden. If there is a peak and a couple of extra men are needed and if there are people who know how to operate the waterside where they live, they cannot be employed. If a port in Brisbane needs extra workers for a peak period they must be flown in from ports in other States-from Newcastle, Melbourne, Sydney or Adelaide. That is what happens. Last year in my own State of Queensland it cost $1m to transfer workers to the ports of Brisbane. That was just the cost of transportation and accommodation. Each of those workers cost $200 a day in air fares, accommodation and travelling allowances before he even began to work on the waterfront. So for a five-day week there goes another $1,000. That is what happens.

The workers are paid for 35 hours a week, regardless of whether they actually work. When they are not working it is called idle time. In recent years idle time-I heard Senator Burns talk about the port of Mackay and I hope it improves-has reached 60 per cent. Overmanning and featherbedding in stevedoring gangs is the key cause of waterside labour shortages. We hear about these shortages. Recently in Brisbane someone wanted to send a yacht to the Tokyo Boat Show. Last year he did it and sold 150 yachts. This time he was told he could not get it on the ship because there was a shortage of waterside workers. We managed to do it but I will not go into the reasons. I will keep that story for another day.

Stevedoring charges to load scrap metal cost one Queensland exporter $14 a tonne-to lift it from the wharf and put it on the ship. In the United Kingdom it costs 70 pence and in the United States $2 a tonne. The reason for the cost in Australia is overmanning. I think there were 14 people involved. I can give the numbers but time is going to beat me. The exporter spoke to me last week. He said he would have been happy-he had a 20,000 tonne cargo-to pay the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia $100,000 if it would stay away and let his people load the cargo, which he would do at a dollar a tonne. He would then save himself $8 per tonne.

As time is running out I will concentrate on what I think the Government should do. The Government is about to be presented-I believe it already has been-with the Inter-State Commission report. I understand it is going to be made public in the not too distant future, either in a few days or in a few weeks. It will be interesting to see how far this Government will go on the report of the Inter-State Commission. It will be interesting to see just what the Inter-State Commission will recommend. The general feeling within the industry is that it will suggest that we move away from the pooling system as a method of somehow getting a relationship going between employer and employee. Stevedores must have the right to set their own labour strengths. I am not suggesting that they be so choosy that they reject a fellow because they do not like the look of him, but they must be able to get the right person to do the right job. They must have the right to determine rosters. We cannot continue the nonsense that has been going on. They must have the ability, for example, to get rid of the silly nonsense whereby on every shift on the ports there must be a full time first aid man who does nothing at all but wait for someone to have a heart attack, which he cannot handle; he has to call an ambulance. Last year that cost the ports of Brisbane $1.5m. If those people had been freed up to work 17 more people would have been able to work on the waterfront.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a so-called urgency motion which is very bland. It seems to be rather a contradiction in terms. But in general it is saying that there needs to be micro-economic reform in this country and productivity needs to increase. Put in those terms, nobody could disagree. The problem with it is that in the speeches that have been made in support of it things have been said which indicate the political nature of the motion. Let me deal with it in those terms.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make some preliminary points. To my utter amazement, I found that in moving this so-called urgency motion Senator Lewis said not one word about what should be done, not one word about what the alternative government's program is about micro-economic reform in the areas mentioned in the motion or any other areas. That is a very significant commentary on the substance of the significance of the motion and the seriousness with which it is taken. In a sense it is not surprising because that draws our attention to what is not in the motion. It is often interesting to look at the way people draft motions such as this to see what they have left out. In this area of micro-economic reform there are a number of important issues. Surprise, surprise; nothing is said about deregulation of the wheat industry. It is the first chance that the Opposition has had since this motion was proposed to do something about micro-economic reform, and it has squibbed it. It is going to do nothing. It is serving its masters in the organised rural lobby, not the farmers, not the national interest.

Normally, one finds that Opposition members-and it has been a characteristic of this Opposition-are lions in opposition. They will tear down the problems, leap into them and be very ruthless; but suddenly they become lambs in government. In this instance they are lambs in opposition as well. In the Australian Financial Review this morning Geoff Kitney stated:
And because of this, doubts will persist about whether Mr Howard can translate an in-principle policy position in Opposition into actual structural change in Government.
. . . that he was held hostage by the National Party on micro-economic reform.
. . . Mr Howard has been seen as a politician with a strong philosophical commitment to market forces and deregulation, lacking the persuasive powers to have these views implemented.
Another article in today's Australian Financial Review states:
The Opposition has effectively turned the recommendations of two reports on the wheat industry on their heads . . .

Those reports had concluded that domestic marketing arrangements needed to be relaxed so that they could prompt improvements in the wheat distribution chain, resulting in significant savings to growers. But those two proposals have been rejected. It is very interesting that in this urgent need for micro-economic reform and efficiency, that obvious, significant proposal slipped through the net. It will be very interesting to see what happens when the matter comes before the Parliament.

The third preliminary point I want to make is that this is quite clearly a diversionary tactic to cover up the inherent contradiction of the macro-economic policies of the Opposition. It has been dealing for some time with the question that interest rates are too high. Therefore, it is obvious that people think that perhaps something should be done about it. Opposition members say that the solution is to tighten fiscal policy. But as Senator Walsh said during Question Time, they will not indicate where they would cut spending. Their alternative is to have a tighter wages policy, but somehow or other, simultaneously, they say that they are concerned about the living standards of Australian families. It may have escaped them that the living standards of Australian families are fundamentally determined by their wages.

They are saying that wages should be tied to productivity and simultaneously they are saying that the rate of productivity increase is zero. A fairly easy bit of arithmetic shows what the wages outcome of that policy would be. The only redeeming feature of that wages policy is that they are absolutely incapable of delivering it, as they were incapable of delivering it the last time they tried to introduce such a draconian wages policy. They failed then; they would fail again. The other implication which they are trying to hide is the impact of their economic policies on employment growth, which has been an outstanding achievement of the Government, and which they would undermine.

The fourth point I make covers both a preliminary point and leads me to the substance of the proposal. It is necessary to acknowledge that micro-economic reform is not easy. We need to distinguish between talking about important things and doing something important. There has been a lot of exposition about things that are important to the future of Australia. As far as I know, nobody who has participated in this debate has in any way challenged that. Let us not pretend that there is a magic wand. It is a long, slow and difficult task. This has been the first government to start to confront the matter. I do not want to pretend that we have solved it; I simply say that it is the first time it has been seriously confronted. Is anybody seriously saying that our waterfront problems have emerged since 1983, or that the problems in coastal shipping have arisen since 1983? Every serious commentator acknowledges that, although we have problems, the shipping situation has improved.

Has the telecommunications monopoly increased since 1983? Of course it has not; it has lessened. There is more to do. I am not trying to say that the problem is resolved. I am saying: let us face up to its seriousness and face up to it honestly. Has the system of consultation and arbitration which leads to this so-called rigidity been introduced by this Labor Government? Of course, it has not. Suddenly, we find that this is a so-called matter of urgency for micro-economic reform, and a few areas where the Government has been successful have suddenly been left off the micro-economic reform agenda because it is inconvenient. The Opposition might have to accept the fact that the Government has done too well. The Government has done better than the Opposition thought was possible, better than it could contemplate, so it decided that it would not talk about it. No wonder the public loses faith in our politicians.

Let us look at what has happened about the effective rates of protection for Australian industry in the last few years. The effective rate of protection as reported by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development-and it is not a unique analysis-in 1984-85 was 22 per cent. In 1986-87 it had fallen to 19 per cent and, on the policies as currently formulated, the OECD's estimate, which I think is commonly shared, is that by 1992-93 it will have fallen to 14 per cent. No one wants to pretend that that is the end; that we have reached nirvana. But it is the most substantial change in industry assistance in the history of Australia, the most substantial reform ever. Somehow or other that did not get mentioned. We have also had dramatic reform in the area of taxation policy, in terms of both efficiency and equity. The OECD report discussed it at great length. Senator Button covered it very comprehensively. Those things really need to be acknowledged. Senator Lewis, to his credit, made passing reference to it. In 1983, those were the key areas requiring micro-economic reform. They have been tackled and substantial progress has been made. More needs to be done; it is a long term issue. Let us be serious about it, let us not try to score cheap points on it.

Let us go to the key areas referred to in the motion as requiring attention: transport and communications and the labour market. The OECD defined four areas in a micro-economic reform agenda: industry policy, tax policy, transport and communications, and labour markets. Let us look firstly at the area of transport and communications. For a start, we have a very fundamental piece of micro-economic reform in the area of transport-the deregulation of the airlines. It has been talked about for a long time. There are even passing indications from time to time that it was the policy of the Liberal Party. But nothing ever happened. The only government that has ever dealt with that issue is this Labor Government. There has been a deathly hush about it from the Opposition because it knows that it was the right policy, correctly introduced.

There is a continuing, ongoing program of other activities in micro-economic reform in transport and communications. For example, there has been a wide-ranging package of reforms to improve the efficiency and performance of the eight transport and communication government business enterprises. Those changes are not necessarily the end of the road but they are substantial. They are the biggest changes since the last Labor government introduced Telecom Australia and Australia Post which were, in themselves, substantial reforms. We are in the process of creating Austel as a regulatory and price-setting body to oversight the monopoly powers of telecommunications enterprises. I certainly do not believe that the economic or social and welfare elements of Australian society will be enhanced by the fundamental trunk route of telecommunications being opened up to competition or being privatised.

Coastal shipping, which has been improved, needs more work, but the most substantial review of it ever is taking place at this moment. The task force which is responsible for that is likely to report to the Government this month. That will be when we are all put to the test. It is no good moving these waffly urgency motions and giving expressions of anguish. We need to wait for that report, which is imminent, and deal with it in a substantial way. Let us say what we are all going to do and then let us be judged by the voters on the merits.

The same situation applies to the waterfront. We have had years of inactivity, predominantly under the auspices of conservative governments. There has been a very extensive inquiry. As Senator Parer said, the Inter State Commission is likely to report soon. My understanding is that the report is likely to be tabled this week. Then we will be able to deal with the substance of what we are all proposing to do-no hand wringing, no grief and anger that somebody ought to do something about these things; we will all be put to the test and the voters will be able to judge us on our merits. So in that area there is a whole range of issues which we all need to confront.

We also have the fundamental question of labour market reform. In opposition, members of the Liberal Party have always spoken with great passion on this issue. Fortunately, in government they have been relatively ineffective in doing the things they say they will do-fortunately because most of these things would in fact have an adverse effect. But the fundamental thing is that they cannot achieve the most important contribution which industrial relations management can make to efficiency in the Australian economy: they cannot deliver industrial harmony. Their confrontationist approach always leads to an increase in the number of working days lost, which creates very significant problems for Australian industry and its competitiveness.

The award restructuring and workplace reform that are going on are the most comprehensive ever. They are not completed; more needs to be done. But in 1989 we have going on the most comprehensive reform since Federation. Yet the wimps who did nothing move an urgency motion saying that something needs to be done about labour market and micro-economic reform. The wage system has been developed in a way that facilitates micro-economic reform. A significant education and training program is under way-the most significant established by any Federal government. Award restructuring will provide incentives for skill formation and help to develop more flexible forms of work organisation. The Government is providing substantial assistance for the expansion of practices of information sharing and participation in decision making so that the processes of management and employer-employee relations can be substantially enhanced. The one certainty is that an adversarial approach will not bring about in organisations the fundamental changes in workplace and management attitudes that we require.

To conclude, I welcome the fact that Senator Button, alone I think amongst the speakers, recognised how difficult such reform is and will continue to be. There are no easy solutions. Much has been done and more needs to be done. This is a phoney motion of urgency. It is a diversionary tactic without a skerrick of a positive contribution-no proposal and no policy. It was designed simply to divert attention from the Opposition's lack of macro-economic policy and a lack of courage in respect of micro-economic reform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I moved this motion of urgency and I now wind up the debate. I totally reject practically everything that Senator McMullan just said. He challenged me to say what our policy is in this area. Let me put it to him in four simple essential elements. Our policies include reduced and restructured taxes, made possible by reduced government spending; reduced and less costly regulation of business activity; a more flexible labour market; and reduced business input costs, especially government taxes and charges. And if this Government had the courage to adopt those four policies it would not be in the bind it is in at present with the economy going down the drain at the rate of $15 billion per annum; that is, over $1 billion per month or $1.7m every hour. That is over $3 1/2m this country has lost in its terms of trade in the course of this debate in the Senate today.

SPEECH.PARA: This is occurring at a time when our commodity prices have been at their highest for 10 years. Indeed, some are at record levels. In addition, we have revenue from the massive tourist boom. What is the Government doing about this problem? It is doing absolutely nothing, except borrowing more and selling off our inheritance.

All that Senator Button could talk about was history. Indeed, some of it went back to `Black Jack' McEwen over 30 years ago. We are talking about micro-economic reform of the waterfront, coastal shipping, rail transport, road transport and communications. We are talking about productivity improvements. That is not some mystical process. It is, in effect, getting rid of waste. I refer to some of the explanations and detail given by my colleagues Senator Hamer and Senator Parer when they spelt out the sort of waste which is going on in this economy at present and the sorts of work practices which have to be altered by this Government. The Government has talked about it and talked about it. Reform in this area was to be the masterpiece of the third Hawke Government-and in fact it is nothing. The situation is so bad now that even the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia, Mr Johnston, has had to raise it as a matter of urgency. Let me quote what he said:
The so-called micro policies of reform-of work practices and the established ways of doing things-have a major role to play in raising productivity.
These are more-not less-urgent when all is not going smoothly at the macro level.
It could not have been put any clearer than that. I call upon the Senate to support this matter of urgency.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Lewis's) be agreed to.

ROW.ENTRY: (Senator Knowles did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Gietzelt).

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: NEW PARLIAMENT HOUSE PROGRESS REPORT AND BUDGET UPDATE JUNE TO AUGUST 1988

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On behalf of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) I present a statement and budget update for the new Parliament House for the period June to August 1988. I seek leave to have the statement incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
STATEMENT TO PARLIAMENT

Construction work on the Parliament House has now been completed. The work remaining involves defects rectification and the finishing touches to the formal gardens on the House of Representatives side of the building.

As in the past years I will now provide honourable members with the updated budget figures for the project which will bring them to August 1988 prices-just after the commencement of the Parliament's operations. Given the stage reached and the relatively minor movements in the budget, after that period it is the Minister's intention for future reporting to revert to six monthly rather than three monthly reports.

The revised building budget now stands at $914.4 million with another $158.45 million for the non building items. The total project budget is therefore increased to $1072.85 million in August 1988 prices.
This updating includes $1.64 million for the effects of inflation in the three months period calculated on escalating the unexpended portion of the budget.

Additional components include $0.77 million for redundancy payments and $1.56 million for industrial dispute costs. Only $0.32 million of this last figure is for costs incurred in the August quarter: there were no industrial dispute costs in July. The other $1.24 million were costs incurred for a significant strike in March 1988, the reimbursement for which was delayed until now.

After almost 8 months of occupancy, many of the early minor problems have now been rectified. I am sure that Members and Senators are appreciative of the improved facilities which of course contribute to the fulfilment of their responsibilities as representatives of their constituents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.
I have no wish to speak on this matter at the moment, so I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In speaking to the annual report of the Australian bicentennial road development program, I want to emphasise how much appreciated this program has been. Originally an initiative of the Fraser Government, it was supported enthusiastically by the then Minister, the Hon. Ralph Hunt. The program finally came into effect on 20 December 1982, for the purpose of providing a major impetus to the development of Australia's road system by the bicentennial year. This was to be financed by a special surcharge on diesel fuel and motor spirit. It is about the progress over those years and the expenditure of that surcharge that I want to make a few points this afternoon.

I commend the fact that a major part of the program has been to upgrade the national highways. However, in the process we seem to have forgotten the arterial and rural roads. The situation has now developed where local authorities have not been given enough for their own areas even to maintain those arterial roads. What has resulted is a major discrepancy between the two-wonderful national highways; however when we drive off the highways all we get are pot-holed surfaces and many times roads that have been returned to dirt and gravel instead of bitumen because councils cannot afford the upkeep. Local authorities are, naturally, very concerned about the Government's refusal to acknowledge that insufficient funding has become a gigantic problem. Cuts have been particularly bad and have had a major impact in country areas. It has become impossible to keep up with the demand for new and improved roads to cater for the needs of the transport industry and the individual motorist.

Some months ago, the Royal Automobile Club of Queensland undertook a State-wide survey of roads and found that country roads are so rough that motorists are often forced to drive on the shoulders rather than on the potholed bitumen. It also found that many roads become impassable when it rains, and that they are deteriorating more rapidly than city and shire councils can repair them. Existing networks are rapidly falling into disrepair because of the decline in maintenance allocations. The transport industry and private motorists have been forced to bear the financial burden of increased maintenance and operating costs brought about by declining standards of road maintenance. The high cost of wear and tear on transport vehicles is then being passed on to consumers in the form of higher prices. I emphasise that a safe, reliable road network is of fundamental importance to our nation's economy.

As this report indicates, the Australian bicentennial road development program was to be financed by a special surcharge on petrol. What has happened is that while more than half the money spent by motorists on petrol goes to the Federal Government, for every litre of petrol or diesel purchased, the Government takes about 30c in tax, returning only about 5.35c to the motorist in the form of road funding. Consequently, it has placed greater financial strain on local and State authorities, already struggling to cope with rising costs.

The present Government's spending on roads has fallen by 30 per cent in real terms over the last four years, including a direct cut of $33m this financial year. In other words, that represents a total cut of $350m. No wonder our roads are falling apart.
Although my time is running out, I take this opportunity to quote from a number of articles about the state of the roads in rural Queensland. One said:
Lack of road funding is an insult to every travel- ling motorist. It is an insult to our intelligence to get so little back from our fuel tax for our roads.
Another said:
It is unfair that people in the most productive areas of Australia have to put up with deteriorating roads while money for roads is lavished on Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra.

We need to think about all these comments for a little longer than the five minutes we are given to speak to these reports. I have no doubt that when the Bill dealing with the bicentennial roads comes in I will be able to say a little more about this. The road network is vital to all Australians. It is the vital basis for our economy. This Government has an obligation that extends beyond the national highway network to ensure that all Australians are served by the highest standard road network.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The annual report of the Australian bicentennial road development program attempts to set out the contribution made by this Government to improving Australia's roads network. When reading the document one notes not so much what the Government has achieved but rather what the Government has failed to achieve because in this regard there is certainly much more to report. As some of us would know, Australia's roads carry 97 per cent of all passenger journeys, 77 per cent of all freight, 83 per cent of all domestic tourism and 43 per cent of overseas tourist journeys between capital cities. Poor roads serve to isolate communities, increase fuel consumption, damage vehicles and increase the cost of goods.

SPEECH.PARA: On page 4 of the report, under the heading of benefits, reference is made to the savings in vehicle maintenance and running costs, including fuel consumption which comes from better roads. It is ironic, therefore, that over the past five years, while the present Hawke Labor Government has been in power, most motorists have wasted two weeks of their life sitting in traffic jams. These traffic jams are becoming the bane of all motorists. Up to 20 minutes of each peak hour can be spent standing still. Around half the fuel used by motorists could be saved if the present stop-start traffic jams were avoided. On highways, fuel consumption could drop by up to 30 per cent if the Government was prepared to do something about it.

Let us look now at the source of funds for the Government's road development program. As the previous speaker, Senator Bjelke-Petersen, said, this Government has used fuel taxes to bludgeon the Australian motorist into submission. Petrol, a necessity for so many people, is taxed at the rate of over 120 per cent. In 1983-84, 66 per cent of fuel excise was spent on roads; now it is just 23 per cent. In 1988, 5.66c a litre of the fuel excise was spent on roads. In 1989 that figure has gone down to 4.95c a litre.

Research by automobile authorities has revealed that half of the existing road surfaces in Australia are over 20 years old. As previous speakers have said, 20 years is considered to be the maximum life span of a road surface. The neglect which this Government has allowed to occur will mean that it will be faced with massive costs for replacement. I note also that if a road is widened by one metre the number of fatalities occurring on that road can be halved. If funding were to be provided to allow for the provision of dual carriageways, we could reduce the number of fatalities by around 80 per cent. It has been said by automobile authorities that this Government's cuts in road funding could result in something like 7,000 lives being lost by the year 2000. About 600 people a year will die because of funding cuts.

The Australian public is by now well and truly fed up with the neglect of our roads. As a result, we have recently had placed before us the fourth major roads Bill from this Government in the last four years. The latest one, the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill, allows the Government at the stroke of a pen to cut the level of funding owing to roads. It contains a veritable minefield of potholes for the unwary motorist. The indexation provisions contained in the ACRD legislation operate when they are determined by the Minister. We know that the Australian land transport program also was supposed to be indexed. However, the Government saw fit to index down the initial 3.66c per litre to 3.241c per litre to keep a constant dollar value of $810m. This latest price deflator manipulation has increased by 8 per cent less than the consumer price index. So the Government's fuel tax rip-off will continue its increasing spiral with a fuel consumption increase of about 3 per cent per annum. It will not be long before that figure the Government reaps is $6.5 billion.

Finally, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister responsible will have ample scope under the ACRD program to manipulate the level of road funding in real terms and, therefore, further discriminate against Australian motorists in order to meet their election promises.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Australian bicentennial road development annual report 1987-88. I support the report and the previous two speakers, Senator Bjelke-Petersen and Senator Calvert, in what they have said about the problems with Australia's roads. I would also like to place on record the fact that Ralph Hunt set the Australian bicentennial road development program in place when he was the Minister responsible in the Fraser-Anthony Government.
—It has been destroyed by this Government.

—Yes. I will get to that in a minute. Mr Hunt did a great deal for this program. It is a pity that this Government has done the damage that it has to it. The program is nearing completion and it is a sad thing that all that was set out to be achieved has not been achieved. As a rural based senator I find that the most frequent complaint is about roads. It is little wonder, because we have a government that in one month can provide millions of dollars to build a bridge across a river in South East Asia, yet it cannot find the resources to help the people in Wellington, New South Wales, to build a bridge, or to provide funds for other river crossings across the State. People definitely have a right to complain about how this Government has treated the road system in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: For many months of the year our roads are impassable. The recent wet weather has caused enormous problems for thousands of country people. Only this morning I received a complaint from a veterinarian who lives no more than 30 kilometres from this building. He has been complaining about the state of the road in his area for the past three years, as have his neighbours. In desperation the local community has on several occasions made temporary repairs itself. When people complain to the local council they are told that no funds are available for repair. Instead of providing a more permanent solution, the council keeps sending out trucks with sand to toss in the creek crossing. The result is that there is both water and sand on the road and unsuspecting travellers get their cars bogged in the mess regularly. Understandably, this veterinarian is fed up. He asked me what can be done.

The people in the Yass and Goulburn districts are asking how many people must die before the Hume Highway is upgraded and diverted away from these towns. Let us look at the figures for New South Wales in the last year. Some 1,041 people died on the roads, but the preliminary figure for injuries as a result of accidents in New South Wales during 1988 stands at 36,700 people, with 9,000 of those people being seriously injured. As we drive along the Hume Highway we are likely to see half a dozen wreaths on the posts signifying the latest victims of our national highway system. This is the same highway along which the Government proudly displays signs telling us that it is a bicentennial road project. Let us remember that in May 1988 Senator Walsh admitted to the Parliament that there was actually a cut in road expenditure of $350m in just four years. That is the problem besetting this country at the moment. Country people will not stand it for much longer.

The Government raises some $7 billion through taxes and excises. This is likely to rise dramatically this year to $10 billion, yet only $1.2 billion of those taxes is being put back into the road system. We can understand people's anger. We must also remember that for every $1 million not spent on roads transport industry costs increase by some $3 million. This country cannot afford to have its road funding cut back as this Government is doing. The Government stands condemned for what it is doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The annual report on the Australian bicentennial road development program reveals that $72.5m is being spent on the section of the Pacific Highway between Sydney and Newcastle to the west of Lake Macquarie. This section was opened to motorists during the year. This $72.5m worth of work is of great significance because it is the money that should have been spent on the Berrima-Mittagong bypass when the previous Government set the Hume Highway upgrading as the top priority for the national highway system and the Australian bicentennial road development program.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hume Highway was given top priority by the excellent Minister for Transport and Construction, Mr Hunt, because in fact it is the highway which carries major traffic volumes and sustains the greatest number of deaths and disasters. Instead of proceeding with what was described at the time as the Mittagong-Berrima bypass-a bypass of two towns-which was planned in 1981-82 and agreed by the communities in that region and the State Government as having top priority, Mr Peter Morris, the Labor Minister for Transport in the new Labor Government, who lived in Newcastle, had a different set of priorities. So instead of the towns of Mittagong and Berrima being bypassed, only the Berrima section of the bypass was opened, just a couple of weeks ago. As a result, the town of Mittagong is an isolated island in the midst of two long stretches of freeway. This is the worst possible position to leave a town in, particularly a town which has many young and old people. It is a ludicrous situation because these people have to try to cross a road which is heavily used by trucks and cars which come off freeways at both ends of the town. The people who made that decision to divert that funding away from the Mittagong and Berrima bypass must bear a heavy responsibility for the inevitable accidents and loss of life that will take place in the four years that we will now have to wait before the freeway bypass that had been planned back in 1982 is eventually completed.

On the day that the Berrima section of the bypass was opened, I protested to Mr Hollis, the local Federal member for the area, that it was a tragedy that only half of the bypass had been completed. He denied that there had been any plans under the previous Government; he denied that there had been any plans by Mr Hunt or the Department; he denied that there had been any priority given to the Hume Highway. He said that in fact there had been no plans for a bypass when he had been elected as the member for Macarthur. Of course, that is simply false. All of the residents of the region know that it is totally, completely and malevolently false. The evidence for that comes from his own mouth. Shortly after his election in 1983 he said that the Mittagong and Berrima bypass-that is, a single bypass-would commence shortly and that the Labor Government was committed to funding the bypass. He did not say `two bypasses'; he said `the bypass'.

The fact is that Mr Hollis has so failed his electorate, the people of Mittagong and all drivers who use the Hume Highway, and this Government has succumbed to pressure from a former Minister for Transport from Newcastle, that roughly 30 kilometres of freeway on the western side of Lake Macquarie with a very low traffic frequency relative to the Hume Highway is now receiving priority of funding in the classic Labor pork-barrelling fashion that this Government is famous for. It is a disgrace that this money has been diverted from this Hume Highway bypass. I can only hope that despite the dangerous position in which the town of Mittagong has been placed by this Government, it will in fact escape with few accidents.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In taking note of the annual report on the Australian bicentennial road development program, I want to draw the attention of the Senate to a recent and what I consider to be a somewhat shabby exercise that has been entered into by the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support, the Hon. Bob Brown. Mr Brown wrote to local councils on 10 March to argue against the case presented by road user organisations such as the Australian Automobile Association (AAA). In that letter he attempts to discredit that campaign for more road funding. In one part of the letter he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have been concerned that one of the three Government partners in our road development programs would choose to ally itself with a private motorist organisation in its campaign against one of the other partners.

Local councils could well be confused by Mr Brown's perception of partnership. Road funding has been cut by successive governments unilaterally. During the course of the Australian bicentennial road development program, the report of which we are discussing today, spending in real terms has declined. In all that time local government has never been invited to be represented around the table when the decisions on expenditure have been made. The bicentennial road development program was not a project in partnership with local government by any stretch of the imagination, because local government was never given the opportunity to participate in the decision making about the level of funds to be provided.

Prior to the adoption of the successor of the bicentennial road development program-the Australian centennial road development program-there had been no invitation for our partners in government at the local level to consult with the Federal Government in order to reach a consensus on the best approach. Had such an invitation been issued, it would have been enthusiastically accepted by local government and perhaps its input would have meant the avoidance of the misunderstandings that resulted from the defective bit of legislation that was presented to the Senate before Christmas last year.

In his letter to the councils Mr Brown went on to suggest that the Federal Government should not have the major responsibility for roads. He says that accepting responsibility for the national highway system should be enough. We all know the effects of that. Despite the Federal Government being the major beneficiary of the fuel excise levy, after national highways take the cream off the top of the revenue can, local roads are at the end of the funding queue. Local government is entitled to make the point that the major beneficiary of road user charges should take the major responsibility for expenditure.
Mr Brown goes on in his letter to say something with which I can agree. He says:

Fuel taxes were never intended simply to finance road-works. They are part of the Government's total tax structure and like other revenues also assist other areas of government responsibility such as pensions, education, health, defence, assistance to veterans, child care, and so on.

The one problem with that argument is that almost all the government services which he has listed have also been the subject of cuts. In some cases, like pensions, veterans' entitlements and child-care, the cuts have been severe and are carried by those in the community least able to bear them.

The statement the Minister makes begs the question of where the revenue goes. Some undeniably goes to compensate for the loss of revenue resulting from negative gearing for company takeovers-a tax measure to look after the Government's corporate mates. Local government is entitled to feel cheated when it is aware of the use that is made of these funds-funds that are desperately needed for road infrastructure.

The Minister, in an attempt to mislead the readers of his letter, vaunted the fact that $20m had been spent on national roads since 1983. He tried to fudge the issue that in real terms funding has declined. Mr Brown told local councils of his disappointment at the photo on the front of the AAA brochure, which he says is a desert track somewhere in the outback. I have seen plenty of bitumen roads in the country which are being torn up because councils cannot afford to maintain them any longer. The Minister concludes his letter by saying:
You will understand my disappointment that some councils in our third tier of government would choose to support and assist the AAA campaign.

The Australian Democrats support any public awareness campaign which ensures the truth about such programs as the bicentennial road development program. We think this letter from Mr Brown is a pretty shabby exercise which is unworthy of him and the Government. Our partners in government have not been treated as partners in respect of road funding. The road networks are disappearing. A letter which is aimed at misleading and intimidating councils is not worthy of this Minister.

In conclusion, can I just say that the Democrats would like to see an Australian centennial rail development program developed as a road safety measure similar to the program we have for roads. That is a measure which we will be pressing forward with over the course of this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate myself with this report which has come at the most important stage of the Australian bicentennial road development program. The sunset clause expired on 31 December 1988. On reflection, it will be one of the measures which former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser will be remembered for. I know it is the norm among some members of this place, including my own colleagues, to berate Malcolm Fraser but he certainly introduced some measures that will last for many years to come. Amongst those was the Australian bicentennial road development program.
—Name the honourable senators who berate Malcolm Fraser.

—We will talk about that some other time. Perhaps the honourable senator may be more interested in the roads that need funding in Western Australia. The point I make is that I was in local government when the measure was first introduced. At that time 2c per litre of the fuel tax was passed on to road making-not necessarily to maintenance, but to road improvement and new road development. For the first time local government could budget with confidence to improve the road system in Western Australia. In the earlier 1980s we certainly saw the improvement of the Great Eastern Highway, the freeways around Perth and the Great Northern Highway. In fact, the Great Northern Highway was finally sealed, through this scheme, right through to Darwin.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, in the last three or four years under this Government, with cuts in funds, we have seen the deterioration of roads in Western Australia and also the postponement of urgent works like the Northam bypass. If Senator McKiernan ever gets far enough away from the city-100 kilometres or less- he will see that the northern bypass is a much needed road. Improvements on the Great Eastern Highway have had to be delayed time and time again because of the lack of funds.

This Government indexed fuel excise to the extent that it has now reached about 21c per litre, but the Government failed to index what went back into roads. I do not decry the fact that some of the duty on fuel goes into other measures that Government has to fulfil in social security and other matters, but what goes back into roads must also be indexed. This Government has failed badly in that respect.

We all know that while the amount of fuel excise used for roads is not indexed, the cost of road making is certainly indexed by the increasing cost in labour, fuel and so on. As one example, a fairly decent-sized, heavy road grader that one could buy for $100,000 four years ago would now cost $400,000 when this Government has pegged what it puts into roads at $1.2 or $1.5 billion. There is certainly indexation in that way. That is the reason State governments and local governments cannot keep up the spending on roads that they should.

Of course, the Australian bicentennial road development program gave way to the issue that we debated in the dying hours of the spring session in 1988. Once again, the Government has fixed the amount that will go back into roads at 4.95c a litre instead of starting off at a figure of 6c which would once again get money back into roads. That would be an increase of about 25 to 30 per cent above what is the case at present.

It is not too late for this Government to index that figure now so that we can once again build good roads and, what is more, safe roads. The Minister for Resources, if he does get out into the country in Western Australia, will see that that is needed and will report that back to his Government and ask it to fix its folly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for consideration of Government papers has expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 March, on motion by Senator Schacht:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade is an important one since it surveys the entire field of Australia's overseas aid and development assistance program. Importantly, it confirms the fact that this program has suffered a disproportionate burden of expenditure reductions in recent years compared with other portfolios. As I said in debate early in March on the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (General Capital Increase) Bill, official government development assistance and aid has dropped from about 0.56 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) to 0.36 per cent in the three years to 1988. The Development Assistance Commission of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has indicated that no other member country has ever reduced aid volume so dramatically.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a very important point to remember, particularly when one reflects on the Australian Labor Party's stated policy in this area. There is again a reduction from 0.56 per cent to 0.36 per cent of gross domestic product. The report echoes many of the views that I put forward in the recent debate in March. I would like to focus today on that section of the report dealing with Australia's participation in two international financial institutions: first, the World Bank and, second, the Asian Development Bank.

I had hoped that the report might have appeared prior to the debate in this chamber in March on Australia's share increase to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development since the report does enforce the arguments that I made at that time for more comprehensive reporting of Australia's participation in the World Bank and, indeed, the Asian Development Bank. The Joint Committee says that Australia's policy towards the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank is not based on a broad view of the banks as developing agencies, bodies that must take into account social and environmental effects and goals in the shaping of their programs. Rather, the Committee believes that policy is based on too narrow a view of the banks simply as banks, bodies that borrow and lend funds for different purposes and simply judge whether there are going to be sufficient returns on loans to cover costs.

That is not what the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank are about. It is pleasing to see that at least the World Bank has in recent months expressed itself unequivocally on those issues. To help bring Australia's policy towards the World Bank into broader perspective, I moved on behalf of the Democrats in that recent debate an amendment that would, amongst other things, have called for an annual report that would be made by the Treasurer in terms of our participation. Such a report would look at three major items: the effectiveness of the World Bank's programs on the alleviation of poverty, the effectiveness of the programs to prevent environmental degradation and what account has been taken of the views and needs of indigenous peoples.

While a gutted form of our amendment did pass, those essential elements unfortunately were not amongst the items that the Government would be required to report upon. The coalition accepted the Government's assertion that reporting would be too difficult. I think it is interesting that, while this chamber thought that that type of reporting would be too difficult, the American Congress, as one legislature, has made mandatory far more comprehensive reporting than even I was suggesting. It seems to believe it is feasible. Indeed, with regard to the alleviation of world poverty, it went so far as to set down the precise indices that should be used in judging the effectiveness of programs-for example, female literacy rates, death rates of children under five, and a number of others. In other words, there are concrete measures by which we are able to ascertain whether those types of programs going into various places are effective in the alleviation of poverty.

During that particular debate I made the point that the World Bank is trying to report publicly on those issues. I find the analysis in the Committee's report reinforces even further the points that I made when it states:

Effective membership requires greater participation and awareness of development issues in policy formation. The Bank's implementation of this poverty alleviation strategies requires a broad understanding of developing countries. The programs must be carefully monitored . . .
Again I quote:
The Bank's president . . . has introduced a requirement that each report to the IBRD board on adjustment programs comment specifically on the program's social impact on the poor.

Those particular items should be noted in terms of this report because they show that an increasing emphasis is being placed-unfortunately not by our country but certainly by others-on the operations of those particular institutions. Again, the Committee notes that Australia's leading representative at the Bank's executive boards is always a Treasury officer. The Committee underlines the fact that there is no guarantee that this person will have expertise in development issues. Furthermore, the Committee does not find any effective dialogue between Treasury and the development experts in Australia's International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) on matters of policy substance. The Committee says:

There must be regular and real dialogue between senior Treasury and AIDAB officials on the critical issues facing the banks. A proper Australian position on the Banks' approach to structural adjustment, Third world debt or the impact of aid on the environment cannot be achieved by the current resort telephone calls and faxes.

To overcome this situation, the Committee recommends that responsibility for policy formulation should shift away from Treasury and towards AIDAB-attached, as it is, to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. To this end, the Foreign Affairs and Trade Minister, not the Treasurer, should be Australia's representative on the boards of governors of both the World and Asian Development Banks. The Australian Democrats concur wholeheartedly with that suggestion. The argument that needs to be carried in this regard is that we are not looking at narrow financial principles-as Senator Stone and Senator Walsh argued in concert in that recent debate-but rather at the broader world view and the view that countries such as Japan have lately indicated that they are pursuing, and policies which the World Bank, in terms of its turning down of the loan for further dams on the Amazon, has recently indicated it is now willing to follow.

Those three issues-the alleviation of poverty, the effects on the environment and the views of indigenous people-are three items that ought to form the backbone of our attitude to further operations in this area. That resolution of the Committee and its recommendation to have the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade as the representative rather than the Treasurer would go a long way to bringing those broader and probably more sympathetic views, from our point of view, to bear on the operations of our relationships with those development authorities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report, A Review of the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau and Australia's Overseas Aid Program, is a very important one and it has taken a considerable amount of effort to compile. I hope that the Government takes good notice of the recommendations. I would like to mention just a few of them-first of all, one on volume. I quote from the report:

SPEECH.PARA: If Australia's adherence to the 0.7% ODA:GNP target is not to become purely rhetorical there must be rapid growth in aid as a proportion of GNP. By 1992 Australian aid should once again stand at 0.5% of GNP.

We are a long way short of that. Our current level of foreign aid is 0.36, which is just up a little bit from 0.34 of the previous year. As Senator Macklin has said, in the previous year the Development Assistance Committee of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development was quite scathing in its criticism of Australia's contribution to foreign aid and talked about the level of cuts which were evident in the previous budget. I quote from the report:

The Committee regretted that the aid budget had suffered a disproportionately high share of the cuts in total public expenditure . . . In view of the urgent aid needs of many developing countries and the desirability of sustaining an adequate joint aid effort, the Committee urged the Australian authorities to resume real increases in aid.

It is to the Government's credit that last year Mr Hawke's guarantee that aid would not fall below 0.36 per cent of gross national product (GNP) occurred in the last budget. It is welcomed but it falls far short of the Australian Labor Party platform commitment to achieve 0.55 per cent by 1990. Of course, the new Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, made some speeches along those lines when he first took over the portfolio. He said that he hoped that the level of aid would be increased from 0.36 per cent of GNP to 0.40 per cent in the next budget. It remains to be seen whether that will be a reality but I hope that it will be as the first stage of reaching that commitment of 0.55 per cent of GNP by 1990.

There is a lot of public support for increasing Government foreign aid. Public opinion polls indicate that people still believe that Australia can and should help the poor. Public support for aid is reflected strongly in the significant increase in public donations to non-government organisations. Donations increased from a total of $33m in 1982 to $68m in 1987. The amount has more than doubled in five years. There is a lot of community support for foreign aid. It is always worth reminding people in the Australian community, and particularly the decision makers, that aid is a two-way street. Over 90 per cent of Australia's bilateral aid is provided as goods; that is, food aid, machinery, etc, or services such as those of agriculturalists, doctors, teachers and so on sourced in Australia. Cutting aid actually means job losses in Australia. In looking forward to the next budget, we hope that there will be no cut in foreign aid.

Equally, of course, the economies of neighbouring Third World countries must grow and develop if trade opportunities are to improve. As we keep hearing from our Asian and Pacific neighbours, who are the major recipients of Australian aid, they are really seeking economic security. Even if we are considering it only from a position of enlightened self-interest, providing as much aid as we can within our region is a means of peace-keeping and building good relationships.

The Australian aid program needs a poverty focus. This has been very clearly outlined by the Australian Council for Overseas Aid (ACFOA), the umbrella group of non-government organisations that cooperates very closely with the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB), the Government organisation, to fund and provide the infra- structure for overseas aid. What ACFOA has to say about a poverty focus is very important. Public support for foreign aid in Australia is principally dependent on aid having that focus. People support giving aid because they want to see poverty ended. It is gratifying to understand that there is that support in the community, that people have a global outlook and are not only concerned with improving their own material lifestyles. The second reason is that the impact of aid will be greatest if focused on assisting the poor. Recent studies such as Does Aid Work have highlighted the effectiveness of targeting aid to assist the poor. Aid does work.

Several other donor countries have adopted a poverty focus. Last year the Canadian Government agreed to a new emphasis in its aid program on dealing with poverty first, on human rights and on partnerships with non-government groups. That sounds like a very good balance to me. The Dutch Government's poverty focus for its aid program has strengthened domestic support for the aid program and protected the program from cuts whilst other areas of public expenditure have been pruned. We have not quite got to that stage in Australia yet, but I hope that we will and that there will be a greater conscience about Australia's contribution to ending poverty worldwide by making sure that we have a very healthy aid program focus in our region.

Achieving a poverty focus requires a geographical focus, sectoral priorities and acceptance of popular participation as the key to successful development. Popular participation is very important indeed, because it has been demonstrated very clearly that non-government organisations, when they are reaching directly to the people who are to be the recipients of aid, find that aid moneys are not wasted on programs which are not designed to suit the needs of the recipients themselves. Obviously, if they have got a lot of say in designing programs, the money will be best spent.

It has also become very clear that too little Australian aid is targeted for health programs, particularly preventive health programs in the Pacific island states. Too much Australian aid goes to large scale capital intensive infrastructural projects. Health, education, training, village level agriculture and water resource development should be given more emphasis as they are the cornerstones of a poverty focus.
I would also like to comment on the section in the report's recommendations on human rights at paragraph 10.55 on page 139. I quote from the report:
Effective aid delivery demands consideration of human rights issues . . .
Broadly speaking, aid should be increased to those countries where the observation of human rights is improving. Where the opposite is the case aid should be reduced . . .

In cases where abuse is particularly serious, and the government is recalcitrant, the suspension of aid should be considered. The effectiveness of the sanctions in changing government performance must be addressed. Australia should follow the course of action most likely to improve the lives of the victims of human rights abuse.

The Philippines would be a very important case study in considering the question of aid in relation to human rights. Human rights violations in the Philippines have been very well documented by an Amnesty International report. I recently had the opportunity to visit the Philippines and saw for myself many examples of violations of human rights. I know that Senator Gareth Evans raised the question of human rights violations when he met President Aquino and others in the Philippine administration. However, I do not think that he was nearly tough enough on the Philippine Government in that respect. That is exactly what the report suggests, that where violations of human rights are particularly serious the suspension of aid should be considered. I am not suggesting the suspension of aid altogether, because poverty is rampant in the Philippines, the people desperately need help, and they consider that they have a lot of support in their struggles for social justice and their moves towards democracy. I believe that our aid should be redirected towards non-government organisations, of which there are many ready, willing and able to take any transfer that comes from Australia as the aid is withdrawn from government to government projects and directed to the people who need it most.

I do not think there could be much argument about the violations of human rights which continue in the Philippines. Many people I met said that the abuse is now much worse than it was under the Marcos regime. They repeatedly told me, `Under Marcos we were afraid of being detained; under the Aquino Government we are afraid of being killed'. That was volunteered to me over and over again. Anybody who is working for a cause oriented group in the Philippines is considered a subversive and is considered liable for targeting by the vigilantes in what Cory Aquino has described as her policy of total war. There can be no democracy in the Philippines at the point of a gun. I experienced democracy Philippine-style at the point of a gun when I was there and it was not a very pleasant experience. So I do not believe that we should be giving any support to the Cory Aquino Administration while these violations of human rights continue. They are abounding and increasing and their record on human rights is getting worse.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am tempted on this occasion to debate the question of the Philippines as it has been raised, but I want to concentrate on the appalling record of the Hawke Government in relation to foreign aid as is now recorded by the bipartisan Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I refer particularly to chapter VI of the Committee's report headed `The Amount of Aid'. It reminds us that since the report of the Committee to Review the Australian Overseas Aid Program, known as the Jackson report, aid has in fact been slashed by 19 per cent in real terms. In other words, between 1985-86 and 1988-89, 19 per cent has been slashed in real terms from the contribution that Australia makes to foreign aid. It is also emphasised in the report that these cuts have come at a time when conditions have been worsening in most developing countries. So the consequence of this slashing of aid is greater than might be first appreciated.

SPEECH.PARA: The report looks very briefly at why this cut may have occurred and clearly forms the view that the cut has occurred because it has been the easy option for government-a soft option, emphasised by some research which, I must say, regrettably indicates that Australians feel that if one is going to cut in some area it is better to cut assistance to other countries and to those who are worse off. I regret that this Government has adopted that easy option and, therefore, in what I accept have been difficult economic times, has slashed foreign aid, as Senator Macklin mentioned a moment ago, at a greater rate than any other area the subject of government cutback.

The most dramatic year was 1986-87, which involved a cutback in real terms of 11.9 per cent. The Senate will remember that year as the year in which this Government embarrassingly abrogated the just renegotiated foreign aid agreement with Papua New Guinea (PNG). This Government, after renegotiating a reduction in that agreement, which was not easy for PNG to accept in its difficult circumstances, within a matter of months reneged on its agreement. As I recall, it sent Senator Gareth Evans on a trip to PNG, our nearest neighbour and the greatest recipient of our assistance, to tell its Government that we were chopping another $10m off our aid contribution. The consequences of that unilateral cut far exceeded the monetary consideration. There was a considerable loss of confidence by PNG in Australia that has never been totally overcome. It was a matter of regret to many of us at the time that this Government would fail to keep its deals in a way that resulted in a lowering of Australia's standing in the international community.

Additionally, these cutbacks regrettably have meant that the greatest cost has been borne in regions that can afford it least; in other words, in the regions of the world where there is chronic poverty, particularly in areas of Africa and South East Asia. That has occurred because a considerable percentage of our foreign aid goes to PNG, although we reneged upon our deal, and because multi- lateral support is locked into the Budget. Therefore, the bilateral assistance we have offered to desperate places has gone to those who have suffered the greatest share of the burden. I believe that is regrettable, and I use this opportunity to state so.

Furthermore the Committee mentioned that the result of these cutbacks may well have had a detrimental effect on the quality of Australia's aid. The reason for that, of course, is that significant aid projects take some time to put into place, to establish, and require some ongoing support. If there are continual cutbacks, it tends to be in those areas in the first instance and, therefore, the quality of assistance can be detrimentally affected.

I would like to mention-as Senator Macklin did-that it is not only this bipartisan committee of the Parliament or the Opposition that has lamented the Government's appalling record in this area, but it has also been noted by the international community. I particularly refer to the Development Assistance Committee (DAC) of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, the donors club committee. It described the fall in Australian aid as unprecedented-that is, that no Western country has ever reduced aid so far so fast. What an appalling indictment upon this Government! Late in 1987 the DAC conducted its biannual peer review of Australia's aid program. Almost half of its two-page press release was devoted to criticism of Australia's declining aid volume. I find that embarrassing. The Opposition finds that embarrassing. The Committee notes that the United Nations target-the target we all know in foreign aid being 0.77 per cent-has now fallen to almost 0.3 per cent. The Committee expresses its concern that this target expressed as percentage of aid against gross national product is now simply becoming purely rhetorical. We experienced that in recent times with Senator Gareth Evans giving speeches saying how his Government was going to arrest this decline and contribute to an increasing record in this area. Yet if we look at the years of his Government, we see it went down from 0.51 to 0.5 per cent to 0.46 per cent, down to 0.38 per cent down to 0.37 per cent and now down to 0.36 per cent.
