This is a consistent pattern of decline. There is no evidence that indicates the Government is going to do anything to arrest that decline.

The two specific areas that immediately come to mind that are required to be addressed-I think I have addressed both on previous occasions in the Senate as being short-sighted examples of the Government's policy-are in relation to United Nations bodies. The first is in relation to the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD). That fund was formed in 1977 to address the need to increase food production in the poorest food deficit countries. This Government has declined to meet the third replenishment of IFAD, a matter that has been criticised by the international community, by the United Nations, by the World Bank and by our own private donor organisations-Community Aid Abroad and the Australian Council for Overseas Aid. It is short-sighted because it is a body that can contribute to helping the poorest nations of the world increase their own food supplies, which is something I would have thought all Australians would wish to see. It is short-sighted also because it is an opportunity for Australian commerce, through this organisation, to get further into the world of international consultancies, which can actually be highly remunerative. A country that suffers our balance of payments problem I would have thought would be one that would want to use these opportunities.

The second short-sighted area is the Government's intention to withdraw from the United Nations Industrial Development Organisation. Similar arguments apply and the Committee, at page 81 of the report, drew the attention of those who read it to the fact that Australian companies are losing opportunities for investing in developing countries as a result of this decision. I draw the attention of the Senate to this short-sighted approach of the Government. On any humanitarian approach the Government's record in this area is appalling. If one looks at a foreign relations approach, our capacity to influence within our region and in the international community generally, the result of the Government's policy is that we have reduced capacity to influence in ways that can be to our benefit. If we look to the purely pragmatic commercial basis, as I indicated a moment ago, as a result of this Government's policies Australia is losing commercial opportunities, which is foolish in our current precarious economic circumstances. I abhor what the Government has decided to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem with sessional orders in discussing a report such as this report of the Joint Committee on Foreign, Affairs, Defence and Trade-a review of the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau and Australia's overseas aid program-is that we only have 10 minutes to address very major issues contained therein. I would have liked to address quite a number of the issues that have been raised in this report quite rightly by the Committee. But because of the limitation of 10 minutes I will have to focus on some of the recommendations and conclusions of the report which are questionable. I will deal briefly with one of the recommendations of the Committee concerning population which is dealt with on page 110 of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The recommendation of the Committee that Australia substantially increase its funding to the United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA) will multiply the shameful attacks on the human rights of the world's poor which have been perpetrated by the well-heeled international population control establishment. This recommendation appears to be based on information which has been given to the Committee by Dr Sadik, the director of the UNFPA, which is misleading, and by certain demographers. I have studied the transcript. Some of that evidence is downright false. The Committee, not having been made aware of all of the facts, has done its best. Indeed it sought to ensure that no funds be paid to organisations involved in countries pursuing coercive family planning practices. However, false and misleading statements have been made to the Committee. I note that the Committee's report says at page 108:
In their discussions with Dr Sadik, the executive director of UNFPA, members of the Committee sought assurances that UNFPA had not funded programs which involved coercive programs.
It then goes on to say:
Dr Sadik advised the Committee that a review conducted by the US Agency for International Development had found that UNFPA had not been involved in coercion.

Clearly, anyone who knows anything about this whole area of population control would see that as being laughable. I admit that the Committee simply stated what Dr Sadik said, but that was blatantly misleading. The United States decision in 1985 to cut all United States funding to UNFPA was made on the basis that the UNFPA was involved in funding the Chinese population control program, which is the most coercive in the world. It is a denial of basic fundamental human rights. Did Dr Sadik tell the Committee that? Did she tell them that the Australian taxpayers' money would go to support population control practices in China, where couples are ordered to refrain from having children without prior authorisation under the threat of sanctions consisting in most cases of deprivation of health, education and housing services, and in many documented cases of forced sterilisation and abortion? Had I the time, I would go into the studies which show that the most favoured method of population control is now the coercive sterilisation of large numbers of people.

Did Dr Sadik tell members of the Committee that the United States official aid bureau, USAID-the United States Agency for International Development-announced as late as June 1988 that the United States would again shun UNFPA because UNFPA assistance to the Chinese Government `indirectly contributes to a coercive family planning program'? Did she tell the Committee that UNFPA is the major contributor to and co-sponsor of a $40m HRP program-that is, the human reproduction program. That program is involved in developing the abortion drug RU486 and the anti-HCG abortifacient drug for population control in the Third World? Incidentally, it is very noticeable, in reading the transcript, that one of those who gave evidence, Dr Hull, stated, in answer to the honourable member for Dundas, Mr Philip Ruddock, that this drug was a contraceptive vaccine. He said, `You can think of it as making the egg immune to sperm'. That is absolutely false. It is scientific nonsense. If he did not know it, he ought to have known it. I do not have time to give the description given to me by the Department of Community Services and Health and by the HRP program itself.

Did Dr Sadik tell the Committee that the review which she claimed cleared UNFPA of involvement with coercive programs had not been made on the basis of an audit of UNFPA, but simply on the basis of statements made by officials of the UNFPA? Subsequently, further studies had been done and evidence had been given to the Foreign Relations Committee of the United States Senate which clearly showed that China was continuing to be involved in a denial of human rights and in coercive population control programs. The details are contained in a very substantial document which I have with me. That was sufficient for the United States Government to continue its refusal to fund the UNFPA.

A number of other highly misleading statements were made to the Committee which, unfortunately, I do not have time to go into, but which I will be happy to discuss with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) and with others who may wish to know the facts. One should bear in mind that an appeal to the Committee to increase funds to UNFPA was made by two or three demographers who are on the population control gravy train. I believe that Australia should abolish the support that it is already giving to UNFPA, totalling $700,000, and it ought to reject any suggestion that it should give more money. Clearly, UNFPA is involved in coercive population control programs and in developing-despite what it says-abortion drugs.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 March, on motion by Senator Aulich:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to speak to this report entitled Education for Active Citizenship because it is an excellent and important report. It is also in many respects a terrifying report because it tells us what many of us here already knew-that is, that many people in Australia know very little about what parliamentarians do and they have little knowledge of our democratic system. The Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training must be congratulated for presenting this report, which is an enormously important piece of work. If the recommendations of this report are heeded and implemented, Australia should develop into an effective participatory democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most fundamental elements of democracy is the right to vote in free and fair elections. I am seriously concerned that State and Federal elections are at times little more than media manipulated monopolies. Surveys in Western Australia carried out by members of my staff have shown that only a tiny minority of voters-perhaps 10 per cent or even less-have a full understanding of our preferential voting system. The majority do not know what preferences are. They do not know what determines when or whose preferences are distributed, nor who has control of the direction of preferences. I am sure that many senators have also received calls in their offices from people who say, `How am I to direct my preferences?', or `Where are you directing my preferences if I vote for you?'. They do not have a full understanding that every voter has total control over his preferences.

Proportional voting, such as that which is used to elect us to this place, is understood by even fewer voters. This is an irony and a tragedy because our electoral systems are, in the main, amongst the fairest and most advanced in the world. It is unfortunate that we had an aberration in the Australian Capital Territory, the modified d'Hondt system. We are awaiting the final results of that election, even though the election was held on 4 March.

If we do not have a proper education program on our voting systems in the electorate, people cannot competently use the excellent electoral systems which we have in Australia. One cannot use one's vote intelligently in a preferential or proportional system if one does not have an understanding of exactly what that system is. That can result in an inane protest vote, which is quite different from a deliberate protest vote of course. Very often it also results in an unintended abstention which causes an aberration in election results.

Protests can also be seen in the registering of some strange parties. In Victoria at one time, for example, the Deadly Serious Party proposed policies which included pensions for one-legged seagulls. That sort of thing does not help our democratic process. Indeed, there were a few strange parties in the ACT election, including parties which seriously proposed the abolition of democracy. With regard to people who advocated a referendum on whether the ACT should have self-government, that referendum should have included all interested parties. Of course, that means that the whole of Australia would have to decide the issue. If the ACT is to be governed by people who represent electorates in other parts of Australia, the people of Australia should have a say on that issue, too.

The recent State election in Western Australia saw the sudden emergence of Grey Power as a political force. We had candidates of good heart who stood because they were eager to help the plight of the aged in our community. Indeed, the plight of a number of the aged in our community is quite severe. I spoke with some of these candidates myself and they had no understanding of the electoral system under which they were standing. In Western Australia there was a new system for the election of the Legislative Council which is based on the Senate system. These people had no understanding that their party's registered preference card would lead to the preferences of people who voted for Grey Power with a `1' in the box above the line going a particular way. Therefore, a group which arose as a protest against the status quo served only to reinforce it by the way its preferences were allocated.

So when we have a general lack of political literacy in the community things happen in election results which ordinary people really do not want to happen at all. As a result of this report, maybe we are moving in a new direction. It has certainly been pleasing to hear speakers on the Government side and the coalition Opposition side highly commend this report and its recommendations. If indeed the recommendations are implemented and we do have a community which understands our electoral systems-how democracy works and how in a democratic society people can have direct input into it-I believe there is hope for us all.

I would like to refer briefly to the recent Australian Capital Territory election results. I have always regarded the Australian Capital Territory as a particularly alive and aware community as far as democratic systems are concerned, and the election results here were very interesting. There will be a new style of assembly, with neither of the major blocs having a majority. It may be that as a result of that we see a new style of governing which is not an adversarial style but a consensus style. As far as the Democrats are concerned, that will serve the people in a much better way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report entitled Income Support for the Retired and the Aged: An Agenda for Reform was tabled in the Senate on 7 December 1988, so it is still being debated some time after its tabling. Perhaps this is part and parcel of the history of this report, because a committee to inquire into income support for the retired and the aged was first set up on 6 September 1983. Because of other work in which this committee was involved it was unable to report before the date of the double dissolution of the Parliament in June 1987. At the commencement of the present Parliament the Senate asked the new Community Affairs Committee to resume inquiry into retirement income provisions in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: This new Committee was set up on 22 September 1987 with only three of the eight members of the former committee appointed to it. The evidence had already been taken and, in fact, the report existed in draft format. This provided some problems for the Committee. However the stated aim of the Committee to provide a `more adequate, equitable and cost-effective retirement income provision for all' is reflected, I believe, in the recommendations of the report.

The report is divided into two parts. Part one has the recommendations in regard to income support provided through the social security system. That part of the report would therefore be of particular interest to those who are totally or almost totally dependent on government pensions to support them in their later years, whereas the second part of the report examines the occupational superannuation systems. Therefore, that part will be of particular interest to those in the community who have or expect to have superannuation provide part or the total of their income in their later years.

Before I look at the recommendations in any great detail I would like to provide the Senate with some of the many statistics set out at the back of the report, because they are of extreme interest. I will look first of all at the principal sources of income for males. Of males aged between 65 and 74, 9.5 per cent rely on superannuation whereas 70 per cent rely on government pensions. Of males aged 75 years or over, 10.9 per cent rely on superannuation for their income and 75.2 per cent rely on government pensions. I turn now to females. Of those aged 65 to 74 years, only 4.5 per cent rely on superannuation whereas 79.4 per cent rely on government pensions. Of those aged 75 years or over, 2.5 per cent rely on superannuation and 85.1 per cent rely on government pensions. Therefore, it is the first part of the report that would be of interest to the majority of people and it is the recommendations in that part of the report I shall concentrate on.

The first recommendation is crucial. It recommends that the level of the age and service pension be increased. At present the pension is about 24 per cent of average weekly earnings. The Committee did not choose to give a preferred percentage but, from all the evidence received, people who are totally dependent on pensions find it very hard to manage on that amount. So an increase should be looked at right away. This recommendation, like the majority of recommendations in part one of the report, was supported by five of the eight senators who sat on the Committee. I would like to add my personal regret that it was not supported by more members of the Committee. The other recommendations in part one of the report advocate an increase in the level of rent assistant and a reduction in the pension adjustment time lag. Prices go up, but pensions do not go up accordingly, which causes a lot of difficulty for people in managing their every day concerns. It certainly is very important that pensions be adjusted automatically and on a regular basis so that people who are totally reliant on pensions know where they stand and are not extremely disadvantaged during the time lag.

The taxation treatment of pensioners causes them to carry an unwarranted tax burden. Pensioners who are in a tax bracket or who are earning minimal sums of money are taxed on those sums of money. That takes away the incentive for people who are reliant on a pension to improve their circumstances. The Committee recommended that there should be a common qualifying age for the age pension, which in these days of equal opportunity legislation seems to be the right move. But I do have some personal reservations about that age being 65 and not 60. Both men and women who do extremely hard physical labour often find it hard to continue doing that sort of work beyond 60 years of age and, of course, with the present unemployment rates in the community it makes better sense for some people, who wish to, to retire earlier rather than later. However, the Committee did recommend flexibility as far as pensions are concerned, so that some pensions would be available at an earlier age.

I think the most interesting proposal by the Committee was what it referred to as a long term reform option. This was put out as a matter for discussion rather that as a firm recommendation. Members of the Committee did hope that the Government would at least look at this sort of option so that there could be more lateral thinking about pension schemes. This reform option involved a two-tiered age pension system. This means that there would be a flat rate 20 per cent pension right across the community-this would take away the disincentive for caring for oneself in one's later years-and there would be a top-up of a further 10 per cent of pension for those who have no other source of income. The Committee had this costed out and the detailed costs are on page 135 of the report. Believe it or not, on the figures for pensions paid out as at 1 January 1988 there would be a net saving of $0.4 billion. So, I hope that the Government will look at that option.

Time is running out; so I will refer only very briefly to part two of the report which, as I said before, relates to income support provided through occupational superannuation schemes. If the recommendations are implemented, there will be more incentive in the community for people to provide for themselves through superannuation schemes. Employers also will be under some pressure to provide superannuation schemes for all employees, with portability of those schemes.

In conclusion, this report deals with very serious matters as far as our community is concerned. We are faced with a greying of the population. A greater proportion of our population will be concerned with these matters and they are not going to go away. Simply importing vast numbers of young immigrants to support our older Australian population will not solve the problem. We need to look at support systems for the aged in a new way, and I hope that this report will contribute towards that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise at this stage the question which I raised during the course of the debate on the second reading-namely, the provision of the solatium payment. The Minister will recall that during the debate on the second reading I raised the question of whether the Government had given any thought to changing the arrangements for solatium payments from a flat payment of $10,000, which would be indexed by movements in the consumer price index, to some other formula which was related more directly to the actual total value of the land which is being acquired.

SPEECH.PARA: I also seek from the Minister some comment on the question which has been raised in a number of representations which have been made to the Government which indicate that there are other things which ought to be taken into consideration in the establishment of the problem. I refer in particular to a submission made by the National Farmers Federation, which says in part:

The Bill rightly seeks to compensate those whose property has been compulsorily obtained by government but does not go far enough in addressing legitimate and intangible loss and distress faced by those whose land or part thereof has been acquired.
The Federation goes on to say:
The Administrative Appeals Tribunal should be the proper forum for the settlement of such claims in addition to those claims for compensation as identified in the Bill.

The NFF makes the point that clearly farming families who have worked properties for generations have an emotional attachment to the land in a way which is indistinguishable from an attachment to a home. As the Minister knows, a solatium is provided essentially for emotional recompense for the acquisition of a home, being a dwelling place. The Farmers Federation goes on to draw attention to the acquisitions of quite substantial parts of land which may be necessary for the completion of the very fast train project, for example. I understand that these sorts of matters have been raised in the Labor Party Caucus within the last couple of days in terms of some exploration of the consequences which may flow from the very fast train project proceeding.

I therefore seek the Minister's comment on those two matters: first, whether the Government has been persuaded that there is any validity in the argument that the solatium payment itself should be related not to a flat fee but to the value of the land which is being acquired; and, secondly, whether the extension of a solatium payment to compensate people for emotional attachment to the land, in exactly the same way as they are being compensated in the provisions of the Bill for emotional attachment to their dwelling place, has received any further consideration by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal with the last point first. The Australian Law Reform Commission, in its report, identified the particular case of a person's home being compulsorily acquired causing that person to have to move from where he or she was living, and a particular item of compensation was identified to cover that circumstance. However, there may be other circumstances in which a person's property is compulsorily acquired and that person has had some particular attachment to the land. In such a case that person may feel that the compensation assessed on all the quantifiable aspects of the property would not be sufficient to compensate for his or her personal loss. In such circumstances there is nothing in the Bill which would prevent an item of claim for compensation of that nature. More significantly, subclause 55 (1) allows for such a claim by providing that the amount of compensation that a person is entitled to is that amount which would justly compensate the person for the acquisition. Putting it in layman's language, if one has a particular affection for the back paddock, or whatever else, that can be a case for receiving compensation.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of what is really a fixed sum versus a variable amount, the Government considered the proposition for solace payments and considered a number of options. Some Australian States provide a householder's solatium for the amount to be paid linked to the value of the property acquired. I think that is what Senator Puplick was considering. The Government believes that this is not a valid basis for payment since the intangible losses suffered by less affluent socio-economic groups are not necessarily any harder or harsher than those suffered by those who are more affluent in the community. In other words, I am appealing to Senator Puplick's romantic side rather than to his economic determinant side to say that the loss of a house or a property and the emotional drain that goes with that process is not necessarily related to one's bank account-nor should it be. We are relatively firm on this matter. Therefore, we ask for a fixed statutory thing-indexed, of course. I think it should be indexed. That is the basis on which we are proceeding now with the first query that Senator Puplick raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his explanation and answer. I will now raise with him the question which, again, I raised yesterday in the debate on the second reading on this matter-namely, the impact of capital gains tax provisions in relation to acquisitions which are made. To put it briefly, if a person is required to make a sale and purchase of a property, or make a sale of an asset, as a result of the Government requiring him to sell that asset under the compulsory powers or the coercive powers which are available to the Government to acquire land, does that render the person liable to pay capital gains tax? Is that a particularly fair situation? I will encapsulate it in this form: if the Government requires somebody to sell a property to the Government because it intends to acquire property under the provisions of the land acquisitions legislation, the vendor has no recourse other than to sell. He would not have sold other than by being compelled to sell by the provisions of the lands acquisition legislation. But because he is compelled to sell, he is put in a position where he has to pay capital gains tax. In other words, the Government both forces him to sell and forces him to pay a capital gains tax on a sale which he would not voluntarily have made but for the acquisition powers of the lands acquisition legislation. Does the Government believe that that person should be entitled to relief from the payment of capital gains tax under those circumstances?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether Senator Puplick can hum the Twilight Zone theme-we are getting into areas which I am not expert on and one is the tax Act. However, one can draw a distinction between compulsory acquisition, as I understand it, and a negotiated settlement. As I understand it, if compulsory acquisition occurs, it is not subject to capital gains tax. That is as I understand it. Senator Puplick may put as much credibility on that as he can, but I think I am right on that point.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of the negotiated agreements, it may well be that the tax Act comes into play. But I have to say that the appropriate mechanism for dealing with that problem is the tax Act and not the Lands Acquisition Act. I do not think we could put a clause in this legislation, even if we were minded to, to override a tax Act in that way. If there is any correction needed to that interpretation, I will certainly pass it on. But I believe that is right.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. He will recall that when I spoke yesterday I indicated that it would be clearly preferable for the tax Act to address this matter. Could I simply seek from the Minister some indication that if in fact a major problem appears to be developing in terms of the burden of capital gains tax-that is to say, if something comes up before the course of the next Federal election and before the election of the next Liberal-National Party Government, which, of course, will do something far more substantial about the capital gains tax-the Government in any review of the Lands Acquisition Act will be prepared to examine the interrelationship with the taxation arrangements and not simply say that that is a matter which is purely related to taxation administration and therefore would not even be considered in any review of the effect of the Lands Acquisition Act, if one is undertaken in the course of the next couple of years?

SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

SPEECH.PARA: Pages 55 and 56, clause 124, line 14 (page 55) to line 2 (page 57), leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
Mining, etc. on certain land
``124. (1) The Governor-General may authorise the grant of a lease or licence to a person to explore, recover or mine for minerals on land situated in a State, which is vested in the Commonwealth.

``(2) Subject to such exemptions and modifications as are prescribed, the mining laws of the State in which the land is situated shall, so far as applicable, apply to a lease or licence under this section, and to exploration, recovering or mining carried on under the lease or licence.
``(3) In this section:
`mineral' means a naturally occurring substance or mixture of substances;

`mining law' means a law relating to the exploration for, or mining or recovery of, minerals, and includes a law relating to the protection of the environment from the effects of such exploration, mining or recovery;
`land situated in a State' means:
(a) land in a State vested in an acquiring authority, being land that is a Commonwealth place for the purposes of the Commonwealth Places (Application of Laws) Act 1970; or
(b) land in a Territory, being land:
(i) vested in an acquiring authority; or
(ii) that:
(a) is in a conservation zone within the Northern Territory pastoral lease area; and

(b) by a grant under section 12 of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 is vested in an Aboriginal Land Trust, whether the vesting occurred or occurs before or after the commencement of this section.''.

The purpose of this amendment is to delete clause 124 in its entirety and to insert a new clause as per the provision of circulated amendment. In my address yesterday during the second reading debate on this Bill, I drew attention to the fact that we have some concerns that whereas the 1955 Act, which this legislation is now replacing, had a mechanism to guarantee compatibility with State practices and procedures in relation to mining, that does not appear to be as entirely clear in the 1988 Bill. This section deals almost exclusively with the question of mining.

When this matter was debated on 20 October 1988 in the House of Representatives, my colleague, Mr Fife, the member of Hume, made the point that from time to time State laws are passed and modified in terms of their relationship to and impact on the operation of State mining regimes. We believe that if the Bill were passed in its current form, new regulations to the proposed Act may be required each time State legislation is changed.

We believe that by retaining reference to State laws in the Bill, there would be no need to modify the regulations under the proposed Act as changes are made to State legislation. It is for that purpose that I have moved the amendment on behalf of the Opposition. By the reinsertion, essentially, of the 1955 formula we would have a system whereby automatic effect would be given to changes in State mining law. If the clause is allowed to stand in its current form, every time a State mining law and practice is changed there will be a need for changes in the Commonwealth regulations to accommodate that. That will be unnecessarily burdensome and time consuming. The reversion to the formula of the 1955 Act guaranteeing compatibility with State practices and procedures is a more preferable action to take.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Several people have expressed concern at the mining provisions contained in the Bill. Although this matter was addressed in debate in the House of Representatives, I will elaborate on the Government's intention and the reasons why these changes are necessary. For many years there has been a perception within the mining industry and some State mines departments that exploration and mining on Commonwealth land was either not allowed or was just too difficult or time consuming to attempt.

SPEECH.PARA: Back in September 1986 the Government established an interdepartmental committee (IDC) to examine the problems in this area and to formulate possible solutions that would streamline the administration of exploration and mining on Commonwealth land. One of the major problems identified by the IDC was the present Lands Acquisition Act. The sections in the present Act that deal with exploration and mining on Commonwealth land are imprecise and inconsistent. The present Act provides that State laws, subject to such exemptions and modifications as are prescribed, shall apply to mining on Commonwealth land in a State or the Northern Territory. The same provision is not made, however, for exploration on Commonwealth land.

A further shortcoming in the current Act is that the exploration and mining provisions apply only to land vested in the name of the Commonwealth. For land vested in the names of most Commonwealth bodies, there is no mechanism that currently allows exploration licences or mining leases to be issued. This resulted in poorly defined administrative procedures. The present system is not working well.

The Government's objective is to facilitate access to Commonwealth land for minimal exploration and development while at the same time both protect its use of the land and meet its statutory responsibilities for environmental protection and heritage conservation. To this end, the Government has recently decided on a multiple land use policy that will apply to all Commonwealth land, the only exceptions being national parks and Antarctica. This policy will ensure, firstly, that a proper resource assessment is undertaken prior to acquisition; secondly, that the wider interests of the Commonwealth are considered in determining land use and not just the specific use to which the land is put; thirdly, that the mining industry is aware of the general guidelines that are likely to govern its operations on Commonwealth land; fourthly, that Commonwealth land is used as efficiently as possible in returning a benefit to the Government and the country; and, fifthly, that environmental and heritage interests are adequately protected when considering development proposals to mine or explore on Commonwealth land.

The other major recommendation was that revised provisions on exploration and mining on Commonwealth land should be included in the Lands Acquisition Bill and that regulations should be developed based on multiple land use policy. The regulations will prescribe all conditions under which exploration and mining will be allowed on Commonwealth land. The mining industry will know exactly what it must do to obtain access to Commonwealth land. The regulations will be drafted after consultation with the States and the Northern Territory.

The regulations will contain provisions similar to those relevant State mining laws and at the same time ensure that the Commonwealth meets its statutory responsibilities in managing the land it owns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some brief concluding remarks on the remainder of the Lands Acquisition Bill 1988. It has been a very difficult Bill for successive governments to come to grips with. I would firstly like to commend the Minister for the way in which he has been prepared to allow public comment and to involve himself and the Government with representations from groups throughout the community in order to produce a number of amendments which have taken into account those individual comments and suggestions. I believe this is a very proper way of dealing with an extremely complicated piece of public policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, I would like to again place on record the very considerable debt which Parliament owes to the Law Reform Commission, in particular Mr Justice Wilcox, for having undertaken the major inquiry which has brought about the new piece of legislation. Finally, I would like to pay tribute once again to all of those members of the Land Acquisition Reform Committee, particularly John Duff and Mary Turner, who have played very significant roles in generating the public debate and the various public forums and public meetings which I have attended, Senator Brownhill has attended, Mr West has attended and departmental officers have attended in order to make sure that there was maximum public input on this piece of legislation.

Now that we are on the verge of having a new Lands Acquisition Act, it is clear that the Act will be tested fairly promptly by all of the requirements for acquisition both in relation to Badgerys Creek and, potentially, in relation to the very fast train project if it is to proceed. I commend the Department. The officers who will be responsible for administration of the Act will have a very hard task in front of them in dealing with these very complicated areas of acquisition.

I was very heartened to hear the Minister indicate that the matter will be kept under review in a way which undoubtedly will bring forth the capacity to make amendments after the Act has been seen in practice for some little time. I believe this exercise has been important and worth while, although frustratingly slow in many respects. Undoubtedly the officers of the Department feel a great deal more frustrated that anybody else as far as this particular matter is concerned. The Bill in its amended form does have the very warm-heated support of the Opposition. We look forward to participating in any reviews or in any further development of this legislation which may be necessary in the light of experience.
Remainder of the Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a short statement to correct part of an answer I gave to the Senate yesterday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a statement to clear up a misrepresentation that occurred in the ANU Reporter. Since it is not a personal statement but one in regard to my Party, I had no course other than to make a statement on the adjournment. In the ANU Reporter Vol. 20, No. 3, of Thursday, 23 March 1989, the following paragraph appears:

SPEECH.PARA: A spokesman for the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, told ANU Reporter that although the list of proposed legislation awaiting debate in the Senate was lengthy, the amalgamation Bill could be brought forward so that the legislation could be in place for the 1 July target date set by the Minister for the creation of the new ANU. He added that the Government expected the Bill to be passed by the Senate with the support of the Democrats, if not the Opposition parties.

That particular proposition, presumably coming from a spokesman for the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), was accepted at face value by the reporter who wrote this particular article in the ANU Reporter. As soon as this hit the newsstands-basically the Australian National University-my phone in Parliament House lit up and did not stop for days. My staff wasted an enormous amount of time correcting what was a view of the spokesman of the Minister which had not been checked with me by the reporter. The spokesman for Mr Dawkins can say what he likes in a political context; I am not having a go at that spokesman. But I am very disappointed that a reporter printed this as is, particularly because in the previous issue our position was stated very clearly. Our position is as of October last year when I issued a statement that we were opposed to amalgamation. It has not changed. The reporter who wrote this article did not check with me and presumably did not bother checking with the previous edition of the paper and went ahead and published this article.

I put to the editor of this paper that, if in fact a spokesperson for me had said that the Government had decided to drop the whole idea of amalgamations, that person would have rung the Minister. Likewise, I expect that, on such matters of contention and matters in issue before the Parliament, it would be a responsible exercise on the part of a reporter before publishing this as a main, lead story on page one at least to do the courtesy of checking with people who are quoted as having a particular position which is diametrically opposed to that which is currently on the record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

So that other people can have equal pleasure and equal access to it, I seek leave to table the text of the sermon.
